</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	All Mineral Reserves have been calculated in accordance with the CIM Standards.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(2)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	The Mineral Reserves for the Pe&#241;asquito Project set out in the table above have been
	estimated by Robert H. Bryson, MMSA, who is a qualified person under NI 43-101. The Mineral
	Reserves are classified as proven and probable, and are based on the CIM Standards. See
	&#147;Description of the Business &#151; Mineral Properties &#151; Mexico &#151; Pe&#241;asquito Project, Mexico &#151;
	Mineral Reserve and Mineral Resource Estimates&#148; for further details.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(3)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	Numbers may not add up due to rounding.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-17-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage33"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Mineral Resource Estimates
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<B>
	Cautionary Note to United States Investors Concerning Estimates of Measured, Indicated and Inferred
<BR>
	Resources
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;This section uses the terms &#147;Measured&#148;, &#147;Indicated&#148; and &#147;Inferred&#148; Resources. United States
	investors are advised that while such terms are recognized and required by Canadian regulations,
	the United States Securities and Exchange Commission does not recognize them. &#147;Inferred Mineral
	Resources&#148; have a great amount of uncertainty as to their existence, and as to their economic and
	legal feasibility. It cannot be assumed that all or any part of an Inferred Mineral Resource will
	ever be upgraded to a higher category. Under Canadian rules, estimates of Inferred Mineral
	Resources may not form the basis of feasibility or other economic studies.
<B>
	United States investors
	are cautioned not to assume that all or any part of Measured or Indicated Mineral Resources will
	ever be converted into Mineral Reserves. United States investors are also cautioned not to assume
	that all or any part of an Inferred Mineral Resource exists, or is economically or legally
	mineable.
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following table sets forth the estimated gold, silver and copper Mineral Resources for the
	Red Lake Gold Mines, the Porcupine Mine, the Musselwhite Mine, the Marigold Mine, the Wharf Mine,
	the &#201;l&#233;onore Project, the Dee/South Arturo Project, the Los Filos Mine, the El Sauzal Mine, the San
	Dimas Mines, the Pe&#241;asquito Project, the Alumbrera Mine, the Marlin Mine, the Pueblo Viejo Project,
	the Cerro Blanco Project, the Escobal Project, the Noche Buena Project and the San Nicolas Project
	as of December&nbsp;31, 2009:
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 18PT">
<B>
	Measured, Indicated and Inferred Gold, Silver and Copper Mineral Resources
</B>
<SUP STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: TEXT-TOP">
<B>
	(1)(9)(10)
</B>
</SUP>
<BR>
<B>
	(excluding Proved/Proven and Probable Mineral Reserves)
</B>
</DIV>

	1,697
</B>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-20-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage36"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT">
<A NAME="X60364EXV99W1_HTM_111">
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
	Mineral Properties
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT">
<A NAME="X60364EXV99W1_HTM_112">
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 18PT">
<B>
	CANADA AND THE UNITED STATES
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Corporation&#146;s properties in Canada and the United States include the Red Lake Gold Mines,
	the Porcupine Mine, as a joint venture, the Musselwhite Mine, as a joint venture, the Marigold
	Mine, the Wharf Mine, the &#201;l&#233;onore Project and the Dee/South Arturo Project.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT">
<A NAME="X60364EXV99W1_HTM_113">
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
	RED LAKE GOLD MINES, CANADA
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Red Lake Gold Mines, an Ontario partnership, was formed on April&nbsp;2, 2007 between Goldcorp
	Canada, as to a 28% interest, and Goldcorp Inc., as to a 72% interest, for the principal purpose of
	operating and developing the combined operations of the Red Lake Complex and the Campbell Complex,
	each located at or about the town of Red Lake, in the province of Ontario, and to carry out all
	activities in connection with or ancillary thereto. In 2009, the gold production from Red Lake
	Gold Mines amounted to 622,738 ounces of gold at a total cash cost of $288 per ounce.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Goldcorp indirectly acquired the Cochenour Deposit upon completion of the Gold Eagle
	Acquisition on September&nbsp;25, 2008. The Cochenour Deposit is located adjacent to properties owned
	by Red Lake Gold Mines. Goldcorp expects to contribute the properties constituting the Cochenour
	Deposit to Red Lake Gold Mines in 2010.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Dean Crick, M.Sc., P.Geo., Stephane Blais, P.Eng. and Anthony Stechishen, P.Geo. prepared a technical report in accordance with NI
	43-101 entitled &#147;The Red Lake Gold Mines Property - Red Lake Mining Division, Northern Ontario&#148; dated November 17, 2006 (the &#147;Red Lake Gold Mines Report&#148;). Dean Crick, Stephane Blais and Anthony Stechishen are each
	employees of the Corporation and are qualified persons under NI 43-101. The following description of the properties held by Red Lake Gold Mines has been
	summarized, in part, from the Red Lake Gold Mines Report and readers should consult the Red Lake
	Gold Mines Report to obtain further particulars regarding the properties held by the Red Lake Gold
	Mines. The Red Lake Gold Mines Report is available for review on the SEDAR website located at
<U>
<I>
	www.sedar.com
</I>
</U>
	under the Corporation&#146;s profile.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<B>
<I>
	Property Description and Location
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The properties held by Red Lake Gold Mines cover approximately 2,782 hectares located in the
	Red Lake Mining Division within the District of Kenora in northwestern Ontario. The Red Lake Gold
	Mines&#146; properties are located in the Canadian Shield, approximately 180 kilometres north of Dryden,
	Ontario. The Red Lake Complex consists of 89 patented claims covering
	1,254 hectares, the
	Campbell Complex consists of 77 patented mineral claims covering 1,084 hectares and the Cochenour deposit area covers
	512 hectares, and comprises 35 patented mineral claims, held in the name of Gold Eagle Mines Ltd., an Ontario
	corporation that is 100% owned by Goldcorp. The Red Lake Gold
	Mines&#146; properties have been legally surveyed for all of the patented claims.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Accessibility, Climate, Local Resources, Infrastructure and Physiography
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Red Lake Gold Mines&#146; properties and the Cochenour Deposit are located in the Municipality
	of Red Lake in northwestern Ontario, Canada. The Municipality of Red Lake is comprised of the
	towns of Madsen and McKenzie Island, Red Lake, Cochenour, Balmertown, Starratt Olsen and Flat Lake.
	The Red Lake area is accessible by Highway 105, which joins the Trans Canada Highway at Vermilion
	Bay, 175 kilometres south and 100 kilometres east of Kenora, Ontario. Commercial air service from
	Thunder Bay and Winnipeg to the community is available several times a day.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The climate in the Red Lake area is typical of a northern continental boreal climate with warm
	summers and cold winters. Mining operations are conducted year-round.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-21-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage37"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Municipality of Red Lake has a population of approximately 5,500. Other industries in the
	Municipality of Red Lake include logging and tourism. Local infrastructure is well developed in
	the Red Lake area, with all the amenities needed for operations by Red Lake Gold Mines available
	locally. Potable water is supplied by the Municipality. Process water is taken from Balmer Lake
	and Sandy Bay. Ontario Hydro supplies power. Each of the Red Lake and Campbell Complexes has 30
	megawatts of transformer capability but is limited to 26 megawatts by the incoming line. There are
	multiple transformers throughout the Red Lake and Campbell Complexes, which step voltage down to
	4,160, 2,300 and 575 volts.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Red Lake area has topography typical of the Canadian Shield with irregular
	hummocky hills and discontinuous ridges created by glaciofluvial material and till. These are
	separated by depressions and hollows occupied by lakes, ponds and muskeg. Elevations are subdued
	and rarely higher than 50&nbsp;metres. Much of the larger Red
	Lake region is undeveloped and is accessible only by air or boat. The natural vegetation is
	predominantly black spruce, fir, tamarack and pine. In the better drained elevated areas the
	vegetation changes to poplar, birch, willow, alder and mountain ash with a variety of shrubs.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Bedrock outcrops are scattered and consist of less than 5% of the surface area. Soil in the
	vicinity is characterized by a 30 to 50 centimetre layer of topsoil overlying compact sand with
	traces of clay, gravel, scattered cobbles and boulders. Low-lying areas contain silty-clay
	sediments that were deposited in glacial lakes.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	History
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The first recorded prospecting in the Red Lake district was carried out by the Northwestern
	Ontario Exploration Company in 1887, but gold was not discovered in the district until 1922. A
	brief summary of the Red Lake and Campbell Complexes follows.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<I>
	Red Lake Complex
</I>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Red Lake Complex was first staked during the Red Lake Gold Rush in 1926. In 1944, the
	property was re-staked and Dickenson Red Lake Mines Limited was incorporated. Production mining
	began in 1948 at a rate of 125 tons per day and increased to 500 tons per day in the 1970s, with
	grades varying between 0.45 and 0.61 ounces of gold per ton. In the early 1980s, the mill capacity
	was increased to 1,000 tons per day and long-hole stoping was introduced which resulted in a
	significant drop in production grade. Cut-and-fill mining was subsequently re-introduced and
	production was increased to about 1,000 tons per day by 1993/4 with the grade ranging from 0.25 and
	0.34 ounces of gold per ton. The average recovery rate at the time was 82%. An exploration
	diamond drilling program initiated in 1995 within the lower levels of the mine at the Red Lake
	Complex resulted in the discovery of a cluster of high grade gold veins between the 30 and 39
	levels of the mine (the &#147;High Grade Zone&#148;).
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Between June&nbsp;1996 and late 1999, operations were suspended due to a labour strike. Mine staff
	and outside contractors maintained essential services and supported the exploration program on the
	property. In September&nbsp;1998, the feasibility of mining the High Grade Zone Mineral Reserves
	through a combination of existing mine infrastructure, new development and a new processing
	facility purchased from Cameco Corporation was studied. An operating plan was developed to mine
	the High Grade Zone.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Mining from the High Grade Zone began in early 2000 and test milling began in July. By the
	end of 2000, full rated production was achieved with a small stockpile of several thousand tons of
	crushed ore remaining on surface. Since production restarted in 2000, the exploration to increase
	resources has focused on the High Grade Zone. See &#147;&#151; Exploration&#148;.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The #3 Shaft at Red Lake Gold Mine was developed from January&nbsp;2004 to January&nbsp;2007 to a depth
	of 6,314 feet. The muck handling system for the #3 Shaft was commissioned at the end of 2008. The
	mine ventilation was upgraded between 2008 and 2009. The first phase of the upgrade was completed in March
	2008 and increased the amount of air being supplied to the bottom section of the mine to 400,000
	cubic feet per minute. The second phase of the ventilation was completed in the second quarter of
	2009. Improvements to the mine dewatering system were completed in 2009.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-22-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage38"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Since the beginning of operations in 1948 until the end of 2009, 10.99&nbsp;million tons of ore
	have been processed at an average head grade of 0.75 ounces per ton to produce 7.81&nbsp;million ounces
	of gold. In 2009, 323,914 tons of ore at an average head grade of 1.283 ounces per ton were
	processed and 439,263 ounces of gold were poured.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<I>
	Campbell Complex
</I>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Campbell Complex claims were staked in 1926. Subsequently, there was a period of claim
	cancellations and restaking of the area. In 1944, George and Colin Campbell restaked the area. In
	this period, Campbell Red Lake Mines was incorporated and Dome Mines purchased an option that
	eventually resulted in Dome Mines acquiring a 57% ownership interest in the company.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 1946, after further exploration had been carried out, a four-compartment shaft with four
	levels was sunk to a depth of 182 metres. Mill construction began in 1948 and the mill went into
	operation the following year reaching a capacity of 300 tons per day soon after the beginning of
	operations. By 1953, the shaft was further deepened to 655 metres and soon after a deeper higher
	grade zone was discovered at the 14
<SUP STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: TEXT-TOP">
	th
</SUP>
	level. The next 30&nbsp;years of production at
	Campbell remained consistent.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A new phase of investment began following the merger between Campbell, Dome and Placer
	Development to form Placer Dome Inc. (&#147;Placer Dome&#148;). This led to the installation of an
	autoclave, replacing the roasting at the Campbell mill, development of a decline from levels 27 to
	30, a mill flotation circuit upgrade, construction of paste fill plant and the commissioning of the
	Reid Shaft in 1999, which enabled the discovery and development of the DC Zone.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Since the beginning of operations in 1949 until the end of 2009, 21.78&nbsp;million tons of ore
	have been processed at an average head grade of 0.59 ounces per ton to produce 11.92&nbsp;million ounces
	of gold. In 2009, 504,699 tons of ore at an average head grade of 0.38 ounces per ton were
	processed and 183,474 ounces of gold were poured.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Geological Setting
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<I>
	Regional Geology
</I>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Red Lake greenstone belt is situated in the western portion of the Uchi Subprovince, a
	typical Achaean granite-greenstone terrain containing eastward trending belts of volcanic and
	sedimentary rocks and syn-volcanic intrusives. The rocks consist of volcanic and sedimentary
	assemblages representing magmatic and erosional events occurring over a period of approximately 300
	million years.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Red Lake greenstone belt outcropping is defined by an east-northeast orientated bow tie
	shaped, anticline, roughly 40 kilometres long and 20 kilometres across. Two perpendicular axes of
	mirror symmetry trend east-northeast and southwest defining the bow tie and intersecting at the
	Dome Stock near Red Lake. The most prominent axis trends east-northeast defining a broad antiform
	with older rocks of the Balmer Assemblage occupying the hinge flanked by younger rocks of the
	Huston and Confederation assemblages on its northern and southern flanks. Between the oldest and
	youngest assemblages is a regional unconformity, overlain by the Huston conglomerate. At each end
	of the anticline, late-orogenic plutons stope up into the greenstone; the Killala-Baird batholith
	in the west, and the Walsh Lake pluton and Cat Island pluton in the east.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Balmer assemblage, predominantly tholeiitic and komatiitic mafic to ultramafic extrusive
	rocks, hosts the gold-bearing ore and constitutes over 50% of the Red Lake greenstone belt rocks.
	The sequence is disconformably overlain by a volcaniclastic/clastic sequence, the Bruce Channel
	assemblage prominent in the east and the Slate Bay assemblage in the southwest. The Trout Bay
	assemblage is characterized by predominantly mafic tholeiitic extrusive rocks. A laterally
	extensive polymict conglomerate belonging to the Huston assemblage marks an angular unconformity
	between Mesoarchean and Neoarchean strata and is overlain by dominantly calc-alkalic felsic
	volcanic rocks belonging to the Confederation assemblage.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Large-scale folding and steep fault systems dominate the eastern part of the Red Lake
	greenstone belt. Northeast trending synclines and anticlines occur northeast of McKenzie Island
	west of East Bay. On the eastern
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-23-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage39"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	side of East Bay, a major fold with a northwest trending fold axis occurs in Bateman and
	Balmer Townships. In the area surrounding Red Lake Gold Mines, horizons of ultramafics within the
	basalt-dominated stratigraphy created complex geometries through competency contrast during the
	mechanical interaction of folding. High strain corridors characterized by pervasive foliation and
	cleavage development along mafic, ultramafic contacts are clearly distinguishable features using
	surface mapping and geophysics.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Quartz-carbonate veining and alteration developed around mafic-ultramafic contacts,
	particularly fold hinges and in the damage zones of small and large displacement fault/shear zones.
	Continued shortening and foliation development caused rotation of conjugate shear zones towards
	parallelism with F2 fold axial surface orientations, producing strong deformation and strain
	partitioning. Further shortening resulted in strong near-vertical extension and locally the
	development of reverse faults.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Auriferous, siliceous, sulphidic alteration and quartz veining, overprinting earlier
	quartz-carbonate veins, began to develop at this stage, apparently after the bulk of strain and
	displacements on major fault systems. Minor strike slip movements on fault systems, reflecting at
	least local changes in the orientation of stress axes, contributed to the dilation and replacement,
	particularly in ultramafic/mafic defined fold hinge zones abutting fault system.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<I>
	Metamorphism
</I>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Owing to the volume of late tectonic granitic plutons, a complex history of metamorphic events
	exists which arises from episodes of burial, crustal thickening, thrusting, baking by felsic
	intrusions of all sizes and ages, and late hydrothermal alterations focussed along shear zones.
	Within the Red Lake greenstone belt the alteration is characterized by greenschist metamorphic
	mineral assemblages, but with amphibolite facies mineral assemblages in areas close to the major
	plutons.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<I>
	Local Geology
</I>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The gold bearing zones of the Red Lake and Campbell Complexes occur on the eastern flank of a
	D2, high strain corridor, known locally as the Cochenour-Gullrock Lake deformation zone or Red Lake
	Mines trend. These units are subparallel to a regional foliation that strikes from 100&#176; to 120&#176;
	azimuth, dipping southwest from 65&#176; to 80&#176;.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At broad scales, the Red Lake Gold Mines trend appears to be hosted by a steeply plunging
	reclined F2 fold system with south-southwest-dipping axial surface, outlined by the Bruce Channel
	contact to the north, south and east, and cored by the Balmer mafic-ultramafic assemblage. This
	fold system has undergone significant modification by a system of steeply-to-moderately southwest
	dipping fault zones which are interpreted to have developed during D2 deformation, a
	northeast-southwest oriented shortening.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The D2 event, comprised of progressive northeast-southwest shortening, resulted in the
	dismemberment of the F2 folds along axial planar shear structures, displacing the steeply plunging
	parasitic mafic/ultramafic fold hinges into discrete litho-structural domains.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<I>
	Site Geology
</I>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Red Lake Gold Mines&#146; properties are underlain mainly by tholeiitic basalt and locally by
	komatiitic basalt of the Balmer assemblage. The mine sequence is completed by peridotitic
	komatiite, rhyolite and associated mafic intrusions of the Balmer assemblage. The steeply plunging
	south-southwest folded package is unconformably overlain by felsic volcaniclastics, clastic and
	chemical sedimentary rocks of the Bruce Channel assemblage defining an enveloping
	syncline-anticline couplet based on younging directions, with the synform hinge located on the
	northside of the Campbell Complex, east of the HG Young shaft underneath Balmer Lake and the
	anticlinal hinge in the south central portion of the former partywall boundary and east at the Red
	Lake Complex. The prominent fabric at the site is the S2 cleavage, trending northwest-southeast,
	axial planar of the F2 folding, plunging steeply to the south-southwest.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The major mineralized zones, although hosted in basalt, are associated with a central
	ultramafic unit, which is a highly carbonatized and altered unit, believed to be either volcanic or
	plutonic in origin.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-24-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage40"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Hydrothermal alteration at the Red Lake Gold Mines&#146; properties can be subdivided into three
	main phases: (1)&nbsp;an early alteration subdivided into (a)&nbsp;carbonatization and pervasive biotite
	(potassic)&nbsp;alteration and (b)&nbsp;early silicification and aluminosilicate-bearing alteration; (2)
	main-stage vein phase of barren dolomite to ankerite, cockade breccias and sheeted veinlet zones
	with chloritic alteration; and (3)&nbsp;a mineralization phase with quartz-sericite &#043;/- cordierite
	alteration and a late episode of veinlet controlled biotite &#043;/- tourmaline alteration.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The mineralized system at the Red Lake Gold Mines&#146; properties is a wedge-shaped zone above
	roughly 27 level which widens upwards and is constrained by bounding fault structures on the
	northeast and southwest flanks. This wedge is defined by steeply south-dipping and south to
	south-southwestern plunging litho-structural packages of ultramafic and rhyolitic bodies, enveloped
	mainly by metabasalts. These bodies outline dismembered folds which also plunge steeply to the
	south to south-southwestern. Fold hinges are preserved between a series of steeply south-dipping
	and north-west to west-northwest-striking fault zones separating the detached folds, these major
	curviplanar fault/shear zones developed in fold limb positions and are approximately axial plane
	parallel.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Exploration
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Despite a prolific mining history since 1949, little exploration and development activity has
	been conducted in proximity to the former boundary between the Red Lake and Campbell Complexes
	which appears to transect the centroid of the orebody. Recently developed inter-mine connections
	provide operational flexibility and staging platforms for exploration of the internal property
	boundary targets. Deep exploration depends upon critical development away from the orebody for
	quality evaluation of highly sought after high grade vein structures to depth.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The current high priority exploration targets include the High Grade Zone and associated
	footwall sulphides, the Party Wall Zone, the Deep Campbell Zone, the upper Red Lake sulphides, and
	surface, bulk mining opportunities. The exploration targets in the High Grade Zone are
	characterized by relatively smaller high grade vein structures and laterally extensive footwall,
	lower grade, sulphide ore structures.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A primary focus of exploration at Red Lake Gold Mines in 2009 was the early completion of the
	4199 exploration drift, enabling drilling of the deep High Grade Zone for the first time in four
	years. Approximately 50,000 feet of diamond drilling has been completed within the resource shape
	from this platform, with results indicating the continuation of the High Grade Zone at depth. In
	2010, Red Lake Gold Mines expects to target new gold reserves in the zone between the 49 and 52
	levels and new resources below the 52 level. The 4199 exploration drift is expected to provide the
	primary exploration platform for exploration of the deep High Grade Zone on an ongoing basis. It
	will be developed progressively in order to maintain favourable drilling geometry into the area.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The &#147;Party Wall&#148; at Red Lake Gold Mines comprises the former boundary area between the Red
	Lake and Campbell Complexes that had been previously unexplored. Assays over the last two years
	have demonstrated a high grade gold resource. Mining operations in the shallower portions of the
	Party Wall have drifted toward the gold zone, with in-fill drilling confirming the resource model.
	Deep drilling of the Party Wall area to the 36 level has resulted in some high grade intercepts, and is expected to be the focus of further exploration drilling during 2010.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Up-plunge and to the east of the High Grade Zone lies an underexplored area called the Far
	East Zone. Assay results in 2009 indicate an ore grade gold zone at the 16 level that is expected
	to continue to down dip. Development and drilling are planned for 2010 to extend the Far East Zone
	down dip.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Mineralization
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In general, there are three types of mineralization zones encountered at the Red Lake Gold
	Mines&#146; properties, namely vein type ore, disseminated sulphide ore and replacement ore. Structures
	at the site exhibit three trends: conformable northwest, north-south and east-west. The
	conformable structures are most common and are sub-parallel to the foliation. The vein systems
	follow these structures. Complex vein arrays are those which also include the north-south and
	east-west components. The arrays are most common near high angle mafic-ultramafic contacts. The
	High Grade Zone occurs in such an environment where enhanced dilatency developed and was
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-25-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage41"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	sustained over a long period of time. Its geometry will combine both conformable and complex
	vein arrays overprinted by replacement mineralization.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The ore veins are normally structurally controlled; averaging 1.5 to 1.8 metres in width and
	extending over strike lengths ranging from 30 to 300 metres. Sulphide replacement zones vary from
	3 to 12 metres in width and extend over a strike length of 120 to 180 metres. Gold mineralization
	zones in the Balmer assemblage of the Red Lake Gold Mines trend can be broadly subdivided into two
	morphological groups: planar to curviplanar zones and plunging zones.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Drilling
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Diamond drilling has been carried out at the Red Lake Gold Mines&#146; properties since the
	beginning of operations. Over the years, various lithological descriptions have been developed for
	each of the complexes and these have continued to develop and change. Since the merger of the
	Campbell and Red Lake Complexes, the Corporation has developed a new lithological coding system
	that incorporates both the old systems.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2009, 513,762 feet of definition, delineation and exploration diamond drilling was
	conducted by Red Lake Gold Mines.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<I>
	Red Lake Complex
</I>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Red Lake drill hole database consists of a total of about 24,000 diamond drill holes
	drilled from underground and surface. The channel sample database is comprised of over 146,000
	channel cuts.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Exploration drill core is transported to the core facility in sealed boxes. Upon arrival it
	is marked up by a geologist and then geologically logged while wet. All drill core is logged using
	computer codes for the various rock types, mineralization, alteration characteristics and
	structural/geotechnical data. The shear structures containing the various mineralized zones are
	logged in detail to establish the zone width and sampling interval. Sections of core with visible
	mineralization are transferred into secured storage to ensure that no core is lost or replaced,
	prior to shipping for assay.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<I>
	Campbell Complex
</I>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Campbell drill hole database consists of a total of about 30,000 diamond drill holes,
	drilled from underground and surface. The channel sample database is comprised of over 88,000
	channel cuts. Drill core sample security is maintained throughout the year with geological
	supervision of transport of the core from the underground/surface drill site, through to the
	logging facility and to the in-house assay laboratory.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;All drill hole collars are surveyed by mine surveyors, and down hole surveys are taken either
	with a Maxibore survey instrument at 5 foot intervals or an acid test/Tropari every 100 feet. Most
	of the drill holes greater than 1,000 feet are surveyed using the Gyro or Maxibore methods. All
	stopes will have channel sampling taken every 8 to 15 feet to fill in the gaps from diamond drill
	intercepts. More recently, Reflex and Ranger electronic compass single-shot survey tests are
	conducted every 100 to 150 feet down the hole, especially for drill holes exceeding 500 feet in
	length.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Half of the core is kept for the majority of exploration and all grassroots exploration drill
	programs. All holes are logged for lithology, alteration, structure and veining/mineralization and
	RQD where applicable.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Sampling and Analysis
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Rigorous sampling is done during production for grade control and correlation with Mineral
	Reserves estimates and production at the Red Lake Gold Mines. At Red Lake, muck and chip sampling
	is performed on a blast by blast basis by the production geology team, while muck sampling at
	Campbell is done by the miner during the mucking process. Muck samples are used to provide a
	general guide and back-up information for day-to-day operations, while test holes are required to
	ascertain that no mineralization is missed in the walls of the stope.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-26-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage42"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The reconciled grade on a stope-by-stope basis is variable between reserves and actual
	production, but shows reasonable correlation over a longer period of time through averaging of
	several cut and fill lifts or multiple long-hole blocks in the same ore lens.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Sample Preparation, Analyses and Security
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Drilling, sampling, analysis, data stewardship, orebody modeling and mine planning are carried
	out in accordance with NI 43-101 industry standards. Regular internal auditing of the Mineral
	Reserve and Mineral Resource estimation processes and procedures are conducted. The sampling and
	analytical methods are believed to be appropriate for the style and type of mineralization. Mine
	geological staff has verified all databases used to generate the geological models and Mineral
	Resource estimates.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As a general rule, exploration drilling, especially in new areas of potential or Inferred
	Mineral Resources, is sampled by taking half core using a diamond saw. Geologists mark the core
	saw cut using a lumber crayon. The remaining half core is saved for future reference, part of
	which may be used for metallurgical testing. The remaining portion of the core is stored on site.
	However, delineation and definition drill holes are sent as whole core for assaying.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Sample lengths are typically in the one to three foot range, and usually shorter in the higher
	grade sections. Low-grade rock and waste are typically sampled over two to three foot lengths,
	averaging 2.20 feet, while very high grade sections are sampled over 0.5 to 2.0 foot intervals with
	an average of 1.60 feet. The sampling strategy is conducted diligently striking a balance between
	approaching a consistent sampling interval for improved population statistics while maintaining
	respect for geologic boundaries.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Standard fire assay procedures with a gravimetric or AA finish (depending on the anticipated
	grade of the sample) are carried out on all assays of production samples. Process, most
	definition, muck and chip data assays are generated using the in-house assay laboratory. Quality
	assurance/quality control practices/procedures are monitored on a regular basis to ensure low assay
	contamination and consistent data accuracy. Overflow sampling and the majority of exploration and
	surface channel, blast hole and diamond drill hole assays are analyzed at the SGS Lab in Red Lake
	or the ALS Chemex Lab in Vancouver, British Columbia.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Metallic screen assay methods are done at SGS in Red Lake for samples with visible gold or for
	samples where fire assay results reported more than 20 ounces of gold per ton. However, there
	appears to be no significant difference in results between metallic screen and regular assay
	methods.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Exploration assay checks (duplicates and re-runs) are conducted regularly on the pulps and
	rejects and at the discretion of the geologist submitting the samples where assays did not match
	physical observations of mineralization.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;All samples have barcode tags and are scanned into the computer at sample receiving. Upload
	of assays is conducted by electronic transfer of certified assay data. Hard copy, official assay
	certificates are archived.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-27-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>

</H5>
<P>

</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">

	December&nbsp;31, 2009:
</DIV>

	per tonne), with a minimum cut-off grade of 0.12 ounces per tonne (4.1 grams per tonne)
	depending on the zone and mining method. Resource models are diluted to minimum horizontal
	widths of 7 to 10 feet (2.12 to 3.1 metres) at a zero grade.
</TD>

<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_19"></A>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<TABLE STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT" CELLSPACING="0" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<!-- BEGIN TABLE HEAD -->
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD WIDTH="64%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>

<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)

<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	The Mineral Resources for Red Lake Gold Mines set out in the table above have been
	estimated by Chris Osiowy, P.Geo., Red Lake Gold Mines, who is a qualified person under NI
	43-101. The Mineral Resources are classified as measured, indicated and inferred, and are
	based on the CIM Standards.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>

	Based on a gold price of $925 per ounce and an exchange rate of 1.1.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(3)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	The average, diluted, cut-off grade for Mineral Resources is 0.22 ounces per tonne (7.5 grams
	per tonne), with a minimum cut-off grade of 0.12 ounces per tonne (4.1 grams per tonne)
	depending on the zone and mining method. The in situ block model has been diluted to minimum
	horizontal widths of 4 to 6 feet (1.22 to 1.83 metres).
</TD>
</TR>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-28-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage44"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Mineral Processing and Metallurgical Testing
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<I>
	Red Lake Complex
</I>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The original Red Lake mill was built in 1948 and was dismantled in early 2000. Construction
	of a new mill took place during 2000. The new process facilities consist of three separate plants:
	the crushing plant, the processing plant and the paste fill plant. Commissioning of the crushing
	plant began in February&nbsp;2000, the processing plant&#146;s commissioning phase commenced in early July
	2000 with the first gold bar being poured on August&nbsp;1, 2000 and commissioning of the paste fill
	plant began in August&nbsp;2000. Commercial production began on January&nbsp;1, 2001. The mill throughput
	capacity is 1,250 tonnes per day.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Unit operations in the processing plant include grinding, gravity concentrating, cyanidation,
	carbon-in-pulp, carbon elution and reactivation, electrowinning, bullion smelting/refining, cyanide
	destruction, flotation and concentrate handling. Three types of gold occur in the Red Lake Gold
	Mines ore requiring these various unit operations.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<I>
	Campbell Complex
</I>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Campbell mill was designed in 1949 to treat free milling and refractory gold ore at a rate
	of 360 tonnes per day. The throughput has been gradually increased over the years to the current
	1,850 tonnes per day.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Conventional crushing and grinding is followed by gravity concentration to recover free
	milling gold. Refractory gold, finely disseminated in the arsenopyrite and pyrite matrix, is
	recovered by flotation followed by pressure oxidation, neutralization and CIL.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Mining Operations
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Red Lake Complex is serviced by three shafts. The Campbell Complex is serviced by two
	shafts and an internal decline. Production is approximately 750 tonnes per day from the
	Red Lake Complex, and 1,850 tonnes per day from the Campbell Complex.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Mining is carried out in the Red Lake Complex using predominantly underhand and overhand cut
	and fill techniques allowing maximum ore extraction and minimal dilution. Pillar recovery and
	longhole mining methods are also be utilized as required. The primary mining method at the
	Campbell Complex is longhole followed by conventional overhand cut-and-fill and approximately 5%
	development ore. The longhole mining includes both longhole panel mining and longhole sill
	recovery.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Based on the year-end 2009 Mineral Reserves, production is
	expected to continue for approximately 8 to
	11&nbsp;years.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Environmental Considerations and Permitting
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Red Lake Gold Mines operates under the Corporation&#146;s environmental and sustainability policy
	which commits the operation to a defined standard of environmental stewardship. Red Lake Gold
	Mines has developed a series of management programs for environmental activities, tailings
	management and occupational health and safety that enable the Corporation to reach its commitments.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;All requisite material permits have been obtained for the mining and continued development of
	the site and are in good standing. Federal and provincial environmental legislation is recognized
	through policies and practices on the site that ensure compliance. The most comprehensive on-site
	environmental program covers the tailings effluent monitoring.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Three closure plans exist for the operations: Cochenour Complex, Campbell Complex, Red Lake
	and Balmer Complexes combined. These documents have been created and/or updated by independent consultants Lorax Environmental Inc./BGC Engineering and BZ Environmental on behalf of Goldcorp or predecessor companies. The closure plans reviewed three closure scenarios: temporary
	suspension, inactivity and final closure.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Cochenour and Red Lake
	closure plans were
	developed and updated by Lorax Environmental Inc. and were
	resubmitted in June 2009 for assessment. These closure plans remain in the Ontario government review process.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The original closure plan for Campbell was prepared by BZ Environmental for Placer Dome, submitted in April
	2004, and accepted in 2006. A new updated version of this document was resubmitted in June 2009.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Currently a new consolidated closure plan including Campbell, Red
	Lake and Balmer Complexes is under development and will be submitted
	in 2010. Lorax Environmental Inc./BGC Engineering are completing
	this assessment and the plan will address all identified short and
	long term issues for the Red Lake Gold Mine facilities in
	Balmertown.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At the Campbell Complex, a nine hectare wetland has been constructed to reduce the
	concentrations of copper, ammonia and low levels of other contaminants occurring in the discharge
	from waste rock and tailings pond facilities. The metals are removed through naturally-occurring
	water treatment as the discharge water moves through the wetlands during the ice-free season. This
	process made the Campbell Complex one of the first gold mines in Ontario to use natural, microbial
	forces to produce a non-toxic discharge. In 2009, Red Lake Gold Mines received approval from the
	Ontario Ministry of the Environment to construct a similar wetland treatment facility at the Red
	Lake Complex. To date, 4.5 hectares of wetland have been developed at the Red Lake Complex, and
	Red Lake Gold Mines expects to complete an additional 3.5 hectares in 2010.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-29-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage45"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2009, Red Lake Gold Mines completed tailings management area upgrades at the Campbell
	Complex tailings facilities, including a dam raise. Red Lake Gold Mines expects to complete
	similar activities at the Red Lake Complex tailings facilities in 2010 to address ongoing water
	balance and tailings management requirements.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Environmental liabilities are limited to those that would be expected to be associated with
	two operating gold mines and two closed gold mines where production is from underground sources,
	including roads, site infrastructure, and waste and tailings disposal facilities. See &#147;Risk Factors&#148;.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Gold
	Eagle Acquisition &#151; Cochenour Deposit
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On September&nbsp;25, 2008, Goldcorp completed the Gold Eagle Acquisition, acquiring the Cochenour
	Deposit and securing control of eight kilometres of strike length along the prolific Red Lake Mines
	trend in Ontario. The property is located immediately south of the historic past producing
	McKenzie Red Lake Mine (651,156 ounces produced), includes the past producing Gold Eagle Mine
	(40,000 ounces produced), and covers the southerly, down-plunge extension of the past producing
	Cochenour-Willans Mine (1,240,000 ounces produced). These past producers are all located on
	properties owned by Goldcorp.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The exploration of the Cochenour Deposit was initiated by Gold Eagle with the objective to
	test the down-plunge extension of the Cochenour-Willans orebody onto the property. The third hole
	into the program during February&nbsp;2004, known as the &#147;discovery&#148; hole, hit the Cochenour Deposit and
	additional drilling continued to expand upon the potential of the discovery. From 2004 to the end
	of 2007, a total of 165 holes and wedges were completed by Gold Eagle for a total of 103,078 metres
	of drilling. The drilling to the end of 2007 intersected the Cochenour Deposit from 750 to 2,350
	metres below surface along a strike length of approximately 1,000 metres. In 2008, the combined
	drilling before and after the Gold Eagle Acquisition added another 66 holes and wedges totalling
	58,838 metres. The Cochenour Deposit is open at depth and along strike to the south. The
	Cochenour Deposit is also open to the north along strike onto Goldcorp&#146;s Cochenour-Willans
	property.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2009, a surface diamond drill program was initiated to explore the &#147;GAP&#148; zone, an
	under-explored area located between the bottom of the Cochenour-Willans orebody and the top of the
	Cochenour Deposit. To date, the drilling program has identified strong gold intercepts in the GAP
	zone. The geologic setting of the Cochenour-Willans orebody and the Cochenour Deposit are similar,
	with the exception that so-called &#147;black-line faults&#148; that cut the orebodies into smaller blocks at
	Cochenour-Willans were not observed in the Cochenour Deposit drilling. This would suggest the
	Cochenour Deposit mineralization is more intact down-plunge of the Cochenour-Willans orebody. The
	significant mineralization occurs in areas of intense carbonate alteration and silica flooding that
	locally contains disseminated pyrite, arsenopyrite, chalcopyrite and vestiges of older
	quartz-carbonate veins. Visible gold is a common occurrence.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Development of this discovery zone will be integrated with the Corporation&#146;s adjoining Red
	Lake Gold Mines assets as a single, comprehensive project, sharing mine infrastructure, ore
	processing facilities and human talent with Red Lake Gold Mines, thus minimizing capital and
	operating costs. During the third quarter of 2009, Goldcorp completed an engineering trade-off
	study related to the Cochenour Deposit. The study indicated that the best alternative for
	exploiting the Cochenour Deposit is to enlarge and upgrade the existing Cochenour shaft and
	construct a 5 kilometre underground tram from the 5400 foot level of the Campbell Complex
	connecting the Cochenour Deposit to the Red Lake Gold Mines. This will enable the Cochenour
	Deposit ore to be hauled directly to the Red Lake Gold Mines and be processed at the existing mill
	facility. Preparatory work for the haulage drift project has commenced. The Cochenour mine is
	dewatered to the 1300 foot level and dewatering is anticipated to be completed during the first
	quarter of 2010. Following dewatering, Goldcorp expects to initiate a delineation drilling program
	from the 2050 foot level of the Cochenour Mine targeting the GAP zone.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT">
<A NAME="X60364EXV99W1_HTM_114">
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 24PT">
<B>
	MEXICO
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Corporation&#146;s properties in Mexico include the Los Filos Mine, the El Sauzal Mine, the San
	Dimas Mines, the Pe&#241;asquito Project, the Noche Buena Project and the Camino Rojo Project. During
	2007, construction and commissioning of the Los Filos project was completed and Los Filos achieved
	commercial production, as defined by Canadian generally accepted accounting principles, as of
	January&nbsp;1, 2008.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Corporate profits in Mexico are taxed only by the Federal Government. Through 2008, there
	were two federal taxes in Mexico that applied to Goldcorp&#146;s operations in Mexico; a Flat Rate
	Business Tax (&#147;FRBT&#148;) and a corporate income tax. Mexican corporate income tax is calculated based
	on gross revenue less deductions for all
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-30-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage46"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	refining and smelting charges, direct operating costs, all head office general and
	administrative costs, and depreciation deductions. During 2008 and 2009, the corporate income tax
	rate in Mexico was 28%, and it will be 30% from 2010 to 2012, 29% during 2013 and 28% during 2014.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The FRBT is a minimum tax that applies in addition to the corporate income tax. The tax is
	applicable to the taxpayer&#146;s net income from the (i)&nbsp;sale of goods; (ii)&nbsp;performance of independent
	services; and (iii)&nbsp;lease of goods at the rate of 16.5% during 2008, 17% during 2009 and 17.5%
	during 2010. The base to which the FRBT is applied is determined by deducting from gross income
	certain items, such as expenses associated with purchasing goods, rendering independent services,
	and leasing goods, or expenses incurred in connection with the administration of such activities.
	Some expenses that are deductible in determining taxable income for income tax purposes, such as
	salaries, interests in some cases and royalties with foreign related parties are not deductible in
	determining the FRBT. However, certain tax credits are available to offset the FRBT, including
	income tax paid during the same fiscal year; a credit on certain salary-related expenses and social
	security contributions paid by an employer; a credit on losses, a credit on fixed assets; and
	monthly FRBT payments. The FRBT follows a cash flow system, which could distort the crediting of
	income tax against the FRBT. Finally, special rules apply to certain taxpayers, such as corporate
	groups like Goldcorp that file consolidated tax returns.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT">
<A NAME="X60364EXV99W1_HTM_115">
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
	LOS FILOS MINE, MEXICO
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Los Filos Mine consists of two open pit mines (Los Filos and Bermejal) with common process
	and ancillary facilities, which is wholly-owned by Desarrollos Mineros San Luis, S.A. de C.V., a
	Mexican company indirectly wholly-owned by the Corporation; and an underground mine and milling
	facility owned by Compa&#241;&#237;a Minera Nukay, S.A. de C.V, also a Mexican company indirectly
	wholly-owned by the Corporation. All of these installations are located in the Nukay mining
	district of central Guerrero State, Mexico. More recently, exploration activities have outlined
	new mineralized bodies in the vicinity of the actual operations, which are described below.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The first gold pour at Los Filos took place in June&nbsp;2007 and commercial production was
	achieved on January&nbsp;1, 2008. Production during 2009 at Los Filos was 224,183 ounces of gold at a
	cash cost of $446 per ounce; the supplementary underground operation produced 15,141 ounces of gold
	during 2009 at a cash cost of $816 per ounce. The combined production at Los Filos, open pit and
	underground (which was previously known as the Nukay mine), was 239,323 ounces of gold at a cash
	cost of $469 per ounce.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In August&nbsp;2009, the processing plant in Nukay was closed. Since that date, economical ore has
	been accumulated to be processed during 2010 at the crushing agglomeration plant (the &#147;CAP&#148;)
	currently under refurbishment.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Construction of a buttress along the west edge was completed in November&nbsp;2009 to further
	secure heap leach pad stability. Monitoring of the heap leach pad is continuing and the monitoring
	data indicate that the pad is currently stable after the 2008 movements.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Completion was attained during 2009 on engineering design of modifications to the CAP;
	construction of the modifications is under way and it is expected to be completed by April&nbsp;2010.
	The CAP is designed to process the mineral from the underground operations at a rate of 800 tonnes
	per day. With the addition of the high grade ore of the open pit operation, the total daily
	tonnage processing is 11,000 tonnes.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Los Filos Mine is located in the Nukay mining district of
	central Guerrero State in southern Mexico, approximately 230 kilometres
	south of Mexico City. Both the mine and the adjacent Nukay mining
	operations lie within the southern part of the Morelos National Mineral
	Reserve (Morelos Sur) which covers a total of 47,600 hectares and was formally controlled by the Consejo Recursos Minerales, an agency
	of the government of Mexico. The Los Filos Mine consists of 20 different concessions totalling 4,962 hectares within the municipality of Eduardo Neri, Guerrero, Mexico.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;P. John Barton, B.Sc.(Eng.), ARSM, MAusIMM, Consultant to Snowden Mining Industry Consultants Inc., Andrew F. Ross, M.Sc., P.Geo. at Snowden Mining Industry Consultants Inc., Michael G. Hester, FAusIMM, B.Sc., M.S., at Independent
	Mining Consultants, Inc., Daniel W. Kappes, P.Eng., B.Sc., M.Sc., President
	of Kappes Cassiday &#038; Associates, and John F. Lupo, Ph.D., P.E., formerly at URS Australia Pty Ltd.,
	prepared a
	technical report in accordance with NI 43-101 entitled &#147;Technical Report NI 43-101F1 Los Filos
	Project, Mexico&#148; dated March&nbsp;31, 2006 (the &#147;Los Filos Report&#148;).
	P. John Barton, Andrew F. Ross, Michael G. Hester, Daniel W. Kappes and John F. Lupo are each qualified persons
	under NI 43-101. The following description of the Los Filos Mine has been summarized, in
	part, from the Los Filos Report and readers should consult the Los Filos Report to obtain further
	particulars regarding the Los Filos Mine. The Los Filos Report is available for review on the
	SEDAR website located at
<U>
<I>
	www.sedar.com
</I>
</U>
	under the Corporation&#146;s profile.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Property Description and Location
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Los Filos Mine is located in the Nukay mining district of central Guerrero State in
	southern Mexico, approximately 230 kilometres south of Mexico City. Both the mine and the adjacent
	Nukay mining operations lie
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-31-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage47"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	within the southern part of the Morelos National Mineral Reserve (Morelos Sur) which covers a
	total of 47,600 hectares and was formally controlled by the Consejo Recursos Minerales, an agency
	of the government of Mexico. The Los Filos Mine consists of 20 different exploitation and
	exploration application concessions totalling 4,962 hectares within the municipality of Eduardo
	Neri, Guerrero, Mexico.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As per Mexican requirements for grant of tenure, the concessions comprising the Los Filos Mine
	have been surveyed on the ground by a licensed surveyor. All appropriate payments have been made to
	the relevant authorities, and the licences are in good standing. Goldcorp has secured a total of
	3,920 hectares to cover surface rights required for the Los Filos operations including both pits,
	process and ancillary facilities areas, roads, services and a buffer area securing future growth
	and potential exploration targets. Surface rights have been secured by either acquisition of
	private and public land or by entering into temporary occupation agreements with surrounding
	communities.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;There are no royalties payable to any entity. Current Mexican legislation does not require
	government royalty payments. Goldcorp also holds the appropriate permits under local, State and
	Federal laws to allow mining operations.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Accessibility, Climate, Local Resources, Infrastructure and Physiography
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Los Filos Mine is located in the Sierra Madre del Sur physiographic province of southern
	Mexico. The property is accessible from Highway 95, a major, paved route between Mexico City and
	Acapulco. At the village of Mezcala on Highway 95, a former 8.5 kilometre dirt road leading to Los
	Filos and Bermejal areas was broadened and paved as part of the Los Filos Mine development and is
	fully operational. Driving time from Mexico City is approximately three hours.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Los Filos Mine is located near established power and road infrastructure at Mezcala and
	near centers of supply for materials and workers at Chilpancingo, Iguala and Cuernavaca.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Although topographic variations result in different climate types at the project, a very hot,
	semi-dry climate is the predominate climate at the site. The average annual temperature ranges
	between 22 degrees Celsius to a low of 18 degrees Celsius. The average annual precipitation is 590
	millimetres. The months with the most rainfall are June through August. Very little precipitation
	(less than 5% of the average annual rainfall) occurs between November and April. However, the
	project area can be affected by tropical storms and hurricanes which can result in short term high
	precipitation events. Mining operations are conducted year-round.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The area is characterized by large limestone mountains divided by wide valleys. The slopes of
	the hills vary from very flat to strong slopes. The maximum elevation in the project area, 1,820
	metres above mean sea level is the summit of Bermejal hill. The valley of Carrizalillo lies at an
	altitude of 1,000 to 1,100 metres above mean sea level. A total of 255 plant species were
	identified in the vicinity of the project area. Three of such plant species are protected;
	however, these protected species are all located outside of the proposed disturbance areas and will
	not be impacted by the project.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Power is supplied through the local utility service, Comision Federal de Electricidad, from a
	main feeder in Mezcala to a sub-station at Los Filos. The 25 MVA substation is designed to allow
	for potential project expansion, through provision of an additional 12.5 MVA capacity. An
	emergency power plant was constructed during 2008 to provide back-up power for the leach pumps and
	gold recovery plant.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Process and potable water for the project is sourced from a large well and filtration gallery
	located 1.5 kilometres west of Mezcala. The gallery has access to the Rio Balsas, which is a large
	perennial river. Water rights were granted in 2006 by the appropriate Mexican authorities.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Site communications include satellite service, using voice over internet protocols (VoIP for
	telephones) and Internet protocols (for regular computer business). Pit operations use two-way
	radio communications.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-32-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
