	of development as the El Morro Project.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Nature and Extent of Title
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In Chile, mining concessions are granted by the courts where the holder has full ownership
	rights and is entitled to obtain the rights of way for exploration and exploitation. In addition,
	the concession holder has the right to defend ownership of the concession against state and third
	parties. A concession is obtained by a claims filing and includes all minerals that may exist
	within its area.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The El Morro Project comprises 201 mining exploration concessions and 219 mining development
	concessions covering a total surface of 70,145 hectares. Concession owners do not necessarily have
	surface rights to the land; however, they do have the right to explore or exploit the concession.
	Mining rights are dominant to surface rights and the Mining Code grants liberal rights to use the
	surface subject to the payment of reasonable compensation to the surface rights owner.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-59-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage75"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;There are sufficient surface rights held in the project area to support the mining operations,
	including access and powerline easements. Surface lands are owned by the Los Huasco Altinos
	Farming Community. Access to the El Morro Project and the right to use the surface lands are
	provided via a legal right-of-way granted to the project operator. The easement over the Santa
	Julia 1&#150;3 tenements was granted October&nbsp;30, 2006 for a 30&nbsp;year period, and covers approximately
	10,190 hectares; this area is where the pit and minesite facilities will be located. An annual
	consideration is payable to the Los Huasco Altinos Farming Community for the right-of-way. A
	second right-of-way was enacted April&nbsp;7, 2006 with the owner of the Estancia Jarillla (San
	Bartolom&#233;) to cover the routes of the projected access road, concentrate and water pipelines, power
	line, and the location of the copper concentrate filter plant, from Highway 5 to the project site.
	A preliminary agreement was reached on August&nbsp;6, 2007 with the Communidad Agricola de Totorai,
	which owns the ground on which the desalination plant is proposed to be built, and part of the
	power and water pipeline route from the desalination plant to Highway 5. A final agreement is
	still to be negotiated.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In Chile, water is considered to be a public domain resource. Private persons may obtain
	rights to use public water, and such right shall be expressed as the right to use a specified
	volume per unit of time. Groundwater encountered in underground mining operations belongs to the
	mining property owner. There is no available water in the project vicinity. The 2008 feasibility
	study has assumed that all water for construction and operations will come from a reverse-osmosis
	desalination plant.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;All titles to the mining properties of El Morro Project are in good standing and duly
	protected with the payment of the corresponding mining patents defined under Chilean law. A second
	layer of mining rights has been established over existing rights to enhance protection and the
	corresponding area is being monitored on a permanent basis to prevent collision with third party
	rights.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Royalties
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Purchase options between Minera Metallica Limitada and Rene Martin Jure (legal mining
	companies S.L.M. Cantarito and Tronquito) were fully exercised on December&nbsp;28, 2001 at a total
	price of $1.5&nbsp;million. The concessions covered by the Agreement with S.L.M. Cantarito and S.L.M.
	Tronquito are subject to a 2% net smelter return (&#147;NSR&#148;) royalty.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On July&nbsp;15, 2003 a purchase option agreement between Minera Metallica Ltda. and BHP Billiton
	plc (&#147;BHP&#148;) for mining exploitation claims totaling 1,849 hectares was exercised for a total
	purchase price of $1.69&nbsp;million. Subsequent to this purchase, on December&nbsp;15, 2004, Noranda Chile
	Ltda (&#147;Noranda&#148;) acquired a 2% NSR royalty from BHP for a total purchase price of $2&nbsp;million. On
	this same date, Noranda sold 30% of this royalty to Metallica Resources Inc. (&#147;Metallica&#148;).
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Santa Julia 1 and 3 claims, which were purchased by Noranda on October&nbsp;20, 2000, have a
	one-time production bonus of $133,333 payable to each of the three former partners in the tenements
	two years after production from the property commences.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Environmental Liabilities
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Existing environmental liabilities are limited to those associated with an advanced
	exploration-stage property, and would involve removal of the exploration camp and infrastructure
	associated with the exploration decline, as well as rehabilitation of roads, drill pads and the
	exploration decline area.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-60-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage76"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The level of assessment required for a project can be either an Environmental Impact
	Assessment (&#147;EIA&#148;) or an Environmental Impact Declaration (&#147;DIA&#148;). A DIA for the El Morro Project
	was filed on October&nbsp;5, 2001. The scope of the permit comprised advanced stage exploration and
	evaluation work, including the use of resource delineation and infill drilling. A favourable
	Environmental Qualification Resolution (i.e. environmental permit) was rendered on December&nbsp;28,
	2001. In November&nbsp;2005, another DIA was submitted by Falconbridge Chile Limitada to develop an
	underground decline for the collection of geotechnical data and to extract bulk metallurgical
	samples. A favorable Environmental Qualification Resolution was rendered in December&nbsp;2006. An EIA
	was prepared by Xstrata for the Project in 2008. The EIA has been reviewed by the government and
	the public. El Morro responded to a first set of observations and is in the process of responding
	to a second set of observations. On February&nbsp;26, 2010, due to the change in project ownership,
	a request for a six month extension was submitted by Goldcorp and granted by the Chilean authorities.
	All information regarding the EIA is available in Spanish on the
	Comision Nacional del Medio Ambiente website at
<U>
	www.e-seia.cl
</U>
	.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Total closure costs were estimated in the $40 to $50&nbsp;million range prior to taking the salvage
	value of the assets into account. Net closure costs were estimated to be around $26.3&nbsp;million.
	Chile currently does not require reclamation and closure bonding. Goldcorp proposes to provide for
	the closure costs by allocating a portion of sales revenue.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Location of Mineralized Zones, Mineral Resources, Mineral Reserves, etc.
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The El Morro group of properties consists of three separate zones of porphyry style copper-
	gold &#177;molybdenum mineralization within a contiguous boundary. The La Fortuna deposit is the only
	property of the three within the outlines of the El Morro holdings with measured and indicated
	resources.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The La Fortuna deposit is considered to be an example of a primary gold&#150;copper porphyry
	system, with strong affinities to high sulphidation, volcanic-hosted gold systems. The La Fortuna
	copper-gold porphyry system extends over an 850 metres by 450 metres north&#150;south elongated area and
	is intrusive into Tertiary-age volcanic/volcano sedimentary sequences. The mineralization,
	including that which extends into the host country rocks, consists of an 800 to 900 metre diameter,
	subvertical, cylinder-shaped mineralized zone which extends downward to depths of 1 kilometre below
	surface and remains open at depth.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The deposit is significantly affected by a major northwest-trending fault system that includes
	the La Fortuna and Cantarito faults which largely define the northern and southern limits of the La
	Fortuna porphyry stock and attendant alteration system.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The La Fortuna deposit is localized within a northwest elongated alteration zone measuring
	approximately 2.5 kilometres long by up to 1.5 kilometres wide along the southeastern flank of
	Cerro La Fortuna. The outcropping portion of the deposit clearly shows a telescoped suite of
	events, which goes from the deep, high temperature-high pressure potassic alteration type into the
	intermediate argillic, phyllic and finally advanced argillic types, all in a vertical distance of
	no more than 200 metres.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The deposit is characterized by four distinct mineral zones which include, from the top down,
	an upper leached cap horizon, a transitional assemblage of secondary supergene copper oxides, an
	intermediate assemblage of secondary supergene copper sulphides (enrichment blanket) and deeper
	assemblage of primary hypogene sulphides. Copper and gold mineralization is hosted in variable
	intensities of quartz veinlet swarms, breccia zones and rarely large vein zones developed in the
	porphyry phases.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Permits
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Mining projects in Chile require both environmental approval and numerous sectorial permits
	prior to construction. Sectorial permits for the El Morro Project are not all required at the same
	time, and approvals times for different permit preparation and approval will vary. It is expected
	that permits will be prioritized and those on the critical path (requiring a long period for
	preparation or for approval, or required early in project development) will be given priority.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Key project permits required for exploitation and construction include: provision of potable
	water (Atacama Health Service); waste water, garbage, sewage, industrial waste disposal (Atacama
	Health Service; maritime considerations including port intake and discharge areas, desalination
	plant, liquid waste discharges (Port Works Office of the Ministry of Public Works, SHOA,
	Directemaar); housing and construction permits
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-61-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage77"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	(Municipality of Copiapo, Atacama Health Service, Ministry of Housing and Urbanism, Municipal Works
	Department); road construction (Road Works Department); road construction in Algarrobal sector
	(National Forest Corporation); extraction of aggregate (Municipal Works Department); storage and
	use of fuel and gas (Superintendent of Electricity and Fuels); electricity supply (Superintendent
	of Electricity and Fuels); explosives use and storage (National Office of Mobilization Chilean
	Army); mining operations (Sernageomin); telecommunications (Regional Office of the Ministry of
	Transportation and Telecommunications).
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Permits held by Goldcorp for the El Morro Project are sufficient to ensure that the
	exploration activities conducted to date within the El Morro Project area were conducted within the
	regulatory framework required by the Chilean Government.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
	Accessibility, Climate, Local Resources, Infrastructure and Physiography
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<B>
<I>
	Means of Access
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Current access to the El Morro Project is through the town of Vallenar, the nearest main town
	to the site which is situated at kilometer 663 of the Pan-American Highway, north of Santiago.
	From Vallenar, the road access, at the current time, follows 72 kilometres of paved road to the
	east to Chanchoquin and then continues another 73 kilometres to the east&#150;northeast via the Totoral
	gravel/dirt road. The proposed mine site is approximately 15 kilometres from the Chilean border
	with Argentina.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Proximity to a Population Centre and Nature of Transport
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The closest community is El Transito with a population of 1,000, located approximately 75
	kilometres by road from the El Morro Project. The nearest commercial airport is located close to
	Copiap&#243;. Chilean airlines have daily flights to and from Santiago.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Climate and Length of Operating Season
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The prevailing climate is of the high cordillera type, with freezing temperatures and moderate
	snowfalls from March to October and dry, cool summers. The proposed mine and plant site has a
	median yearly temperature of 25 degrees Celsius. During winter time, values around -1 degree
	Celsius are reached, but extremes can reach -15 degrees Celsius.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Precipitation is generally limited to snowfall during the winter months. Rainfall is rare.
	The amount of snowfall during the winter can vary from minor, blowing snow to accumulations and
	drifting of up to 2 metres. The higher peaks in the area are snow-covered year round.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Mining operations are expected to be able to be conducted year-round. Exploration field
	seasons are usually limited to the period between October and April, depending on winter climatic
	conditions associated with the high altitude
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Local Resources and Infrastructure
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A skilled labour force is available in the Copiap&#243; region and surrounding mining areas of
	northern Chile. Fuel and supplies are expected to be provided from nearby communities such as
	Copiap&#243;.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The terrain surrounding the deposits is adequate for construction of administration, camp,
	mine, plant, tailings, and waste rock disposal facilities. Goldcorp holds sufficient tenure that
	the required infrastructure can be built.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Planned mine site infrastructure to support proposed operations will include, in addition to
	the future plant site at the mine, mine access road construction and upgrades, a desalination
	plant, concentrate filtration plant, and construction of major receiving, storage, and transfer
	facilities at different locations in Chile en-route to the mine. In the 2008 feasibility study,
	Xstrata proposed construction of an entirely new access route to the Pan American highway from the
	El Morro Project.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-62-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage78"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Due to the shortage of water in the proposed mine area, Xstrata concluded in the 2008
	feasibility study that a seawater desalination plant would offer the most reliable water supply
	over the lifetime of the mine operation.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Electric power required for the project was planned in the 2008 feasibility study to be
	supplied by the Chilean central power grid from a new substation to be installed at Algarrobal
	located 50 kilometres north of the existing Maintencillo substation near Vallenar and 83 kilometres
	south of the Cardones substation near Copiap&#243;. Two overhead transmission lines will distribute
	power from the Algarrobal substation to the El Morro mine site facilities.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A concentrate filtration plant was planned to be built in the 2008 feasibility study near the
	Pan American highway in the vicinity of the community of Las Cunas, which is also on the proposed
	new access road to the El Morro site.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Topography, Elevation and Vegetation
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Project lies in the high Andes, between 3,800&#150;4,250 metres above sea level, and the
	Project area is characterized by a relatively mild relief. Vegetation is composed of hard grass
	and sparse, low bushes, typical of the cold cordilleran climate. Guanacos, foxes, hares, mice,
	vicu&#241;as and numerous cordilleran birds constitute the fauna. Permanent water flow is observed in
	several nearby streams, which drain either to the Copiapo River or to the Huasco River watersheds.
	Several permanent ice caps are located to the east near the Argentine international border.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
	History
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<B>
<I>
	Prior Ownership
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;BHP had acquired initial claims in the area in 1992. Metallica joint ventured the La Fortuna
	area with BHP in July&nbsp;1997. Metallica and BHP renegotiated the joint venture at La Fortuna into a
	Metallica option to purchase in 1999.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Metallica&#146;s subsidiary company, Minera Metallica Limitada, acquired the Cantarito and
	Tronquito claims through option agreements concluded with Cantarito Uno de la Sierra Juntas de
	Cantarito de la Estancia Huasco Alto and Tronquito uno de la Sierra Portezuelo de Cantarito de la
	Estancia Huasco Alto in 1998.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Noranda acquired the Santa Julia claims under option in the same area in 1999 from Santa Julia
	Uno de la Sierra Fortuna.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Noranda and Metallica entered into the El Morro joint venture in 1999, with each party
	contributing its claims. Noranda could earn a 70% interest over a six year period beginning
	September&nbsp;1999. Noranda was project operator from 2000 until 2005, when the company was acquired
	by Falconbridge Limited (&#147;Falconbridge&#148;).
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In September&nbsp;2005, Falconbridge paid a required $10&nbsp;million to Metallica, and this, in
	conjunction with $10&nbsp;million expenditure on exploration incurred by Noranda between 1991 and 2002,
	and earlier payments to Metallica totalling $1.6&nbsp;million, earned Falconbridge the 70% interest in
	the project.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In August&nbsp;2006, Xstrata plc (&#147;Xstrata&#148;) acquired Falconbridge&#146;s interest in the project
	through its purchase of Falconbridge. Some changes were made to the joint venture arrangement.
	Additional covenants of the original joint venture letter included an obligation for Xstrata to
	fund at its sole cost, a feasibility study, to be delivered by September&nbsp;14, 2007. Metallica had a
	one time election to have Xstrata provide for 70% of Metallica&#146;s required 30% contribution to costs
	and expenditures incurred on or before commencement of commercial production. On September&nbsp;13,
	2007, Xstrata and Metallica agreed to a four month extension to allow the feasibility report to be
	completed. The report was delivered March&nbsp;31, 2008. Metallica was subsequently acquired by New
	Gold.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On October&nbsp;11, 2009, Xstrata Chile triggered the right of first refusal (&#147;ROFR&#148;) to acquire
	its 70% interest in El Morro by delivering a notice of offer to Datawave Sciences Inc., a New Gold
	subsidiary, advising that Xstrata
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-63-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage79"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	Chile had received a third party offer dated September&nbsp;29, 2009 from Barrick Gold Corporation
	to acquire its 70% interest in El Morro for a purchase price of $463&nbsp;million, which Xstrata Chile
	intended to accept. The ROFR entitled Datawave, which holds the remaining 30% interest in El Morro,
	to purchase the Xstrata interest on the same terms and conditions as contained in the Barrick offer
	as set forth in the draft Barrick Sale Agreement which was attached to Xstrata&#146;s notice to
	Datawave.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On January&nbsp;6, 2010, Goldcorp, New Gold, Datawave and Finco (a Datawave subsidiary) entered
	into an Acquisition Funding Agreement pursuant to which the parties agreed, among other things,
	that Datawave would exercise the ROFR and purchase the Xstrata interest; Goldcorp would loan the
	funds needed by Datawave to pay for the Xstrata interest; and after the Xstrata interest was
	acquired by Datawave or a designated subsidiary of Datawave, Goldcorp or a designated subsidiary of
	Goldcorp would acquire the Xstrata interest.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Datawave exercised the ROFR on January&nbsp;7, 2010 by delivering the required notice to Xstrata
	Chile. On that same date, Goldcorp and New Gold made public disclosure of the fact that the parties
	had entered into the Acquisition Funding Agreement in connection with the exercise of the ROFR.
	Xstrata Chile communicated to Barrick that the ROFR exercise notice had been delivered and that it
	would therefore not be proceeding to complete the sale of the Xstrata interest to Barrick pursuant
	to the Barrick sale agreement.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On January&nbsp;13, 2010, Barrick commenced an action in the Ontario Superior Court of Justice,
	Court File No.&nbsp;CV-10-853900CL, naming Goldcorp, New Gold, Datawave, and Finco as defendants. The
	statement of claim alleges, among other things, that the purported exercise of the ROFR was
	unlawful and ineffective under the El Morro shareholders agreement and that, as a consequence, the
	contemplated sale of the Xstrata interest pursuant to the exercise of the ROFR would breach
	Barrick&#146;s rights under the Barrick sale agreement. The causes of action alleged against each of the
	defendants are inducing breach of contract, unlawful interference with economic interests,
	conspiracy to injure, waiver of tort and unjust enrichment.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On February&nbsp;1, 2010, Xstrata Chile delivered a letter to Barrick exercising its right to
	terminate the Barrick sale agreement on the ground that the condition precedent concerning the
	non-exercise of the ROFR had not been satisfied. On February&nbsp;2, 2010, Datawave advised Barrick that
	it and Xstrata Chile intended to proceed to complete the transactions required under section 10.4
	of the El Morro shareholders agreement to transfer the Xstrata interest from Xstrata Chile to
	Datawave pursuant to its exercise of the ROFR. On February&nbsp;5, 2010, Barrick delivered a letter to
	Xstrata Chile advising Xstrata Chile that it was in default under the Barrick sale agreement and
	that Barrick required Xstrata Chile to complete the sale to Barrick in accordance with the terms of
	the Barrick sale agreement. On February&nbsp;16, 2010, a Datawave subsidiary acquired the Xstrata
	interest from Xstrata Chile for $463&nbsp;million using the proceeds of the Goldcorp loan. Subsequently,
	a Goldcorp subsidiary acquired all of the Xstrata interest from the Datawave subsidiary as provided
	in the Acquisition Funding Agreement.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On February&nbsp;26, 2010, Barrick delivered a motion seeking leave to amend its statement of claim
	to add Xstrata Chile, Xstrata Canada and El Morro as defendants. In the amended statement of claim,
	Barrick asserts additional claims against Xstrata Chile for breach of the Barrick sale agreement
	and breach of the duty of good faith in the performance of its contractual obligations and adds
	Xstrata Canada as a defendant to the existing tort claims. See &#147;Legal Proceedings and Regulatory
	Actions&#148;.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Exploration Work
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Initial exploitation consisted of development of shallow open pits and underground workings to
	extract high-grade copper sulphide mineralization, some time prior to 1931. There is no record
	available of the tonnages or grades of material that was exploited.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Modern exploration commenced with BHP, in 1992. Work completed included geological mapping,
	rock chip sampling, and ground and airborne geophysical surveys. By 1994 the company had
	identified the La Fortuna, El Negro and Cantarito targets, the latter an epithermal gold
	occurrence. BHP drilled a total of 29 reverse circulation (&#147;RC&#148;) and core holes (5,044 metres),
	with 3,567 metres completed at La Fortuna, 1,376 metres at Cantarito and 100 metres at El Negro.
	BHP ceased exploration in 1994, but maintained the claims.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-64-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage80"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Seeking a gold prospect, and based on the Cantarito epithermal gold occurrence, Metallica
	joint ventured the La Fortuna area with BHP in July&nbsp;1997. Metallica&#146;s work program between 1997
	and 1999 comprised geological mapping, Landsat and airphoto interpretations, talus and PIMA
	sampling, MMI and enzyme leach soil sampling, stream sediment and rock chip sampling, trenching,
	and induced polarization (&#147;IP&#148;), magnetic, and resistivity ground geophysical surveys. Metallica
	drilled 3,213 metres of RC in 17 holes divided between the four areas of El Morro (seven holes), La
	Fortuna (four holes), Cantarito (four holes) and El Negro (two holes). Additionally, one core hole
	was drilled at El Morro to a depth of 500 metres.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Noranda joint-ventured into the El Morro Project in 1999. Work to 2006 comprised geological
	mapping, talus, rock chip and stream sediment sampling, IP, resistivity and ground magnetic
	geophysical surveys, and core drilling. During the period 2000 to 2003, 14 holes were drilled at
	El Morro: 146 holes (including 58,461 metres in 141 diamond holes) at La Fortuna; 26 holes at El
	Negro, and two holes at Cerro Colorado. No work was completed on the property between 2002 and
	2004. Mineral resources were first estimated for the Project in 2003.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
	Geological Setting
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<B>
<I>
	Regional, Local and Property Geology
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The El Morro Mining District sits in the Main Cordillera of the Copiap&#243; Region (Region III) in
	northern Chile.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The La Fortuna copper-gold porphyry system extends over an 850 metre by 450 metre north&#150;south
	elongated area and is intrusive into the Tertiary volcanic host rocks. The mineralization,
	including that which extends into the host country rocks, consists of an 800&#150;900 metre diameter,
	subvertical, cylinder-shaped mineralized zone which extends downward to depths of 1 kilometre below
	surface and remains open at depth. The La Fortuna deposit is localized within a northwest
	elongated alteration zone measuring approximately 2.5 kilometres long by up to 1.5 kilometres wide
	along the southeastern flank of Cerro La Fortuna.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Paleocene to Early Eocene volcanic host rocks to the intrusions consist of dacitic crystal
	tuffs which locally grade into lithic tuffs and volcanic breccias and agglomerates of the Los
	Altares Volcanic Sequence. Two copper-bearing porphyry phases are identified, the Feldspar
	Porphyry (&#147;FP&#148;) and the Quartz Porphyry (&#147;QP&#148;). The FP with a medium to coarse granular texture
	and scarce groundmass, has been classified as a porphyry because of the two grain size populations
	it shows; the abundance of plagioclase crystals, lesser amounts of biotite, scarce amphibole and
	occasionally up to 5% quartz grains has led to the rock being variously classified as
	quartz-monzodiorite, monzodiorite, granodiorite and dacite porphyry. The QP has a texture almost
	entirely obliterated by the intense phyllic alteration, but showing in places relicts of porphyry
	to micro-crystalling texture where mafic minerals are hard to distinguish in the mass of
	plagioclase crystals: the rock has been variously described as a microdiorite, dacite, andesite and
	monzodiorite porphyry.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Exploration
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Exploration has been undertaken by Metallica, Noranda, Falconbridge and Xstrata personnel, or
	by contractors (e.g. geophysical surveys). Exploration activities on the El Morro Project have
	included regional and detail mapping, rock, silt and soil sampling, trenching, RC and diamond
	drilling, ground IP geophysical surveys, mineralization characterization studies and metallurgical
	testing of samples. Petrographic studies and density measurements on the different lithologies
	have also been carried out.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A major topographic validation program was completed in 2006. This program resulted in the
	production of two digital aero-photographic restitutions at 1:10,000 and 1:2,000 scales with 10
	metres and 2 metres resolution respectively using the UTM Projection (South American 1956 Datum,
	Zone 19 South).
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Regional and detailed geological mapping was completed in a number of phases. Map scales
	varied from regional (1:105,000) to prospect scale (1:5,000). Map results were used to identify
	areas of quartz veining, alteration, silicification and sulphide outcrop that warranted additional
	work. Interpretation of satellite imagery and air photos were used to identify areas that required
	geological mapping and sampling.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-65-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage81"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Stream sediment, talus, soil and rock chip sampling, and PIMA alteration studies were used to
	evaluate mineralization potential and generate targets for RC and diamond drilling. In general,
	geochemical sampling and PIMA alteration surveys have been effective at identifying areas of
	prospective copper-gold mineralization, often buried at depths ranging from 10 to 100 metres.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 1998 Metallica conducted a talus sampling program at two different areas of the El Morro
	mineralized zone; a multi-element analysis of the northern zone, and a copper-gold-molybdenum
	analysis of the southern zone. The copper-gold-molybdenum anomalies confirmed the exploration
	potential of the El Morro area. In 1999 Metallica completed a 100 metres x 100 metres grid talus
	sampling over the La Fortuna area. The copper-gold-molybdenum anomalies also confirmed the
	exploration potential at the La Fortuna area. A strong copper anomaly of 0.27% is present at La
	Fortuna in association with high gold values of up to 0.32 grams per ton of gold. Molybdenum is
	anomalous, and is more or less coincident with the elevated gold values. The anomaly distribution
	of lead, zinc, arsenic, antimony, and vanadium behave as expected in a porphyry system.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At the northern end of El Negro a zone identified as the Camp area produced
	copper-gold-molybdenum geochemical anomalies covering a surface area of approximately 0.6
	kilometres x 1.2 kilometres. A 50 metre long chip channel sample on a road cut near the
	exploration camp, gave 0.26% copper, 0.13 grams per ton of gold and 22 parts per million molybdenum
	result. The area was tested in a preliminary manner by drilling, which encountered minor low-grade
	copper, gold and molybdenum mineralization.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Geophysical surveying has been effective in mapping sulfide mineralization that could include
	copper and gold mineralization associated with porphyry systems. At least four mineralized systems
	have been defined from the work, all of which are interpreted to represent porphyry systems.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 1998, Quantec Geof&#237;sica Limitada (&#147;Quantec&#148;) conducted a gradient array IP survey at
	the El Morro Project. During early 1999, gradient IP and ground magnetic surveys were conducted on
	the El Morro, El Negro and La Fortuna grids. Several reconnaissance lines were also surveyed on a
	separate grid, El Burro. Numerous lines were surveyed with dipole-dipole array IP at El Morro, El
	Negro and La Fortuna to provide better control and depth information for the anomalous zones.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The IP and resistivity surveys were conducted in the time domain with the gradient,
	dipole-dipole, and pole-dipole arrays. The gradient array utilized current dipoles 2 to 4
	kilometres in length. Station and dipole spacing were 100 metres. The dipole-dipole array with a
	dipole spacing of 200 metres was employed on the grids. The ground magnetic survey was conducted
	on the same lines and grids as the gradient array IP survey. Station spacing was 10 metres, and
	all data were corrected for diurnal drift using readings from a base station.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Geotechnical and hydrological studies were performed between 2006 to 2008 to support
	feasibility-level studies. Work completed included:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	&#149;
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	Geomechanical core logging and orientation of drill core using the Ballmark
<SUP STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: TEXT-TOP">
	&#174;
</SUP>
	core
	orientation system (1250 structures) and acoustic televiewer (ATV)&nbsp;surveys (1697
	structures).
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	&#149;
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	Hydrogeological instrumentation and testing including double-packer and triple-packer
	testing, installation of nine vibrating wire piezometers, eight sealed PVC standpipe
	piezometers and one open PVC standpipe piezometer, and response testing of the sealed
	standpipe piezometers.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	&#149;
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	Point Load Index testing of drill core, defining 2798 valid tests, to estimate
	unconfined compressive strength of the different geotechnical units.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	&#149;
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	Laboratory testing of core samples, including the following valid tests: 27 direct
	shear, 34 uniaxial compressive strength, 32 triaxial compressive strength, and 19 Brazilian
	Disc tensile tests.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	&#149;
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	Discontinuity set mapping and characterization of surface outcrop (200 structures) and
	underground exposures (2,423 structures) from the exploration bulk sample decline.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Petrography and mineralogical studies have been completed. In order to define zoning of
	elements besides copper, gold, molybdenum, and silver in the La Fortuna system and also verify
	possible significant levels of deleterious elements (such as lead, arsenic, mercury, etc.), 5% of
	the sample population was tested by ICP analysis in 2000. Results indicated no deleterious
	elements are present in major amounts.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;An
	1,150 metre long exploration decline was sunk in 2006 to provide bulk
	sampling for metallurgical purposes, to confirm grade continuity from
	the bulk samples, and to provide additional density data.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Mineralization
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	The La Fortuna deposit is considered to be an example of a primary gold-copper porphyry system,
	with strong affinities to high sulphidation, volcanic-hosted gold systems.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Porphyry deposits in general are large, low to medium-grade deposits in which primary
	(hypogene)&nbsp;sulphide minerals are dominantly structurally-controlled and which are spatially and
	genetically related to felsic to intermediate porphyritic intrusions. The large size and
	structural control (e.g., veins, vein sets, stockworks, fractures, &#145;crackled zones&#146; and breccia
	pipes) serve to distinguish porphyry deposits from a variety of deposits that may be peripherally
	associated, including skarns, high-temperature mantos, breccia pipes, peripheral mesothermal veins,
	and epithermal precious metal deposits. Secondary minerals may be developed in supergene-enriched
	zones in porphyry copper deposits by weathering of primary sulphides. Such zones typically have
	significantly higher copper grades, thereby enhancing the potential for economic exploitation.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-66-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage82"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Approximately 3 kilometres to the south west of La Fortuna is the El Negro prospect. The El
	Negro porphyry is a granodioritic stock that has been overprinted by an assemblage of strong
	potassic (biotite&#150;K-feldspar&#150;magnetite &#177; apatite) alteration in association with a weakly-developed
	quartz-vein stockwork. Aphanitic andesite, sandstone, micro-conglomerates or fine-grained crystal
	tuff, that gently dip east, form the country rock.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The individual intrusive pulses usually are small in size, not greater than 200&#150; 300 metres in
	diameter, or occur as dykes. The largest, the El Negro Porphyry, which hosts minor sulphide
	mineralization is granodioritic in composition, with feldspar&#150;biotite&#150;quartz phenocrysts in a
	medium-grained groundmass.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;El Morro is a 1 kilometre squared zone of hydrothermal alteration that is characterized by
	kaolinitic external halos grading inward to quartz&#150;sericite alteration and a potassic core. The
	prospect is about 4 kilometres west of La Fortuna.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Copper-gold mineralization occurs within a secondary supergene blanket (pyrite-chalcocite) and
	an underlying zone of hypogene sulphides (pyrite-chalcopyrite) developed beneath an immature
	goethitic/jarositic leached cap. Mineralization centres on a zone of potassic alteration
	(secondary biotite &#043; quartz) that is surrounded by a broader zone of illite-kaolinite alteration.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Cantarito zone is a zone of epithermal mineralization, located 700 metres east of La
	Fortuna. A system of high-sulphidation gold veins has been emplaced along a northwest-trending
	fault system. Mineralization is hosted within Jurassic-age tuffs. Despite hosting local bonanza
	gold grades, attempts to develop a Mineral Resource estimate for Cantarito have largely failed to
	date due to the erratic distribution of gold grades.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Drilling
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Drilling on the El Morro Project has consisted of 206 core (84,245.13 metres) and 67 RC
	(14,330.05 metres) drill holes for a total 273 holes drilled (98,575.18 metres).
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The name of the drill contractor used for the BHP and Metallica drilling is not known. An
	independent contractor, Connors, using either a Boyles 37 or Boyles 56 type drill rig, conducted
	the core drilling for Noranda in 2000&#150;2001 and for Falconbridge in 2005&#150;2007 at the El Morro
	Project. Ausdrill was used in 2002.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;There is no information on the RC drill methods. Reverse circulation samples were collected
	at regular 2 metre intervals in plastic bags at the sample cyclone. Samples were split at the
	drill site, and about 4 kilograms was generated for assay. A small sample of the drill cuttings
	was also collected and washed for logging which was done at either the project logging facility or
	offsite at the project office.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In all core drilling completed at EL Morro since 1993, standard diamond drilling has employed
	PQ (83.1 millimetre diameter), HQ3 (63.5 millimetre diameter) and NQ3 (47.6 millimetre diameter)
	core size. Core has always been collected using wireline retrieval methods.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Core was transferred to wooden core boxes and brought to the project core processing facility
	where it was photographed, logged for geologic and geotechnical information, and sampled.
	Transport of core boxes to the core shed was done by personnel from the company that was managing
	the drill program, or the drilling supervisor.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Core recovery averaged better than 80% for 95% of the core intervals. The zones with low
	recovery are associated with the first 20&#150;30 metres below the surface which corresponds with the
	leached&#150;weathered portion of the deposit.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Logging of RC drill cuttings and core utilized standard logging procedures that recorded
	lithological, mineralogical and geotechnical data.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At La Fortuna, drill hole locations have typically been surveyed both prior to drilling and
	following completion of individual holes by conventional surveying techniques. At the conclusion
	of the June&nbsp;2006 drill program, all collars had either been re-surveyed by an independent
	contractor and/or checked using high definition GPS instrumentation.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-67-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage83"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Down-hole deviation directional surveys were done on all diamond core holes using either a
	single shot Sperry Sun instrument (50 metre down-hole intervals), a digital gyroscope, or a
	&#147;Maxibore&#148; instrument (3 metres down-hole intervals). Single shot surveying was used for only a
	few of the early exploration holes, while all delineation holes drilled after 2000 were surveyed
	with either the gyroscope or Maxi-bore instruments.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The central portion of the La Fortuna deposit has been delineated at a nominal drill grid
	spacing of 55 metres by 55 metres with most of the core holes inclined -65 degrees to -70 degrees
	either to the southwest or northeast (azimuth 30 degrees or 210 degrees) with several holes drilled
	orthogonally to the drill grid. On the deposit margins, drill spacing widens to 100 metres x 100
	metres and 150 metres x 150 metres. Within the volume represented by the current resource block
	model, drill hole depths average 412 metres and range from a minimum of 84 metres to a maximum of
	970 metres testing a vertical profile that extends between 4,100-3,200 metres elevation.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
	Sampling and Analysis
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<B>
<I>
	Methods, Location, Nature, Spacing, Density
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Reverse circulation samples were collected at regular 2 metre intervals in plastic bags at the
	sample cyclone. Samples were split at the drill site, and about 4 kilograms was generated for
	assay.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Core is sampled on regular 2 metre intervals, irrespective of lithology or mineralization
	style. Core was split using either mechanical core splitters or a combination of manual and
	electro-hydraulic core splitters.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Density samples were taken at regular 4 metre intervals for all diamond drill holes drilled at
	La Fortuna. Bulk density factors were determined by project personnel using a wax coating method
	to coat 10&#150;20 centimetres of unsplit HQ and NQ core samples and then weighing in both air and
	submerged in water to determine the density value. Tonnage factors for resource estimation were
	derived by calculating an average bulk density based on drill core density data for each lithology
	and mineral zone combinations and then applied as a global average to the block model lithology
	code.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Several primary assay laboratories have been used for routine analyses over the project
	history. Laboratories include Actlabs S.A. (Actlabs), Bondar Clegg, and ACME Analytical
	Laboratorios S.A. (&#147;Acme&#148;). Umpire (secondary)&nbsp;laboratories during the project analytical history
	include Geoanalytica, CIMM and ALS Chemex. All laboratories are currently certified and are
	independent of Goldcorp, and were independent of project operators.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Samples were dried in a gas oven at 80&#150;100 degrees Celsius. After drying, the entire sample
	was crushed to nominal minus 10 mesh size. The sample was thoroughly blended using a riffle
	splitter. A representative sample cut of approximately 250 grams was pulverized to 95% minus 150
	mesh and placed in an envelope as the assay pulp for analysis.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The analytical method used by Bondar Clegg for the early programs was geochemical analysis for
	the copper and molybdenum values and fire assay with an atomic absorption finish for the gold
	values. For later analytical programs, copper, silver and molybdenum were analyzed by AAS
	following a four-acid digest. Gold was analyzed via fire assay and an AAS finish.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Sample Quality
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The author of the El Morro Report is of the opinion that the quality of the gold analytical
	data are sufficiently reliable to support Mineral Resource and Mineral Reserve estimation and that
	sample preparation, analysis, and security are generally performed in accordance with exploration
	best practices and industry standards.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-68-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage84"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Quality Control
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Neither the Metallica nor the BHP drilling programs included quality assurance/quality control
	(&#147;QA/QC&#148;) samples.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Metallica noted that the data reliability programs for the 1999 to 2001 programs were
	professionally done according to accepted industry methods and standards. In 2002, Noranda
	implemented a revised system of basic QA/QC procedures. Subsequent Xstrata programs have continued
	the Noranda sampling and logging procedures. QA/QC includes submission of standard reference
	materials, duplicates, and blanks, and re-assay of a proportion of the samples.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Data Verification
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A number of data verification programs and audits have been performed over the Project
	history. These included assay database audits in 1999&#150;2001, and 2002&#150;2005 by Noranda, and
	2005&#150;2007 by Xstrata; a downhole survey database audit by external consultants Norwest in 2006; and
	an independent review in 2007 by AMEC of the proposed database to support feasibility-level
	studies.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;These programs indicated an assay database that was acceptable to support Mineral Resource and
	Mineral Reserve estimation.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Goldcorp performed an independent data review of the information supporting the 2008
	feasibility study as part of its due diligence assessment on the El Morro Project acquisition.
	This indicated to Goldcorp that the 2008 feasibility study results were appropriate to support
	Goldcorp&#146;s declaration of Mineral Resources and Mineral Reserves for the La Fortuna deposit.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Security
	of Samples
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Sample security was not generally practiced at La Fortuna during the drilling programs, due to
	the remote nature of the site. Sample security relied upon the fact that the samples were always
	attended or locked at the sample dispatch facility. Sample collection and transportation have
	always been undertaken by company or laboratory personnel using company vehicles.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Drill samples were either picked up at site by ALS Chemex, or prepared to a pulp at a sample
	preparation facility operated at site by either Actlabs or ACME, depending on the year. Pulps were
	transported by laboratory personnel to the appropriate analytical facility.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Chain of custody procedures consisted of filling out sample submittal forms that were sent to
	the laboratory with sample shipments to make certain that all samples were received by the
	laboratory.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-69-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>

</H5>
<P>

<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Mineral
	Reserve and Mineral Resource Estimates
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following table sets forth the estimated Mineral Reserves for Goldcorp&#146;s 70% interest in
	the El Morro Project as of March&nbsp;31, 2008:
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 18PT">

</DIV>

<TD>

<TD>

</TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT">
	146.0
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;

<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	The Mineral Resources for the El Morro Project set out in the table above have been
	estimated by Maryse Belanger, P.Geo., Goldcorp, who is a qualified person under NI 43-101.
	The Mineral Resources are classified as measured, indicated and inferred, and are based on
	the CIM Standards.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>

	(2)
</TD>

</TD>

<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">

	&nbsp;

	(3)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	Mineral Resources that are not Mineral Reserves and do not have demonstrated economic
	viability.
</TD>

<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(4)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	Mineral Resources are estimated using a gold price of $500 per ounce, and a copper
	price of $1.25 per pound.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(5)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>

	Tonnages include allowances for losses resulting from mining methods.
</TD>

<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>

<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(6)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	Ounces and pounds are estimates of metal contained in the Mineral Resource and do not
	include allowances for processing losses.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>

	reasonable prospects of eventual economic extraction.

	&nbsp;

</TD>
