</TABLE>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Mining
	Operations
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Life-of-mine production assumptions in the 2008 feasibility study were two years of
	pre-stripping, and 14&nbsp;years of metal production. A total 162.1&nbsp;million tonnes of pre-strip is
	projected, with 2.66&nbsp;million tonnes of mineralization stockpiled to be sent to the crusher in Year
	10. The mining rate is envisaged at 90,000 tonnes per day.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Production will start in the last part of the second year of pre-strip, with 2.7&nbsp;million
	tonnes of ore sent to the plant. Production will be approximately 32 to 33&nbsp;million tonnes per year
	from production Year 1 to Year 14, with approximately 147&nbsp;million tonnes per year of waste
	generated annually in the same period. For Years 1 to 7, about 20&nbsp;million tonnes per year of
	low-grade mineralization will be sent to a low-grade stockpile for treatment in Year 10. Low-grade
	was defined as any material with a copper equivalent grade of between 0.325% and the actual cut-off
	grade for any mining period. For planning purposes, the period by period cut-off grades ranged
	from a low of
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-70-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage86"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	0.3% copper equivalent in the later years of planned mine life (Years 9 to 18) to a peak of 0.55%
	copper equivalent in the first year of production.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;All mining will be carried out on 15 metre benches. Ramp and step-out widths will be 35
	metres, with about 180 metres between ramps. Inter-ramp slope angles range from 40&#150;49&#186;; whereas
	design bench face angles range from 62&#150;67&#186;.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Within the current open pit plan, the material that is classified as Inferred Mineral
	Resources, but treated as waste for the purposes of developing the mine plan and within the
	financial analysis. While there is a reasonable expectation that some or all of the Inferred
	Mineral Resources can be upgraded and classified as higher-confidence Mineral Resources with
	additional exploration and blast hole drilling programs, Goldcorp cautions that some or all of this
	Inferred mineralization may not be able to be converted to higher-confidence Mineral Resource
	categories or eventually to Mineral Reserves.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The waste dump is planned to be located south of the pit, in the Quebrada Larga. A total of
	38&nbsp;million tonnes of waste from the pre-strip will be trucked 6 kilometres to the proposed tailings
	dam location, also in the Quebrada Larga to be used in rock wall construction. The primary crusher
	will be situated about 1.5 kilometres west of the pit, adjacent the concentrator.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Open pit mining will be carried out with haul trucks and a combination of rope and electric
	shovels, excavators, and large front-end loaders. All rock will require drilling for sampling and
	blasting purposes.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The 2008 feasibility study envisages the owner manpower commencing in the pre-strip period
	with 320 persons, increasing to a peak of 358 in Years 6 and 7, and then decreasing to 146 persons
	in Year 14. Contractor manpower, used in the mining operation, is envisaged as commencing with 365
	persons in Year 1, and peaking at 397 persons in Years 8 and 9.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Process
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The plant design considered in the 2008 feasibility study is conventional for the copper
	industry, and uses some of the largest processing machinery currently available. Plant design
	includes a crushing plant, semi-autogenous grinding (SAG)&nbsp;circuit, pebble crusher, rougher
	flotation and regrind circuit, and cleaner and scavenger flotation banks. Concentrate will be
	transferred via pipeline to a concentrate filter plant about 9 kilometres east of the Pan-American
	Highway, 108 kilometres from site. Filtered concentrate will be trucked to the proposed port site
	for trans-shipment. Tailings from the plant will be thickened, and gravity-fed to the tailings
	storage facility.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Marketing and Sales
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The marketing strategy developed for the 2008 feasibility study envisaged that approximately
	70% of sales would be made under long-term contracts to Asian smelters, and 30% of sales to
	European smelters. Sales were designed as a mixture of long-term and spot sales, varying from 56%
	long-term to 44% spot from Years 1 to 6 to 39% long-term to 61% spot for Years 7 to 10, and 100% of
	sales at spot prices for all years thereafter to the end of mine life. This mix of sales provides
	the El Morro Project with some marketing flexibility and the ability to enter into long-term sales,
	if warranted, later in the mine life.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Taxation
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Chilean companies are subject to a statutory income tax rate of 35% on its taxable income.
	However, that rate is applicable as a 17% tax on income accrued at company level, and the 18%
	balance is applied when the company distributes profits to a foreign parent company by way of
	dividends. This tax on dividends, or second tier tax, may be deferred indefinitely as long as (i)
	dividends are paid to local shareholder company, or (ii)&nbsp;if the foreign parent immediately
	reinvests the dividends in another Chilean company.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The asset model used to analyze the economics of the El Morro deposit does not include the
	impact of the second tier tax.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On top of the regular income tax, there is a 5% mining tax which is calculated on operative
	net income (earnings before interest and taxes with regular rather than accelerated depreciation).
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The financial model incorporates a blend of funding from the Corporation by way of equity and
	internal debt, optimized based on thin capitalization rules in the Chilean tax laws.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Capital Costs
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;An initial capital investment of $2,499&nbsp;million was projected, and included an allowance for
	real price escalation and a 13.1% contingency allowance. The total life-of-mine capital
	expenditure, including sustaining capital, was estimated at $2,771&nbsp;million.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-71-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage87"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Operating Costs
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The weighted average operating cost for the 14&nbsp;years of the El Morro Project operation is
	$10.65 per tonne or $0.95 per pound of fine copper. For the purposes of due diligence review and the El Morro Report, Goldcorp
	accepted the operating cost assumptions in the 2008 feasibility study. However, Goldcorp plans,
	during 2010, to update all cost parameters for the 2008 feasibility study to reflect Goldcorp&#146;s
	metal price and exchange rate predictions, and to procure updated operating cost estimates.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Financial Analysis
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The El Morro cashflow model was developed first quarter 2008. The Project was evaluated on a
	pre-tax, project stand-alone, 100% equity-financed basis. Capital costs for mine development were
	treated as sunk costs for an operating mine, therefore payback considerations for the El Morro
	Project are not relevant as part of the financial analysis. Certain key economic assumptions were
	made, and at the estimated long-term copper and gold prices above, the El Morro Project base case
	provides a negative after-tax full-equity net present value of -$1,150&nbsp;million. The combination of
	high capital cost, and relatively short mine life were key impacts on project profitability.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Sensitivity analyses indicated that the project is sensitive to operating costs and metal
	prices. If costs for the base case were maintained, but copper prices increased, the El Morro
	Project showed positive returns for a long-term copper price above $2.04 per pound. In the case
	where the copper price was maintained at $1.25 per pound, and the operating and capital costs for
	the base case were maintained, the project showed a positive return for gold prices in the vicinity
	of $1,400 per ounce. Spot prices at the effective date of the El Morro Report were $3.38 per pound
	for copper and $1,135 per ounce for gold.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Exploration
	and Development
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The existing infrastructure, availability of staff, the existing power, water, and
	communications facilities, the methods whereby goods are transported to the mine, and any planned
	modifications or supporting studies are sufficiently well-established, or the requirements to
	establish such, are well understood by Goldcorp, and can support the declaration of Mineral
	Resources and Mineral Reserves. Key infrastructure requirements include development of a new
	access route, construction of water and concentrate pipelines, an electrical line, port,
	concentrate facility and desalination plant.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the opinion of the author of the El Morro Report, the El Morro Project warrants additional
	work, specifically updating the 2008 feasibility study to reflect the current operating climate,
	costs, metal prices and exchange rates. This indicates the data supporting the Mineral Resource
	and Mineral Reserve estimates were appropriately collected, evaluated and estimated, and the
	original project objective of identifying mineralization that could support development of a mining
	operation has been achieved.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During due diligence studies on the El Morro Project, Goldcorp reviewed the 2008 feasibility
	study and noted a number of areas that require review, and have the potential to enhance project
	economics. These areas are planned to be reviewed as part of a feasibility study update to be
	performed during 2010.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT">
<A NAME="X60364EXV99W1_HTM_120">
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
	MARLIN MINE, GUATEMALA
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;James S. Voorhees, P.Eng., formerly at Glamis, prepared an amended technical report dated
	November&nbsp;11, 2003 entitled &#147;Marlin Project Technical Report&#148; (the &#147;Marlin Report&#148;). Mr.&nbsp;Voorhees
	is a qualified person under NI 43-101. The following description of the Marlin Mine has been
	summarized, in part, from the Marlin Report and readers should consult the Marlin Report to obtain
	further particulars regarding the Marlin Mine. The Marlin Report is available for review on the
	SEDAR website located at
<U>
<I>
	www.sedar.com
</I>
</U>
	under Glamis&#146; profile.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Project Description and Location
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Marlin Mine is 100% owned by Montana Exploradora de Guatemala, S.A., a wholly-owned
	subsidiary of the Corporation. It is located in the northern section of the province of San Marcos
	in the municipality of San Miguel Ixtahuacan in western Guatemala, approximately 140 kilometres
	northwest of the capital, Guatemala City.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The project consists of one 200 hectare exploitation concession and 10,000 hectares of
	exploration concession. Approximately 550 small properties have been purchased by the Corporation
	and steps are being taken to have title to surface rights registered in the Corporation&#146;s name. All
	of the surface rights in the vicinity of the project area are believed to be privately controlled,
	but few of the owners possess written title to their land.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Guatemalan mining law provides three types of licenses. The licenses are reconnaissance,
	exploration and exploitation. A reconnaissance license has a six month period of duration with the
	possibility of renewal for an additional six month period. This license can cover an area from 500
	to 3,000 square kilometres and upon application it can be converted to an exploitation license. An
	exploration license covers an area of up to 100 square kilometres and has a term of
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-72-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage88"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	three years with the possibility of extension for two additional two year terms. With each
	extension the surface area should be reduced by 50&nbsp;percent. An exploitation license follows from
	the exploration license and has a 25&nbsp;year term with an extension for a second 25&nbsp;year term upon
	application. It covers a maximum of 20 square kilometres. Surface rights fees are payable with
	all types of licenses and a royalty of one percent is payable at the exploitation stage. The one
	percent royalty is shared equally between the state and the municipality where the project is
	situated.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;All environmental regulatory permits, licenses and authorizations required to carry out
	planned operations at the Marlin Mine have been obtained and are in good standing.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Accessibility, Climate, Local Resources, Infrastructure and Physiography
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Marlin Mine is 25 kilometres by air west-southwest of the town of Huehuetenango or 300
	kilometres by paved and gravel roads from Guatemala City. The Corporation has completed
	substantial improvements on roads leading into and roads within the project area.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The climate is predominantly warm and dry with well defined wet and dry seasons. The majority
	of the 1,088 millimetres of average annual rainfall occurs from April to October. The average
	yearly temperature in the area is approximately 25 degrees Celsius. Typically high temperatures
	are estimated to reach 40 degrees Celsius with low temperatures falling to 3 degrees Celsius.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Power for the mine is obtained from a local power broker and is provided via a 27 kilometre
	power line built by the Corporation and dedicated to the Marlin Mine.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Water is provided from two deep wells that encounter fracture-controlled water sources. No
	water is pumped from the Rio Tzala as originally envisioned. Water is stored in a small pond and
	gravity distributed throughout the property.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Topography at the project site is characterized by moderate to steep terrain with elevations
	ranging from 1,800 to 2,300 metres above sea level.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	History
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Marlin deposit was discovered in western Guatemala through regional grass-roots
	exploration in 1998 by Montana Exploradora, S.A. and was later purchased by Francisco Gold
	Corporation (&#147;Francisco&#148;) in 2000. In June&nbsp;2002, Francisco shareholders approved a Plan of
	Arrangement between Glamis and Francisco that merged Francisco into Glamis and effectively
	transferred control of the Marlin Mine to Glamis. With the Guatamalan government&#146;s issuance of
	environmental permits and the key exploitation license, construction on the project commenced early
	in 2004. In the second quarter of 2004, the Glamis board increased the original development budget
	from $120&nbsp;million to $140&nbsp;million to incorporate additional capacity and reflect the increased
	costs of construction materials. Mill capacity expanded by more than 20&nbsp;percent to 5,000 tonnes
	per day.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Geological Setting
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Marlin district is located 15 to 20 kilometres south of the Cuilco-Chixoy-Polichic Fault,
	a major sinistral transform fault that separates the North American and Central American cratons.
	Tertiary movement is documented to be over 150 kilometres. The Marlin deposit is on a projection
	of a southern splay off of the Polochic fault system. The northern side of the Polochic fault
	system contains Mesozoic sediments. The south side of the Polochic fault contains Paleozoic
	schist, gneiss and granite and a series of Tertiary mafic volcanic eruptive events composed mostly
	of dacitic to andesitic tuff, lahar and andesitic to basaltic flows. These eruptive units are
	separated by thin beds of waterlain sediments composed mostly of shale and tuffaceous shale. These
	older volcanics are covered by thick eruptive units of Quaternary and recent dacitic volcanic ash.
	The Marlin deposit is located within the Tertiary mafic eruptive unit. The deposit trends in the
	same direction as the Polochic fault system.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;There are four major lithologic units present at the Marlin site: quaternary pyroclastic
	deposits, marlin andesites, tertiary volcaniclastic sequence and porphyric dykes.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-73-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage89"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Mineralization
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The mineralization lies on the eastern portion of a two kilometre east-west trending vein
	system, which is one of several parallel vein systems identified in the Marlin district. Most of
	the mineralization is in quartz veins and quartz vein stockwork within a Tertiary-age, dacitic,
	lithic tuff of the Marlin formation or within south-dipping tectonic breccia zones within the
	Tertiary Volcaniclastic Sequence. A small part of the mineralization is in calcite veins.
	Drilling to date has confirmed geological continuity along strike to include the Cochis and the
	Main Zone.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The mineralization is consistent over an east-west distance of 1,500 metres and is up to 300
	metres wide. A 150 by 75 metre on surface layer of weathered vein &#147;rubble&#148; overlies the main zone
	of Marlin. Clay alteration consisting of illite and kaolinite forms adjacent to the veins although
	not abundant. Post mineralization faults have produced shear zones within the mineralization.
	Approximately 9&nbsp;percent of the mineralization and 30&nbsp;percent of the reserves found to date are
	oxide. The remaining is non-oxide. The non-oxide mineralization contains pyrite at concentrations
	of one to three percent.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Exploration
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2005, exploration activities concentrated on drilling two of the several veins which have
	been identified in the area of the Marlin Mine. A total of 27 holes were completed during the year
	at the West Vero zone located 0.7 kilometres south of the main Marlin zone. The Rosa vein was also
	drilled from the underground mine. Additionally, in-fill drilling at the La Hamaca deposit located
	3 kilometres north of Marlin allowed for the conversion of 152,000 ounces of gold resources to
	reserves.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2006, exploration activities concentrated on continued drilling of the West Vero and Agel
	areas adjacent to the Marlin Mine. A total of 37 holes were completed during the year at the West
	Vero and Agel zones. Some infill drilling was also carried out at the La Hamaca deposit.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2007, exploration focused on definition of additional reserves in the Marlin West extension
	zone, conversion of West Vero zone resources to reserves and advancement of the exploration drift
	towards the Coral zone, a satellite occurrence located one kilometre north of Marlin. During the
	year, a total of 24 holes were drilled for a total of 11,410 metres at West Marlin, 21 holes were
	drilled for a total of 7,647 metres at West Vero and 187 metres of underground drift development
	towards Coral was completed.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2008, exploration continued to focus activities on the West Vero zone, West Marlin
	extension and the Coral drift. As of December&nbsp;31, 2008, 7,601 metres of drilling were carried out
	at West Vero, consisting of 17 holes, 7,346 metres of drilling were carried out at West Marlin,
	consisting of 19 holes, and 316 metres of drift were completed in the Coral drift as well as 519
	metres of drilling in one hole to reach the Coral zone.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2009, exploration continued in the West Vero zone, the West Tello extension area, the Coral
	zone and the new Ixcaniche target area. Underground drilling was also carried out to define
	extensions of the Tello and Rosa veins. As of December&nbsp;31, 2009, 22 drill holes for 14,082 metres
	were completed at West Vero, 6 drill holes for 879 metres were completed in the West Tello zone, 4
	drill holes for 871 metres were completed at Coral and 1 drill hole for 371 metres was completed at
	Ixcaniche. Underground exploration drilling of the Rosa and Tello veins comprised 14 drill holes
	for 3,917 metres. In addition, 56 metres of underground development were completed in the Coral
	drift.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Drilling
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Marlin Mine has been drilled nearly continuously since Francisco discovered the property
	and began drilling in 2001. Francisco completed 72 core holes totalling 7,606 metres. The
	drilling was concentrated around the outcrop of gold mineralization and its extension into the
	subsurface. The average drill-hole depth is 106 metres. After purchasing the property from
	Francisco in 2002, Glamis concentrated on expanding the mineralization down dip and along strike
	with a combination of 150 rotary, 119 rotary/core holes (rotary pre-collared) and 97 shallow holes
	drilled in the rubble zone.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Rotary drilling was the primary source of sample collection in 2002. Shallow RZG holes were
	drilled evaluating the surficial &#147;rubble zone&#148; a regolith which contains higher than average grade
	mineralization. The average depth of these holes is 14 metres. Sample intervals of the RC
	drilling are 1.5 metres. During 2003, rotary drilling was primarily used to pre-collar core holes.
	The rotary holes were drilled to a point above the lower grade domain. Sample interval of the RC
	drilling is 1.5 metres.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-74-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage90"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Glamis used core drilling predominantly to determine the geometry and grade of the high grade
	quartz vein. Holes are collared using H size core and reduce to N as drilling conditions dictate.
	Sample interval of the core drilling averages 1.56 metres and varies from a minimum of 0.01 metres
	to 6.09 metres.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Subsequent to operational start-up, surface and underground exploration drilling has continued
	on a regular basis. As of December&nbsp;31, 2008, the Corporation had drilled and received analytical
	assay data on 1,405 drill holes (reverse circulation and core) totalling 231,967 metres.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Sampling and Analysis
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Rotary samples collected from 4
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 70%">
<SUP>
	3
</SUP>
</FONT>
	/
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 60%">
	4
</FONT>
	inch, face-sampling, hammer-drilled reverse circulation
	holes are initially collected in a five-gallon bucket. The weight is then recorded and the sample
	placed into the hopper of a Gilson splitter. The process is repeated until the entire 1.5 metre
	sample is collected. The total weight is recorded on the sample sheet along with the sample
	identification and the time of day collected. Weights are only recorded for the dry portion of the
	drill hole. The Gilson splitter is set to split the sample into two halves, one half is retained
	and the other half is wasted. The remaining 50&nbsp;percent is placed into the hopper again and another
	50&nbsp;percent split is made. The two samples are placed into pre-labeled plastic sample bags, one for
	assay and the other is stored. An air hose and nozzle is provided for blowing out the Gilson
	splitter, pan and buckets. A geologist is assigned to the rotary rig to supervise sample
	collection and log geology.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The diamond drill core is collected and placed in wooden core boxes made locally on site. The
	core is washed to obtain a clean surface for geologic and geotechnical logging and placed in a
	covered logging facility. All core is photographed on print film. Core is sawn longitudinally
	with a diamond saw and half the core, on a nominal 1.5 metre interval broken at lithologic
	boundaries, is placed in a pre-labeled plastic bag. The other core holes are shipped to Chemex&#146;s
	Hermosillo, Mexico laboratory for preparation. After preparation, the samples were shipped for
	assaying to either Rocky Mountain Geochemical&#146;s laboratory in Reno, Nevada or Chemex Labs in
	Vancouver, British Columbia. Since June&nbsp;2002, when Glamis began the second drilling program, splits
	from the core holes are shipped to a facility operated by Inspectorate&#146;s laboratory in Sparks,
	Nevada for assay. Unused core from both drilling campaigns is available for inspection on site.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Inspectorate uses their rock sample preparation on the Marlin samples. Thoroughly dried
	samples are reduced to greater than 80&nbsp;percent passing 10 mesh using a two stage crushing
	procedure, jaw and roll mill. After homogenization, a 300 gram split is obtained using a Jones
	riffle splitter. The split is further reduced to greater than 90&nbsp;percent passing 150 mesh. Clean
	sand is employed in pulverization between all samples. The sand then is inserted into the sample
	stream one per batch where it is reported as a blank sample.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gold and silver is estimated for each sample using fire assay. Samples that exceed three
	grams per tonne of gold and 200 grams per tonne of silver are automatically submitted for fire
	assay-gravimetric finish. If geologists identify visible gold in the core, the sample is submitted
	for 5 assay tonne analysis.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Bulk density determination was performed on 92 core samples. The distribution of density
	samples within the mineralized area is sufficient for resource estimation.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Although the number of quartz determinations appears low, the confidence interval at 95
	percent is an acceptable 3&nbsp;percent. The number of determinations in the rubble zone is also low
	but the zone only contains 300,000 tonnes.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Security of Samples
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Both independent laboratories used in the Marlin Mine exercise quality control in the form of
	duplicates, standard reference materials and blanks.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Glamis established a limited QA/QC program focused on coarse reject and pulp reject checks. A
	frequency of 1 in 20 pulps is systematically submitted to the check lab (Chemex Labs, Nevada) for
	gold and silver analysis. Coarse rejects are also submitted to the check lab.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-75-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage91"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Samples analyzed at Inspectorate and Chemex were paired and examined on scatterplots. In
	general, the check and primary labs agree within an overall average of less than 5&nbsp;percent.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>

</I>
</B>

</TD>

	&nbsp;

<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">

<TD WIDTH="3%">

<TD WIDTH="96">
</TD>

<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	The Mineral Resources for the Marlin Mine set out in the table above have been estimated by
	Andrew S. Tripp, P.Eng., Marlin Mine, who is a qualified person under NI 43-101.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">

</TD>

<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(3)
</TD>

	&nbsp;
