</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The terms of the Corporation&#146;s revolving term credit facility and certain debt held by the
	Corporation&#146;s subsidiaries requires the Corporation and certain of its subsidiaries, with some
	exceptions, to satisfy various affirmative and negative covenants and to meet financial ratios and
	tests, including ratios and tests based on leverage, interest coverage and net worth. The
	covenants under the Corporation&#146;s debt agreements, limit, among other things, the Corporation&#146;s
	ability to incur indebtedness, make payments on outstanding debt if such payments would cause it to
	fail to meet financial covenants, create liens on assets, sell assets, make capital expenditures,
	or engage in mergers or acquisitions.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Given the restrictions in the Corporation&#146;s debt covenants on these and other activities, the
	Corporation may be significantly limited in its operating and financial flexibility, limited in its
	ability to respond to changes in its business or competitive activities and may be restricted in
	its ability to engage in mergers, acquisitions or dispositions of assets. A failure to comply with
	these covenants, including a failure to meet the financial tests or ratios, would likely result in
	an event of default under the debt agreements and would allow the lenders to accelerate
	the debt under these agreements. If the debt is accelerated, the Corporation&#146;s assets may not
	be sufficient to repay such debt in full.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-101-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage117"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Additional Capital
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The mining, processing, development and exploration of Goldcorp&#146;s properties, may require
	substantial additional financing. Failure to obtain sufficient financing may result in delaying or
	indefinite postponement of exploration, development or production on any or all of Goldcorp&#146;s
	properties or even a loss of property interest. There can be no assurance that additional capital
	or other types of financing will be available if needed or that, if available, the terms of such
	financing will be favourable to Goldcorp. Low gold prices during the five years prior to 2002
	adversely affected Goldcorp&#146;s ability to obtain financing, and low gold, silver, copper, lead and
	zinc prices could have similar effects in the future.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Servicing Debt
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Corporation&#146;s ability to make scheduled payments of the principal of, to pay interest on
	or to refinance the indebtedness, depends on the Corporation&#146;s future performance, which is subject
	to economic, financial, competitive and other factors beyond its control. The Corporation may not
	continue to generate cash flow from operations in the future sufficient to service the debt and
	make necessary capital expenditures. If the Corporation is unable to generate such cash flow, it
	may be required to adopt one or more alternatives, such as selling assets, restructuring debt or
	obtaining additional equity capital on terms that may be onerous or highly dilutive. The
	Corporation&#146;s ability to refinance its indebtedness will depend on the capital markets and its
	financial condition at such time. The Corporation may not be able to engage in any of these
	activities or engage in these activities on desirable terms, which could result in a default on its
	debt obligations.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Pe&#241;asquito Development and Marketing Risk
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Pe&#241;asquito Project is currently nearing the conclusion of the construction stage.
	Construction and development of the project is subject to numerous risks, including, but not
	limited to, delays in obtaining equipment, material and services essential to completing
	construction of the project in a timely manner; changes in environmental or other government
	regulations; currency exchange rates; labour shortages; and fluctuation in metal prices. There can
	be no assurance that the construction will continue in accordance with current expectations or at
	all. Much of the risk has been mitigated as Pe&#241;asquito is routinely producing concentrates through
	the first of two 50,000 tonnes per day circuits. Commissioning of the second 50,000 tonne per day
	circuit is anticipated to be completed by the third quarter of 2010.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Concentrates containing combinations of gold, silver, lead and zinc will be produced in large
	quantities at Pe&#241;asquito and loaded onto highway road vehicles and/or rail cars for transport to
	in-country smelters or to sea ports for export to foreign smelters in markets such as Asia, Europe
	and North America. This type of process involves a high level of environmental and financial risk.
	Goldcorp could be subject to potential significant increases in road and maritime transportation
	charges and refinery charges. Transportation of such concentrate is also subject to numerous risks
	including, but not limited to, delays in delivery of shipments, road blocks, terrorism, weather
	conditions and environmental liabilities in the event of an accident or leak. Goldcorp could be
	subject to limited smelter availability and capacity and could also face the risk of a potential
	interruption of business from a third party beyond its control, which in both cases could have a
	material adverse affect on Goldcorp&#146;s operations and revenues. There is no assurance that
	smelting, refining or transportation contracts for the Pe&#241;asquito products will be entered into on
	acceptable terms or at all.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Labour and Employment Matters
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;While Goldcorp has good relations with both its unionized and non-unionized employees,
	production at Goldcorp&#146;s mining operations and at the Alumbrera Mine is dependant upon the efforts
	of Goldcorp&#146;s and Alumbrera&#146;s employees. In addition, relations between Goldcorp and its employees
	may be impacted by changes in the scheme of labour relations which may be introduced by the
	relevant governmental authorities in whose jurisdictions Goldcorp carries on business. Adverse
	changes in such legislation or in the relationship between Goldcorp or Alumbrera with its employees
	may have a material adverse effect on Goldcorp&#146;s business, results of
	operations and financial condition.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-102-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage118"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Land Title
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Although the title to the properties owned and proposed to be acquired by Goldcorp were
	reviewed by or on behalf of Goldcorp, no formal title opinions were delivered to Goldcorp and,
	consequently, no assurances can be given that there are no title defects affecting such properties.
	Title insurance generally is not available, and Goldcorp&#146;s ability to ensure that it has obtained
	a secure claim to individual mineral properties or mining concessions may be severely constrained.
	Goldcorp has not conducted surveys of the claims in which it holds direct or indirect interests
	and, therefore, the precise area and location of such claims may be in doubt. Accordingly,
	Goldcorp&#146;s mineral properties may be subject to prior unregistered liens, agreements, transfers or
	claims, including native land claims, and title may be affected by, among other things, undetected
	defects. In addition, Goldcorp may be unable to operate its properties as permitted or to enforce
	its rights with respect to its properties.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Portions of Goldcorp&#146;s mineral reserves come from unpatented mining claims in the United
	States. There is a risk that any of Goldcorp&#146;s unpatented mining claims could be determined to be
	invalid, in which case Goldcorp could lose the right to mine mineral reserves contained within
	those mining claims. Unpatented mining claims are created and maintained in accordance with the
	General Mining Law of 1872. Unpatented mining claims are unique United States property interests,
	and are generally considered to be subject to greater title risk than other real property interests
	due to the validity of unpatented mining claims often being uncertain. This uncertainty arises, in
	part, out of the complex federal and state laws and regulations under the General Mining Law of
	1872. Unpatented mining claims are always subject to possible challenges of third parties or
	contests by the federal government. The validity of an unpatented mining claim, in terms of both
	its location and its maintenance, is dependent on strict compliance with a complex body of federal
	and state statutory and decisional law.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In recent years, the United States Congress has considered a number of proposed amendments to
	the General Mining Law of 1872. If adopted, such legislation, among other things, could impose
	royalties on gold production from unpatented mining claims located on United States federal lands,
	result in the denial of permits to mine after the expenditure of significant funds for exploration
	and development, reduce estimates of mineral reserves and reduce the amount of future exploration
	and development activity on United States federal lands, all of which could have a material and
	adverse affect on Goldcorp&#146;s cash flow, results of operations and financial condition.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Climate Change Risks
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Goldcorp acknowledges climate change as an international and community concern. Goldcorp
	supports and endorses various initiatives for voluntary actions consistent with international
	initiatives on climate change. The Corporation is committed to reducing energy consumption and
	greenhouse gas emissions and it promotes energy efficiency at all of its operations.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition to voluntary actions, governments are moving to introduce climate change
	legislation and treaties at the international, national, state/provincial and local levels. Where
	legislation already exists, regulation relating to emission levels and energy efficiency is
	becoming more stringent. Some of the costs associated with reducing emissions can be offset by
	increased energy efficiency and technological innovation. However, if the current regulatory trend
	continues, Goldcorp expects this will result in increased costs at some of its operations.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Two initiatives of particular importance to Goldcorp are:
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>
	The Western Climate Initiative
</I>
	(&#147;WCI&#148;): The WCI is a cooperative effort of U.S. states and
	Canadian provinces (including British Columbia, Manitoba, Ontario and Quebec) that are
	collaborating to identify policies to reduce greenhouse gas (&#147;GHG&#148;) emissions, including the design
	and implementation of a regional cap-and-trade program. The design for the WCI cap-and-trade
	program is comprehensive. When it is fully implemented in 2015, the WCI program will cover up to
	90% of the GHG emissions in WCI partner states and provinces. Goldcorp will continue to monitor
	developments in the WCI and its potential impacts on operations.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In March&nbsp;2009, the USEPA released proposed rules for a mandatory GHG registry that is intended
	to cover 85-90% of the nation&#146;s GHG emissions &#150; requiring reporting from approximately 13,000
	facilities. The proposed
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-103-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage119"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	rule requires reporting from direct emitters, &#145;upstream&#146; suppliers of
	fossil fuels and GHG chemical products, industrial chemical plants, and vehicle and engine
	manufacturers, among others.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Goldcorp addresses the physical risks of climate change by ensuring that extreme weather
	conditions are included in emergency response plans as required.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>
	Sea level rise:
</I>
	Goldcorp&#146;s operations are not directly threatened by current predictions of
	sea level rise. All of the Corporation&#146;s operations are located well inland at elevations from 100
	metres to 4,000 metres above sea level. However, changes in sea levels could affect ocean
	transportation and shipping facilities which are used to transport supplies, equipment and
	personnel to Goldcorp&#146;s operations and products from those operations to world markets.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>
	Extreme weather events:
</I>
	Extreme weather events (such as increased frequency or intensity of
	hurricanes, increased snow pack, prolonged drought) have the potential to disrupt operations at the
	Corporation&#146;s mines. Where appropriate, Goldcorp&#146;s facilities have developed emergency plans for
	managing extreme weather conditions, however, extended disruptions to supply lines could result in
	interruption to production.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I>
	Resource shortages:
</I>
	Goldcorp&#146;s facilities depend on regular supplies of consumables (diesel,
	tires, etc.) and reagents to operate efficiently. In the event that the effects of climate change
	cause prolonged disruption to the delivery of essential commodities, then Goldcorp&#146;s production
	efficiency is likely to be reduced.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Goldcorp will continue to monitor the development of more energy efficient products and
	services, and will avail itself of these products and services as opportunity allows. Goldcorp
	will also continue to assess the options for the development of hydro, solar and geothermal power.
	The ability to substitute these sources of power for existing coal or gas fired generation has the
	potential for significant emissions savings.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Goldcorp will continue to assess energy efficiency opportunities across all of its operations
	with the goal of reducing both costs and greenhouse gas emissions. Goldcorp routinely collates
	data on energy use and greenhouse gas emissions. These data are reported annually in the
	Corporation&#146;s Sustainability Report and in its submission to the Carbon Disclosure Project and is
	available on the Corporation&#146;s website in May or June of each year.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Insurance and Uninsured Risks
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Goldcorp&#146;s business is subject to a number of risks and hazards generally, including adverse
	environmental conditions, industrial accidents, labour disputes, unusual or unexpected geological
	conditions, ground or slope failures, cave-ins, changes in the regulatory environment and natural
	phenomena such as inclement weather conditions, floods, hurricanes and earthquakes. Such
	occurrences could result in damage to mineral properties or production facilities, personal injury
	or death, environmental damage to Goldcorp&#146;s properties or the properties of others, delays in
	mining, monetary losses and possible legal liability.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Although Goldcorp maintains insurance to protect against certain risks in such amounts as it
	considers reasonable, its insurance will not cover all the potential risks associated with a mining
	company&#146;s operations. Goldcorp may also be unable to maintain insurance to cover these risks at
	economically feasible premiums. Insurance coverage may not continue to be available or may not be
	adequate to cover any resulting liability. Moreover, insurance against risks such as loss of title
	to mineral property, environmental pollution, or other hazards as a result of exploration and
	production is not generally available to Goldcorp or to other companies in the mining industry on
	acceptable terms. Goldcorp might also become subject to liability for pollution or other hazards
	which may not be insured against or which Goldcorp may elect not to insure against because of
	premium costs or other reasons. Losses from these events may cause Goldcorp to incur significant
	costs that could have a material adverse effect upon its financial performance and results of
	operations.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-104-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage120"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Infrastructure
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Mining, processing, development and exploration activities depend, to one degree or another,
	on adequate infrastructure. Reliable roads, bridges, power sources and water supply are important
	determinants, which affect capital and operating costs. Unusual or infrequent weather phenomena,
	sabotage, community, government or other interference in the maintenance or provision of such
	infrastructure could adversely affect Goldcorp&#146;s operations, financial condition and results of
	operations.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Joint Ventures
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Goldcorp holds an indirect 37
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 70%">
<SUP>
	1
</SUP>
</FONT>
	/
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 60%">
	2
</FONT>
	% interest in the Alumbrera Mine, the other 12.5% and 50%
	interests being held indirectly by Yamana Gold Inc. and Xstrata Plc, respectively. Goldcorp holds
	an indirect 40% interest in the Pueblo Viejo Project, an indirect
	66
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 70%">
<SUP>
	2
</SUP>
</FONT>
	/
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 60%">
	3
</FONT>
	% interest in the Marigold
	Mine and an indirect 40% interest in the South Arturo Project, the remaining interest in each of
	these properties being held indirectly by Barrick. Goldcorp&#146;s interest in these properties is
	subject to the risks normally associated with the conduct of joint ventures. The existence or
	occurrence of one or more of the following circumstances and events could have a material adverse
	impact on Goldcorp&#146;s profitability or the viability of its interests held through joint ventures,
	which could have a material adverse impact on Goldcorp&#146;s future cash flows, earnings, results of
	operations and financial condition: (i)&nbsp;disagreement with joint venture partners on how to develop
	and operate mines efficiently; (ii)&nbsp;inability of joint venture partners to meet their obligations
	to the joint venture or third parties; and (iii)&nbsp;litigation between joint venture partners
	regarding joint venture matters.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Subsidiaries
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Goldcorp is a holding company that conducts operations through Canadian and foreign (Antiguan,
	Argentinian, Barbadian, Bermudian, Cayman Island, Guatemalan, Honduran, Mexican and American)
	subsidiaries, joint ventures and divisions, and a significant portion of its assets are held in
	such entities. Accordingly, any limitation on the transfer of cash or other assets between the
	parent corporation and such entities, or among such entities, could restrict Goldcorp&#146;s ability to
	fund its operations efficiently. Any such limitations, or the perception that such limitations may
	exist now or in the future, could have an adverse impact on Goldcorp&#146;s valuation and stock price.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Market Price of the Corporation&#146;s Securities
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Common Shares and the common share purchase warrants of the Corporation (the &#147;Warrants&#148;)
	are listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange (the &#147;TSX&#148;) and the New York Stock Exchange (the &#147;NYSE&#148;).
	Securities of mining companies have experienced substantial volatility in the past, often based on
	factors unrelated to the financial performance or prospects of the companies involved. These
	factors include macroeconomic developments in North America and globally and market perceptions of
	the attractiveness of particular industries. The price of the Common Shares and the Warrants are
	also likely to be significantly affected by short-term changes in gold, silver or copper prices or
	in its financial condition or results of operations as reflected in its quarterly earnings reports.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As a result of any of these factors, the market price of the Common Shares and the Warrants at
	any given point in time may not accurately reflect Goldcorp&#146;s long-term value. Securities class
	action litigation often has been brought against companies following periods of volatility in the
	market price of their securities. Goldcorp may in the future be the target of similar litigation.
	Securities litigation could result in substantial costs and damages and divert management&#146;s
	attention and resources.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Future Sales of Common Shares by Existing Shareholders
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Sales of a large number of Common Shares in the public markets, or the potential for such
	sales, could decrease the trading price of the Common Shares and could impair Goldcorp&#146;s ability to
	raise capital through future sales of Common Shares. Goldcorp has previously completed private
	placements at prices per share which are lower than the current market price of the Common Shares.
	Accordingly, a significant number of shareholders of Goldcorp have an investment profit in the
	Common Shares that they may seek to liquidate. Substantially all of the Common Shares can be
	resold without material restriction either in the United States, in Canada or both.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-105-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage121"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Key Executives
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Goldcorp is dependent on the services of key executives, including its President and Chief
	Executive Officer, Chief Financial Officer, Chief Operating Officer and a small number of highly
	skilled and experienced executives and personnel. The loss of these persons or Goldcorp&#146;s
	inability to attract and retain additional highly skilled employees may adversely affect its
	business and future operations.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Conflicts of Interest
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Certain of the directors and officers of Goldcorp also serve as directors and/or officers of
	other companies involved in natural resource exploration and development and consequently there
	exists the possibility for such directors and officers to be in a position of conflict. Any
	decision made by any of such directors and officers involving Goldcorp will be made in accordance
	with their duties and obligations to deal fairly and in good faith with a view to the best
	interests of Goldcorp and its shareholders. In addition, each of the directors is required to
	declare and refrain from voting on any matter in which such directors may have a conflict of
	interest in accordance with the procedures set forth in the
<I>
	Business Corporations Act
</I>
	(Ontario) and
	other applicable laws.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Conversion of the Notes
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The conversion of some or all of the Notes may dilute the ownership interests of existing
	shareholders. Any sales in the public market of any of the Common Shares issuable upon such
	conversion could adversely affect prevailing market prices of the Common Shares. In addition, the
	anticipated conversion of the Notes into Common Shares or a combination of cash and Common Shares
	could depress the price of the Common Shares.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT">
<A NAME="X60364EXV99W1_HTM_123">
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 18PT">
<B>
	DIVIDENDS
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the three financial years ended December&nbsp;31, 2009, 2008 and 2007, the Corporation has
	paid monthly dividends to shareholders in the amount of $0.015 per share. On February&nbsp;28, 2005, in
	connection with the merger with Wheaton River Minerals Ltd., the Corporation paid a special
	dividend of $0.50 per share.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Although Goldcorp expects to continue paying an annual cash dividend, the timing and the
	amount of the dividends to be paid by Goldcorp will be determined by the Board of Directors of
	Goldcorp from time to time based upon, among other things, cash flow, the results of operations and
	financial condition of Goldcorp and its subsidiaries, the need for funds to finance ongoing
	operations, compliance with credit agreements and other instruments, and such other considerations
	as the Board of Directors of Goldcorp considers relevant.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT">
<A NAME="X60364EXV99W1_HTM_124">
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 18PT">
<B>
	DESCRIPTION OF CAPITAL STRUCTURE
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The authorized share capital of the Corporation consists of an unlimited number of Common
	Shares. As of March&nbsp;18, 2010, 733,855,826 Common Shares were issued and outstanding. Holders of
	Common Shares are entitled to receive notice of any meetings of shareholders of the Corporation, to
	attend and to cast one vote per Common Share at all such meetings. Holders of Common Shares do not
	have cumulative voting rights with respect to the election of directors and, accordingly, holders
	of a majority of the Common Shares entitled to vote in any election of directors may elect all
	directors standing for election. Holders of Common Shares are entitled to receive on a pro-rata
	basis such dividends, if any, as and when declared by the Corporation&#146;s board of directors at its
	discretion from funds legally available therefor and upon the liquidation, dissolution or winding
	up of the Corporation are entitled to receive on a pro-rata basis the net assets of the Corporation
	after payment of debts and other liabilities, in each case subject to the rights, privileges,
	restrictions and conditions attaching to any other series or class of shares ranking senior in
	priority to or on a pro-rata basis with the holders of Common Shares with respect to dividends or
	liquidation. The Common Shares do not carry any pre-emptive, subscription, redemption or
	conversion rights, nor do they contain any sinking or purchase fund provisions.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-106-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>

<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The price of the Common Shares as quoted by the TSX at the close of business on December&nbsp;31,
	2009 was C$41.35 and on March&nbsp;18, 2010 was C$39.82.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
	Warrants
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Warrants are listed and posted for trading on the NYSE under the symbol &#147;GGWS&#148; and on the
	TSX under the symbol &#147;G.WT.G&#148;. The following table sets forth information relating to the trading
	of the Warrants on the TSX for the months indicated.
</DIV>

<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The principal occupations of each of the Corporation&#146;s directors and executive officers
	within the past five years are disclosed in the brief biographies set forth below.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-109-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage125"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B>
<I>
	Ian
	W. Telfer &#151; Chairman of the Board and Director.
</I>
</B>
	Mr.&nbsp;Telfer was appointed Chairman of the
	Board of the Corporation effective November&nbsp;15, 2006 and was appointed Chairman of the World Gold
	Council in December 2009. Prior thereto, he was President and Chief Executive Officer of the Corporation since
	March&nbsp;17, 2005 and Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Wheaton River Minerals Ltd. prior to
	such time since September&nbsp;2001. Mr.&nbsp;Telfer has over 25&nbsp;years experience in the precious metals
	business. He has served as a director and/or officer of several Canadian and international
	companies. Mr.&nbsp;Telfer is a Chartered Accountant. He holds a Bachelor of Arts degree from the
	University of Toronto and a Masters in Business Administration from the University of Ottawa.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B>
<I>
	Douglas M. Holtby &#151; Vice Chairman of the Board and Lead Director.
</I>
</B>
	Mr.&nbsp;Holtby is the
	Vice-Chairman of the Board and Lead Director of the Corporation. He is also President and Chief
	Executive Officer of three private investment companies, Arbutus Road Investments Inc., Majick
	Capital Inc. and Holtby Capital Corporation and Chairman of the Board of Silver Wheaton Corp. From
	1974 to 1989, he was President of Allarcom Limited, from 1982 to 1989, he was President of Allarcom
	Pay Television Limited, from 1989 to 1996, he was President, Chief Executive Officer and a director
	of WIC Western International Communications Ltd. and Chairman of Canadian Satellite Communications
	Inc. and, from 1998 to 1999, he was a Trustee of ROB.TV and CKVU. He is a Fellow Chartered
	Accountant.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B>
<I>
	John P. Bell &#151; Director.
</I>
</B>
	Mr.&nbsp;John Bell was Canadian Ambassador to the Ivory Coast from 1984
	to 1987 and then Ambassador to Brazil from 1987 to 1990. He also served as High Commissioner to
	Malaysia from 1993 to 1996. Mr.&nbsp;Bell was special advisor to the Canadian Minister of Foreign
	Affairs and Head of the Canadian Delegation on environment issues during the lead-up to the Earth
	Summit in Rio de Janeiro in June&nbsp;1992, and was Canada&#146;s chief negotiator at the Earth Summit. Mr.
	Bell has been Chief Federal Negotiator for the Indian Affairs and has served on several
	not-for-profit boards of directors. Mr.&nbsp;Bell is also an independent director of Taiga Building
	Products Ltd. He holds a Bachelor of Commerce and an Honorary Doctorate of Laws from the University
	of British Columbia.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B>
<I>
	Lawrence I. Bell &#151; Director.
</I>
</B>
	Mr.&nbsp;Lawrence Bell served as the non-executive Chairman of
	British Columbia Hydro and Power Authority until December&nbsp;2007. From August&nbsp;2001 to November&nbsp;2003,
	Mr.&nbsp;Bell was Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of British Columbia Hydro and Power Authority
	and, from 1987 to 1991, he was Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of British Columbia Hydro and
	Power Authority. He is also a director of International Forest Products Limited and Silver Wheaton
	Corp. and is former Chairman of the University of British Columbia Board of Directors and former
	Chairman of Canada Line (Rapid Transit) Project. Prior to these positions, Mr.&nbsp;Bell was Chairman
	and President of the Westar Group and Chief Executive Officer of Vancouver City Savings Credit
	Union. In the province&#146;s public sector, Mr.&nbsp;Bell has served as Deputy Minister of Finance and
	Secretary to the Treasury Board. He holds a Bachelor of Arts degree and an Honours Ph.D. from the
	University of British Columbia. He also holds a Masters of Arts degree from San Jos&#233; State
	University.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B>
<I>
	Beverley A. Briscoe &#151; Director.
</I>
</B>
	Ms.&nbsp;Briscoe has been President of Briscoe Management Limited
	since 2004. From 2003 to 2007, she was Chair of the Industry Training Authority for BC, from 1997
	to 2004, she was President and owner of Hiway Refrigeration Limited, from 1994 to 1997, she was
	Vice President and General Manager of Wajax Industries Limited, from 1989 to 1994, she was Vice
	President, Finance of Rivtow Group of Companies and, from 1983 to 1989, she was Chief Financial
	Officer of various operating divisions of The Jim Pattison Group. Ms.&nbsp;Briscoe is currently a
	director of Ritchie Bros. Auctioneers Inc. She is a Fellow Chartered Accountant. She holds a
	Bachelor of Commerce degree from the University of British Columbia.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B>
<I>
	Peter J. Dey &#151; Director.
</I>
</B>
	Mr.&nbsp;Dey is a well known senior corporate executive and an
	experienced corporate director. He is Chairman of Paradigm Capital Inc., an independent investment
	dealer. He is also a director of Coventree Inc. He is a former Chairman of the Ontario Securities
	Commission and former Chairman of Morgan Stanley Canada, and he was a Senior Partner of Osler,
	Hoskin &#038; Harcourt LLP. In 1994, he chaired the Toronto Stock Exchange Committee on Corporate
	Governance, and has since been involved with developing global corporate governance standards as
	Chairman of the Private Sector Advisory Group of the Global Corporate Governance Forum. He holds a
	Masters of Laws degree from Harvard University, a Bachelor of Laws degree from Dalhousie University
	and a Bachelor of Science degree from Queen&#146;s University.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B>
<I>
	Charles A. Jeannes &#151; President, Chief Executive Officer and Director.
</I>
</B>
	Mr.&nbsp;Jeannes was
	appointed President and Chief Executive Officer of the Corporation effective January&nbsp;1, 2009. He
	previously held the role of Executive Vice President, Corporate Development of the Corporation from
	November&nbsp;2006 until December&nbsp;2008.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-110-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage126"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	From 1999 until the completion of the acquisition of Glamis, he was Executive Vice President,
	Administration, General Counsel and Secretary of Glamis. Prior to joining Glamis, Mr.&nbsp;Jeannes
	worked for Placer Dome, most recently as Vice President of Placer Dome North America. He holds a
	Bachelor of Arts degree from the University of Nevada and graduated from the University of Arizona
	School of Law with honours in 1983. He practiced law from 1982 until 1994 and has broad experience
	in mining transactions, public and private financing, permitting and international regulation.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B>
<I>
	P.&nbsp;Randy Reifel &#151; Director.
</I>
</B>
	Mr.&nbsp;Reifel is President and a director of Chesapeake Gold Corp.
	that explores for precious metals in Mexico and Central America. Mr.&nbsp;Reifel was appointed to the
	Board in November&nbsp;2006. Prior thereto, he had been a director of Glamis since June&nbsp;2002 following
	the acquisition of Francisco Gold Corp. In 1993, Mr.&nbsp;Reifel founded and served as President and a
	director of Francisco Gold Corp. which discovered the El Sauzal gold deposit in Mexico and the
	Marlin gold deposit in Guatemala. Mr.&nbsp;Reifel holds a Bachelor of Commerce degree and a Masters of
	Science degree in Business Administration from the University of British Columbia.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B>
<I>
	A.&nbsp;Dan Rovig &#151; Director.
</I>
</B>
	Mr.&nbsp;Rovig was appointed to the Board in November&nbsp;2006. Prior
	thereto, he had been a director and Chairman of the Board of Glamis since November&nbsp;1998. Before
	his appointment as Chairman, Mr.&nbsp;Rovig served first as President of Glamis from September&nbsp;1998
	until his appointment as a director and the President and Chief Executive Officer of Glamis and its
	subsidiaries from November&nbsp;1989 to August&nbsp;1997 when he retired. Prior to 1988, Mr.&nbsp;Rovig was an
	executive officer of British Petroleum Ltd., including its subsidiaries Amselco Minerals Inc. and
	BP Minerals America for five years. He holds a Bachelor of Science in Mining Engineering, a
	Masters of Science in Mineral Dressing Engineering from Montana College of Mineral Science and
	Technology and a Doctor of Science (honoris causa) from Montana Tech of the University of Montana.
	He is also a registered member of the Society for Mining, Metallurgy and Exploration, and the
	Geological Society of Nevada.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B>
<I>
	Kenneth F. Williamson &#151; Director.
</I>
</B>
	Mr.&nbsp;Williamson was appointed to the Board in November&nbsp;2006.
	Prior thereto, he had been a director of Glamis since 1999. He was Vice-Chairman, Investment
	Banking at Midland Walwyn/Merrill Lynch Canada Inc. from 1993 to 1998. He has worked in the
	securities industry for more than 25&nbsp;years, concentrating on financial services and the natural
	resource industries in the United States and Europe. Mr.&nbsp;Williamson is a director of a number of
	companies in the natural resource sector. He holds a Bachelor of Applied Science (P.Eng.) degree
	from the University of Toronto and a Masters in Business Administration from the University of
	Western Ontario.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B>
<I>
	Lindsay A. Hall &#151; Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
</I>
</B>
	Mr.&nbsp;Hall was
	appointed Chief Financial Officer and Executive Vice President of the Corporation on April&nbsp;19, 2006
	and March&nbsp;3, 2006, respectively. He is the former Executive Vice President and Chief Financial
	Officer of Placer Dome. Mr.&nbsp;Hall is a Chartered Accountant with strong financial credentials,
	which include being Vice President of Finance at West Coast Energy, Chief Financial Officer of Duke
	Energy Americas in Houston, and Treasurer of Duke Energy Inc.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B>
<I>
	Steve P. Reid &#151; Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer.
</I>
</B>
	Mr.&nbsp;Reid was appointed
	Chief Operating Officer of the Corporation effective January&nbsp;1, 2007 and, prior thereto, Executive
	Vice President, Canada and USA effective concurrently with the completion of the acquisition of
	Placer Dome (CLA)&nbsp;Limited. Mr.&nbsp;Reid is a mining engineer with 30&nbsp;years of extensive international
	experience in both the operating and business aspects of the mining industry. Prior to joining
	Goldcorp, he worked for Placer Dome as the Country Manager for the Canadian operations. He spent a
	total of 13&nbsp;years working for Placer Dome, holding numerous corporate, mine management and
	operating roles worldwide. Mr.&nbsp;Reid has also worked in leadership positions for Kingsgate
	Consolidated and Newcrest Mining Limited, where he was responsible for running operations
	throughout Asia and Australia.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B>
<I>
	Timo Jauristo &#151; Vice President, Corporate Development.
</I>
</B>
	Mr.&nbsp;Jauristo was appointed Vice
	President, Corporate Development of the Corporation effective June&nbsp;16, 2009. Mr.&nbsp;Jauristo is a
	geologist with over 30&nbsp;years of international experience in the mining industry in gold, base
	metals and uranium. He spent 15&nbsp;years with Placer Dome in various operating and corporate roles in
	exploration in Australia and Asia and in business development. Mr.&nbsp;Jauristo was involved in
	numerous merger and acquisition transactions in many of the major gold producing regions of the
	world. Between leaving Placer Dome in 2005 and joining Goldcorp in 2009, Mr.&nbsp;Jauristo was the Chief
	Executive Officer of Zincore Metals Inc. from November&nbsp;2006 to
	May&nbsp;2009 and was the Chief Executive Officer of Southwestern Resources Corp. from September&nbsp;2007 to May&nbsp;2009, both junior mining
	companies with exploration and development assets mostly in Peru.
</DIV>

<B>
<I>
	George Burns &#151; Vice President, Canada and United States.
</I>
</B>
	Mr.&nbsp;Burns was appointed Vice
	President, Canada and United States of the Corporation effective August&nbsp;8, 2007. Mr.&nbsp;Burns has
	over 31&nbsp;years of experience in the mineral sector, including executive, operations, development and
	engineering leadership roles in gold, copper and coal operations. Prior to joining the
	Corporation, Mr.&nbsp;Burns was Vice President and Chief Operating Officer of Centerra Gold Inc. Mr.
	Burns served in various capacities for Asarco, including Vice President of Mining as well as
	numerous capacities for Cyprus Minerals Corporation and he began his career with the Anaconda
	Company in 1978. Mr.&nbsp;Burns received a Bachelor of Science degree in Mining Engineering from the
	Montana College of Mineral Science and Technology in 1982.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B>
<I>
	Salvador Garcia &#151; Vice President, Mexico.
</I>
</B>
	Mr.&nbsp;Garcia was appointed Vice President, Mexico on
	May&nbsp;20, 2008. Since February&nbsp;2007 he has held the role as Director of Goldcorp Mexico and was
	Director General for the Mexico region until May&nbsp;2008. Mr.&nbsp;Garcia has held several positions at
	Luismin since 1986, including Mine Supervisor at San Dimas District, Mine Superintendent, Assistant
	Manager, and San Dimas Manager. Prior to this, he worked as Chief Mine Production in San Martin,
	Zacatecas for Industrial Minera Mexico (Grupo Mexico) until 1985. He received his B.S. in Mining
	Engineering from the University of Guanajuato in 1978. Mr.&nbsp;Garcia is a member of the Mexican
	Mining Engineers, Metallurgists and Geologists Association and a member of the Board of the Mexican
	Mining Chamber.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B>
<I>
	Eduardo Villacorta &#151; Vice President, Central and South America.
</I>
</B>
	Mr.&nbsp;Villacorta was appointed
	Vice President, Central and South America effective December&nbsp;1, 2009. Mr.&nbsp;Villacorta has been
	involved with Goldcorp&#146;s Central American businesses at Marlin, San Mart&#237;n and Cerro Blanco for
	more than nine years. He went to law school at the National University of Honduras (UNAH), with an
	emphasis on corporate law and has taken several training programs on management and negotiations.
	As a member of Abogados y Asesores Corporativos S.A.C., a law firm in Honduras, he worked for
	several mining companies in the country, one of them being Glamis which he joined in 2001 as
	General Manager of the San Mart&#237;n Mine. Prior to his actual position, Mr.&nbsp;Villacorta was the
	Executive Director for the region
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B>
<I>
	John Allan &#151; Vice President, Sustainable Development.
</I>
</B>
	Mr.&nbsp;Allan was appointed Vice President,
	Sustainable Development of the Corporation effective March&nbsp;7, 2007. Mr.&nbsp;Allan is an environmental
	scientist with 28&nbsp;years experience in various environmental roles in the mining industry. Prior to
	joining the Corporation, he held the position of Group Manager, Environment with Newcrest Mining
	Limited for a period of eight years. He has held senior environmental roles with RGC Limited and
	Rio Tinto, being responsible for environmental performance of operations in Australia, South East
	Asia and North America.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B>
<I>
	Dina Aloi &#151; Vice President, Corporate Social Responsibility.
</I>
</B>
	Ms.&nbsp;Aloi was appointed Vice
	President, Corporate Social Responsibility of the Corporation effective March&nbsp;16, 2009. Prior to
	joining Goldcorp, Ms.&nbsp;Aloi was the Global Director of the Social Impact Management practice at
	Hatch Ltd., a major engineering consulting firm since January&nbsp;2006. From January&nbsp;2005 to January
	2006, Ms.&nbsp;Aloi was an independent international development consultant, following 15&nbsp;years of
	service with non-governmental organizations focused on development, war zones, displaced
	populations and child soldiers. Ms.&nbsp;Aloi holds a Bachelor of Arts in Rural Sociology from Cornell
	University, a Master of Arts in Social Anthropology and a Graduate Diploma in Refugee and Migration
	Studies from York University.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">

<B>
<I>
	Gerard Atkinson &#151; Vice President, Human Resources.
</I>
</B>
	Mr.&nbsp;Atkinson joined the Corporation in May
	2006 and was appointed Vice President, Human Resources, Corporate and Canada of the Corporation
	effective May&nbsp;2, 2007. Mr.&nbsp;Atkinson has 20&nbsp;years experience in senior human resources roles in the
	mining industry and in the oil and gas industry with Duke Energy Gas Transmission and Trans Canada
	Pipelines. Mr.&nbsp;Atkinson holds a Bachelor of Commerce degree from the University of Durham in
	England.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">

<B>
<I>
	David L. Deisley &#151; Vice President, General Counsel.
</I>
</B>

	the mining industry. From April&nbsp;2000 to August&nbsp;2007, Mr.&nbsp;Deisley was employed by Barrick or one of
	its subsidiaries as legal counsel in Chile (2000 to 2002) and the United States (2003 to 2007).
	Immediately prior to joining Goldcorp in September&nbsp;2007, Mr.&nbsp;Deisley was employed as Regional
	Counsel, North America by Barrick Gold of North America, Inc. Prior to joining Barrick, Mr.&nbsp;Deisley was a partner with Parsons Behle &#038;
	Latimer where he served as head of the firm&#146;s natural resource and environmental practice group for
	five years.
</DIV>

	Inc.), ultimately as Director of Corporate Accounting. Ms.&nbsp;Louie is a Chartered Accountant and

	Project Development on October&nbsp;30, 2008. Prior thereto, he served as the Vice President, Chief
	Operating Officer, Luismin, Mexico from May&nbsp;2007 to October&nbsp;2008. From August&nbsp;2006 until the
	completion of the acquisition of Glamis, Mr.&nbsp;Olson was Vice President, Director, Mexican Operations
	of Glamis. He has a Bachelor of Science degree in Metallurgical Engineering and a Masters of
	Science degree in Mining Engineering from the University of Idaho. Prior to joining Glamis, from
	2001 to August&nbsp;2006, Mr.&nbsp;Olson was Vice President, General Manager for Coeur d&#146;Alene Mines Corp. at
	its Rochester mine and Senior Vice President, Operations for mines in Chile and Argentina. Mr.
	Olson has extensive experience in design, construction and managing mines in Nevada, California,
	Chile and Argentina.

</I>

	March&nbsp;2006 and was appointed Vice President, Information Technology of the Corporation effective
	May&nbsp;2, 2007. Mr.&nbsp;Olson is responsible for providing strategic direction, guidance and leadership
	in the area of information technology to all of Goldcorp&#146;s operations. Prior to joining the
	Corporation, he spent seven years with Deloitte &#038; Touche LLP in an information technology
	consulting role, and 10&nbsp;years with Teck Cominco Limited as a mine controller where his
	responsibilities included information technology at specific mine sites.

	acquisition of Glamis, Mr.&nbsp;Ronkos worked most recently as Vice President, Exploration of Glamis.

	Corporation effective November&nbsp;15, 2006, having joined the Corporation in July&nbsp;2006. He is
	responsible for global tax planning, tax-related support of corporate development and finance
	activities and tax compliance. Before joining the Corporation, Mr.&nbsp;Ruus was Vice President,
	Taxation for Placer Dome where he played leading tax roles for 10&nbsp;years. Prior to this he spent 14

	President, Risk Management on January&nbsp;1, 2007 and subsequently appointed Vice President, Metals
	Marketing in May&nbsp;2008. From 2000 until the completion of the acquisition of Glamis, Ms.&nbsp;Sedestrom
	served as Vice President, Finance, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer of Glamis. Ms.&nbsp;Sedestrom

	science, both from the University of Michigan. Ms.&nbsp;Sedestrom has over 20&nbsp;years of experience in
	the mining and mining-related industries with Glamis, Goldman Sachs &#038; Co., including the J. Aron
	commodity-trading division.

</I>

	appointed Vice President, Regulatory Affairs on May&nbsp;20, 2008. Prior thereto, she served as
	Director, Regulatory Compliance from August&nbsp;2007 to May&nbsp;2008, was appointed Corporate Secretary on
	May&nbsp;2, 2007 and served as Director, Legal and Assistant Corporate Secretary from August&nbsp;15, 2005 to
	May&nbsp;2, 2007. Ms.&nbsp;Tudela has more than 20&nbsp;years of experience in the securities and corporate
	finance areas. She is a member of the Forum for Women Entrepreneurs BC and the Institute of
	Corporate Directors. Prior to joining Goldcorp, Ms.&nbsp;Tudela worked in the Securities and Corporate
	Finance Department of Davis LLP. Ms.&nbsp;Tudela was Corporate Secretary of Diamond Fields Resources
	Inc. from 1995 to 1996 and Director, Legal and Assistant Corporate Secretary of Silver Wheaton from
	July&nbsp;2005 to October&nbsp;2007.

	Jeffrey Wilhoit &#151; Vice President, Investor Relations.
</I>
</B>
	Mr.&nbsp;Wilhoit was appointed Vice
	President, Investor Relations of the Corporation effective January&nbsp;1, 2007. From November&nbsp;2005
	until the completion of the acquisition of Glamis, Mr.&nbsp;Wilhoit served as Director, Investor
	Relations of Glamis. Prior thereto, from November&nbsp;1996 to November&nbsp;2005, Mr.&nbsp;Wilhoit served as

<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Directors are elected at each annual meeting of Goldcorp&#146;s shareholders and serve as such
	until the next annual meeting or until their successors are elected or appointed.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
	at March&nbsp;18, 2010, the directors and executive officers of Goldcorp, as a group,
	beneficially owned, directly or indirectly, or exercised control or direction over 5,074,302 Common
	Shares, representing less than one percent of the total number of Common Shares outstanding before
	giving effect to the exercise of options or warrants to purchase Common Shares held by such
	directors and executive officers. The statement as to the number of Common Shares beneficially
	owned, directly or indirectly, or over which control or direction is exercised by the directors and
	executive officers of Goldcorp as a group is based upon information furnished by the directors and
	executive officers.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
	Cease Trade Orders, Bankruptcies, Penalties and Sanctions
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;No director or executive officer of the Corporation is, or within ten years prior to the date
	hereof has been, a director, chief executive officer or chief financial officer of any company
	(including the Corporation) that, (i)&nbsp;was subject to a cease trade order, an order similar to a
	cease trade order or an order that denied the relevant company access to any exemption under
	securities legislation, that was in effect for a period of more than 30 consecutive
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-114-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage130"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	days, that was issued while the director or executive officer was acting in the capacity as
	director, chief executive officer or chief financial officer; or (ii)&nbsp;was subject to a cease trade
	order, an order similar to a cease trade order or an order that denied the relevant company access
	to any exemption under securities legislation, that was in effect for a period of more than 30
	consecutive days, that was issued after the director or executive officer ceased to be a director,
	chief executive officer or chief financial officer and which resulted from an event that occurred
	while that person was acting in the capacity as director, chief executive officer or chief
	financial officer.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;No director or executive officer of the Corporation, or a shareholder holding a sufficient
	number of securities of the Corporation to affect materially control of the Corporation, (i)&nbsp;is, or
	within ten years prior to the date hereof has been, a director or executive officer of any company
	(including the Corporation) that, while that person was acting in that capacity, or within a year
	of that person ceasing to act in that capacity, became bankrupt, made a proposal under any
	legislation relating to bankruptcy or insolvency or was subject to or instituted any proceedings,
	arrangement or compromise with creditors or had a receiver, receiver manager or trustee appointed
	to hold its assets, other than Ian Telfer who was Vice Chairman of a technology company when it
	made an assignment in bankruptcy on July&nbsp;31, 2001; or (ii)&nbsp;has, within ten years prior to the date
	hereof, become bankrupt, made a proposal under any legislation relating to bankruptcy or
	insolvency, or become subject to or instituted any proceedings, arrangement or compromise with
	creditors, or had a receiver, receiver manager or trustee appointed to hold the assets of the
	director, executive officer or shareholder.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;No director or executive officer of the Corporation, or a shareholder holding a sufficient
	number of securities of the Corporation to affect materially the control of the Corporation, has
	been subject to (i)&nbsp;any penalties or sanctions imposed by a court relating to securities
	legislation or by a securities regulatory authority or has entered into a settlement agreement with
	a securities regulatory authority; or (ii)&nbsp;any other penalties or sanctions imposed by a court or
	regulatory body that would likely be considered important to a reasonable investor in making an
	investment decision.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
	Conflicts of Interest
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;To the best of Goldcorp&#146;s knowledge, and other than as disclosed in this annual information
	form, there are no known existing or potential conflicts of interest between Goldcorp and any
	director or officer of Goldcorp, except that certain of the directors and officers serve as
	directors and officers of other public companies, specifically Silver Wheaton Corp. and Uranium One
	Inc., and therefore it is possible that a conflict may arise between their duties as a director or
	officer of Goldcorp and their duties as a director or officer of such other companies. See &#147;Risk
	Factors &#151; Conflicts of Interest&#148;.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT">
<A NAME="X60364EXV99W1_HTM_127">
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 18PT">
<B>
	LEGAL PROCEEDINGS AND REGULATORY ACTIONS
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On January&nbsp;13, 2010, the Corporation received a statement of claim filed by Barrick in the
	Ontario Superior Court of Justice, against the Corporation, New Gold, and their affiliated
	subsidiaries, relating to the exercise of the right of first refusal by a New Gold subsidiary in
	respect of Xstrata Copper Chile S.A.&#146;s interest in the El Morro Project, as described above under
	the heading &#147;General Development of the Business &#150; Acquisition of 70% Interest in El Morro
	Project&#148;. Among the relief requested by Barrick is that the El Morro Project be held in trust for
	the benefit of Barrick. On February&nbsp;26, 2010, Barrick delivered a motion seeking leave to amend its
	statement of claim to add Xstrata Chile, Xstrata Canada and El Morro as defendants. In the amended
	statement of claim, Barrick asserts additional claims against Xstrata Chile for breach of the
	Barrick sale agreement and breach of the duty of good faith in the performance of its contractual
	obligations and adds Xstrata Canada as a defendant to the existing tort claims. To date, several
	scheduling conferences have been held, but no case schedule has been ordered, nor has Barrick&#146;s
	pending motion seeking leave to amend its statement of claim been set for hearing. The next
	scheduling conference is set for March&nbsp;24, 2010. Goldcorp is confident that it has acted lawfully
	and appropriately in all aspects of this transaction and intends to defend itself against the
	claim.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In addition to the litigation brought by Barrick described above, the
	Corporation is, from time to time, involved in various claims, legal proceedings and
	complaints arising in the ordinary course of business. The Corporation cannot reasonably predict
	the likelihood or outcome of these actions. Goldcorp does not believe that adverse decisions in any
	other pending or threatened proceedings related to any matter, or any amount which may be required to be paid by reason therein, will have a material effect on
	the financial condition or future results of operations of the Corporation.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-115-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>

<A NAME="eolPage131"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT">
<A NAME="X60364EXV99W1_HTM_128">
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 18PT">
<B>
	INTEREST OF MANAGEMENT AND OTHERS IN MATERIAL TRANSACTIONS
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other than as described below and elsewhere in this annual information form, since January&nbsp;1,
	2007, no director, executive officer or 10% shareholder of the Corporation or any associate or
	affiliate of any such person or company, has or had any material interest, direct or indirect, in
	any transaction that has materially affected or will materially affect the Corporation or any of
	its subsidiaries.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In April&nbsp;2007, the Corporation completed the sale of the Amapari Mine and the Peak Mines to
	Peak Gold. As a result of the sale, Goldcorp became a holder of approximately 22% of the then
	outstanding common shares of Peak Gold. In connection with the transaction, Julio Carvalho, the
	Corporation&#146;s former Executive Vice President, Central and South America, was appointed President
	and Chief Executive Officer of Peak Gold and Ian Telfer, the Corporation&#146;s Chairman of the Board,
	was appointed as a director of Peak Gold. See &#147;General Development of the Business &#151; Sale of
	Amapari and Peak Mines&#148; for further details.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In July&nbsp;2007, the Corporation completed the sale to Silver Wheaton of 25% of the life of mine
	silver production from the Pe&#241;asquito Project for a cash payment of $485&nbsp;million. Eduardo Luna,
	former Executive Vice President of the Corporation, is Chairman of the board of directors of Silver
	Wheaton and each of Lawrence I. Bell and Douglas M. Holtby are directors of both the Corporation
	and Silver Wheaton. See &#147;General Development of the Business &#151; Sale of 25% of Life of Mine Silver
	Production from Pe&#241;asquito Project&#148; for further details.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In February&nbsp;2008, the Corporation completed the sale of its 108&nbsp;million common shares of
	Silver Wheaton for aggregate gross proceeds to the Corporation of C$1.566&nbsp;billion. This
	represented the sale of all of the Corporation&#146;s remaining interest in Silver Wheaton. Each of
	Lawrence I. Bell and Douglas M. Holtby are directors of both the Corporation and Silver Wheaton.
	See &#147;General Development of the Business &#151; Sale of Silver Wheaton Shares&#148; for further details.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT">
<A NAME="X60364EXV99W1_HTM_129">

	TRANSFER AGENT AND REGISTRAR

	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The transfer agent and registrar for the Common Shares in Canada is CIBC Mellon Trust Company
	at its principal offices in Vancouver, British Columbia and Toronto, Ontario. The co-transfer
	agent and registrar for the Common Shares in the United States is Mellon Investor Services LLC at
	its principal offices in Jersey City, New Jersey.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The warrant agent for the Warrants is CIBC Mellon Trust Company at its principal offices in
	Vancouver, British Columbia and Toronto, Ontario. The co-transfer agent and registrar for the
	Warrants in the United States is Mellon Investor Services LLC at its principal offices in Jersey
	City, New Jersey.

<A NAME="X60364EXV99W1_HTM_132">

</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 18PT">
<B>
	AUDIT COMMITTEE
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Corporation&#146;s Audit Committee is responsible for monitoring the Corporation&#146;s systems and
	procedures for financial reporting and internal control, reviewing certain public disclosure
	documents and monitoring the performance and independence of the Corporation&#146;s external auditors.
	The Audit Committee is also responsible for reviewing the Corporation&#146;s annual audited consolidated
	financial statements, unaudited interim consolidated financial statements and management&#146;s
	discussion and analysis of financial results of operations for both annual and interim consolidated
	financial statements and review of related operations prior to their approval by the full board of
	directors of the Corporation.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Audit Committee&#146;s charter sets out its responsibilities and duties, qualifications for
	membership, procedures for committee member removal and appointments and reporting to the
	Corporation&#146;s board of directors. A copy of the charter is attached hereto as Schedule &#147;A&#148;.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The members of the Corporation&#146;s current Audit Committee are Beverley Briscoe (Chair),
	Lawrence I. Bell, A. Dan Rovig and Kenneth F. Williamson. Each of Ms.&nbsp;Briscoe and Messrs.&nbsp;Bell,
	Rovig and Williamson are independent and financially literate within the meaning of Multilateral
	Instrument 52-110
<I>
	Audit Committees
</I>
	(&#147;MI 52-110&#148;). In addition to being independent directors as
	described above, all members of the Audit Committee must meet an additional &#147;independence&#148; test
	under MI 52-110 in that their directors&#146; fees are the only compensation they, or their firms,
	receive from the Corporation and that they are not affiliated with
	the Corporation. The meaning of independence under MI 52-110 is set out in Schedule &#147;A&#148; to the Audit Committee&#146;s charter.
</DIV>

	-118-
<!-- /FOLIO -->

<P>
<A NAME="eolPage134"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Audit Committee met five times in 2009. Each of Lawrence I. Bell, Beverley A. Briscoe, A.
	Dan Rovig and Kenneth F. Williamson were present at all five meetings.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
	Relevant Education and Experience
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Set out below is a description of the education and experience of each audit committee member
	that is relevant to the performance of his or her responsibilities as an audit committee member:
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 2%">
<B>
<I>
	Beverley A. Briscoe &#151;
</I>
</B>
	Ms.&nbsp;Briscoe has been President of Briscoe Management Limited
	since 2004. From 2003 to 2007, she was Chair of the Industry Training Authority for BC,
	from 1997 to 2004, she was President and owner of Hiway Refrigeration Limited, from 1994 to
	1997, she was Vice President and General Manager of Wajax Industries Limited, from 1989 to
	1994, she was Vice President, Finance of Rivtow Group of Companies and, from 1983 to 1989,
	she was Chief Financial Officer of various operating divisions of The Jim Pattison Group.
	Ms.&nbsp;Briscoe is currently a director of Ritchie Bros. Auctioneers Inc. She is a Fellow
	Chartered Accountant. She holds a Bachelor of Commerce degree from the University of
	British Columbia.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 2%">
<B>
<I>
	Lawrence I. Bell &#151;
</I>
</B>
	Mr.&nbsp;Lawrence Bell served as the non-executive Chairman of British
	Columbia Hydro and Power Authority until December&nbsp;2007. From August&nbsp;2001 to November&nbsp;2003,
	Mr.&nbsp;Bell was Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of British Columbia Hydro and Power
	Authority and, from 1987 to 1991, he was Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of British
	Columbia Hydro and Power Authority. He is also a director of International Forest Products
	Limited and Silver Wheaton Corp. and is former Chairman of the University of British
	Columbia Board of Directors and former Chairman of Canada Line (Rapid Transit) Project.
	Prior to these positions, Mr.&nbsp;Bell was Chairman and President of the Westar Group and Chief
	Executive Officer of Vancouver City Savings Credit Union. In the province&#146;s public sector,
	Mr.&nbsp;Bell has served as Deputy Minister of Finance and Secretary to the Treasury Board. He
	holds a Bachelor of Arts degree and an Honours Ph.D. from the University of British
	Columbia. He also holds a Masters of Arts degree from San Jos&#233; State University.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 2%">
<B>
<I>
	A. Dan Rovig &#151;
</I>
</B>
	Mr.&nbsp;Rovig was appointed to the Board in November&nbsp;2006. Prior thereto,
	he had been a director and Chairman of the Board of Glamis since November&nbsp;1998. Before his
	appointment as Chairman, Mr.&nbsp;Rovig served first as President of Glamis from September&nbsp;1998
	until his appointment as a director and the President and Chief Executive Officer of Glamis
	and its subsidiaries from November&nbsp;1989 to August&nbsp;1997 when he retired. Prior to 1988, Mr.
	Rovig was an executive officer of British Petroleum Ltd., including its subsidiaries Amselco
	Minerals Inc. and BP Minerals America for five years. He holds a Bachelor of Science in
	Mining Engineering, a Masters of Science in Mineral Dressing Engineering from Montana
	College of Mineral Science and Technology and a Doctor of Science (honoris causa) from
	Montana Tech of the University of Montana. He is also a registered member of the Society
	for Mining, Metallurgy and Exploration, and the Geological Society of Nevada.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 2%">
<B>
<I>
	Kenneth F. Williamson &#151;
</I>
</B>
	Mr.&nbsp;Williamson was appointed to the Board in November&nbsp;2006.
	Prior thereto, he had been a director of Glamis since 1999. He was Vice-Chairman,
	Investment Banking at Midland Walwyn/Merrill Lynch Canada Inc. from 1993 to 1998. He has
	worked in the securities industry for more than 25&nbsp;years, concentrating on financial
	services and the natural resource industries in the United States and Europe. Mr.
	Williamson is a director of a number of companies in the natural resource sector. He holds
	a Bachelor of Applied Science (P.Eng.) degree from the University of Toronto and a Masters
	in Business Administration from the University of Western Ontario.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
	Pre-Approval Policies and Procedures
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Audit Committee&#146;s charter sets out responsibilities regarding the provision of non-audit
	services by the Corporation&#146;s independent registered chartered accountants. This policy encourages
	consideration of whether the provision of services other than audit services is compatible with
	maintaining the auditor&#146;s independence and requires Audit Committee pre-approval of permitted audit
	and audit-related services.
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	-119-
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage135"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF">
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
	External Auditor Service Fees
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
<B>
<I>
	Audit Fees
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The aggregate audit fees billed by the Corporation&#146;s independent registered chartered
	accountants for the financial year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009 were $5,502,300 (for the financial year
	ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 &#150; $5,537,600).
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Audit-Related Fees
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The aggregate audit-related fees billed by the Corporation&#146;s independent registered chartered
	accountants for the financial year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009 were $401,100 (for the financial year
	ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 &#150; $60,700).
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	Tax Fees
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The aggregate tax fees in respect of tax compliance, tax advice and tax planning billed by the
	Corporation&#146;s independent registered chartered accountants for the financial year ended December
	31, 2009 were $483,800 (for the financial year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 &#150; $194,700).
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
<I>
	All Other Fees
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The aggregate non-audit fees billed by the Corporation&#146;s independent registered chartered
	accountants for the financial year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009 were $Nil (for the financial year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2008 &#150; $Nil).
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 12PT">
<B>
	Auditor Partner Rotation
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As a registrant with the United States Securities and Exchange Commission, the signing
	Deloitte audit partner and the engagement quality control partner cannot serve in those roles on
	the Goldcorp audit team for more than five consecutive years. Deloitte audit partners of Goldcorp
	subsidiaries whose assets or revenues constitute 20% or more of the assets or revenues of
	Goldcorp&#146;s respective consolidated assets or revenues cannot serve in this role for more than seven
	consecutive years.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT">
<A NAME="X60364EXV99W1_HTM_133">
</A>
</DIV>

</DIV>

</I>
</U>
	. Additional information,
	including directors&#146; and officers&#146; remuneration and indebtedness, principal holders of the
	Corporation&#146;s securities and securities authorized for issuance under equity compensation plans is
	contained in the management information circular of the Corporation dated March&nbsp;26, 2010 which will
	be available on SEDAR at
<U>
<I>

</I>
</U>
	. Additional financial information is provided in
	the Corporation&#146;s audited consolidated financial statements and management&#146;s discussion and
	analysis for the financial year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009.
