<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF; MARGIN-LEFT: .25IN; WIDTH: 7.20IN">
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	(in United States dollars, tabular amounts in millions, except where noted)
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<I>
	Related to the processing facilities
</I>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	&#149;
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	Commissioning of the primary crusher commenced early in the second quarter of 2009 with the
	first material crushed and conveyed on April&nbsp;10, 2009.
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	&#149;
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	The Line 1 grinding, flotation and filtration circuits, including the reagents warehouse,
	were commissioned during the third quarter of 2009 and are now fully operational. The first
	concentrates were produced in October&nbsp;2009 and as of February&nbsp;28, 2010, 11,486 Dry Metric
	Tonnes (&#147;DMT&#148;) of lead concentrates and 16,116 DMT of zinc concentrates had been produced and
	accepted by customers, with qualities that meet commercial specifications.
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	&#149;
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	Construction efforts are now focused on Line 2 with the mills set in place, installation of
	mill motors in progress and erection of flotation cells on-going. Remaining parts for the
	mills are on site. Steel erection continues in the grinding and lead flotation areas, while
	concrete work continues in the lead and zinc re-grind areas.
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	&#149;
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	The permit for water requirements to support full production throughout the life of mine
	was received. The Torres and El Vergel well-fields are now fully operational and capable of
	being controlled remotely. At December&nbsp;31, 2009, sufficient water was stored for on-going mill
	operation.
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<I>
	Related to the exploration activities
</I>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	&#149;
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	During 2009, activities at the site were focused on defining the south sediments of the
	Chile Colorado pit as well as condemnation drilling and geotechnical drilling around the
	Pe&#241;asco pit. Further drilling for the deeper manto targets was initiated.
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	&#149;
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	Regional exploration was focused on several targets, with the majority of effort focused on
	Noche Buena, and drilling in the Mazapil Valley and El Quemado.
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	&#149;
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	The Noche Buena project is a mid-stage exploration project located in north-eastern
	Zacatecas state, four kilometers north of the Pe&#241;asquito project. The Noche Buena property
	comprises some twenty-four square kilometers and is contiguous with the northern border of the
	Pe&#241;asquito land position. Historic mining has occurred on the property with the last
	production being around 1990. In-fill drilling of oxide ore and continued testing of sulphide
	systems remain a key focus of exploration efforts. Measured and indicated resources at
	December&nbsp;31, 2009 totaled 0.5&nbsp;million ounces of gold and 18.4&nbsp;million ounces of silver.
	Inferred resources totaled 0.2&nbsp;million ounces of gold and 2.0&nbsp;million ounces of silver.
	Current resources support the potential for a low-cost satellite heap leach operation in the
	Pe&#241;asquito district.
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	GOLDCORP&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;33
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	&nbsp;
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	&nbsp;
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage176"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF; MARGIN-LEFT: .25IN; WIDTH: 7.20IN">
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	(in United States dollars, tabular amounts in millions, except where noted)
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<B>
	&#201;l&#233;onore Project, Canada
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<I>
	The &#201;l&#233;onore Project is located in the north-east corner of the Opinaca Reservoir in the James Bay
	region of Qu&#233;bec, Canada. The &#201;l&#233;onore deposit is a major new gold discovery in a relatively
	unexplored area in the Province of 9u&#233;bec, located in the core of what Goldcorp believes to be a
	promising new gold district in North America. As of December&nbsp;31, 2009, the deposit contained 3.2
	million ounces of indicated gold resources at an average grade of 11.92 grams per tonne and 6.3
	million ounces of inferred gold resources at an average grade of 12.93 grams per tonne.
</I>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	Exploration drilling during 2009 focused on better defining and understanding the deposit and high
	grade potential of the ore body, including the potential high grade blocks between the elevations
	500 and 900 meters from surface, and concentrated on the deep, north and south extensions of the
	deposit. Positive drilling results along with geological interpretation and modeling continue to
	define the high grade core and plunge of the deposit.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	In preparation for the sinking of a 725 meter deep exploration shaft to commence in 2010, access to
	the site was enhanced during 2009 through the construction of a winter road and a temporary
	airstrip. Site accommodation and support infrastructure was also enhanced for this work.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	A recently completed pre-feasibility study for the &#201;l&#233;onore project in Quebec has confirmed
	management&#146;s expectation for a long-lived underground gold mine with strong, sustained production
	at low cash costs. Over a 16-year mine life expected to commence in 2015, annual gold production is
	expected to average approximately 330,000 ounces at cash costs below $400 per ounce based upon an
	average mined grade of over 10 grams per tonne and a daily processing rate of 3,000 tonnes per
	day.&nbsp;The initial capital expenditure for the project is expected to total approximately $800
	million.&nbsp;Project expenditures of approximately $95&nbsp;million are expected in 2010.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	The pre-feasibility study is based on the 2008 reserve and resource update.&nbsp;The significant
	increase in inferred gold resources as reported in the Company&#146;s 2009 reserve and resource
	statement is being incorporated into the study, as are additional opportunities to optimize the
	project. Drilling of the deposit has identified a deep zone of high grade gold mineralization to
	the north of the Roberto zone, and scoping efforts have focused on accessing this high grade
	material earlier in the mine life to further enhance project economics. No production from &#201;l&#233;onore
	is currently included in the Company&#146;s five-year 57% growth profile.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	Collar excavation for the exploration shaft is expected to commence during the first quarter of
	2010, with sinking completed in the third quarter of 2012.&nbsp;Based upon work to be completed in 2010,
	a construction decision on the &#201;l&#233;onore project is expected at year-end.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	Collaborative work continues between Goldcorp, Wemindji and the Grand Council of the Crees to
	support the advanced exploration program and develop a collaboration agreement for the future mine.
	The project Environmental and Social Impact Study (&#147;ESIA&#148;) was submitted in January&nbsp;2010 and work
	to provide grid power to the project site by the third quarter of 2010 continues.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	Capital expenditures during the fourth quarter of 2009 and the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009
	amounted to $19.6&nbsp;million and $66.6&nbsp;million, respectively. Cumulative expenditures to date amounted
	to $227.6&nbsp;million including a cumulative pre-payment to Hydro Quebec for the power line
	construction in the amount of $32.0&nbsp;million.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	GOLDCORP&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;34
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	&nbsp;
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	&nbsp;
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage177"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF; MARGIN-LEFT: .25IN; WIDTH: 7.20IN">
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	(in United States dollars, tabular amounts in millions, except where noted)
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<B>
	Cerro Blanco Project, Guatemala
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<I>
	The Cerro Blanco Project is located in southwestern Guatemala and is considered to be a classic hot
	springs gold deposit with typical bonanza type gold mineralization. As of December&nbsp;31, 2009, the
	deposit contains 1.3&nbsp;million ounces of indicated gold resources at an average grade of 15.64 grams
	per tonne and 0.7&nbsp;million ounces of inferred gold resources at an average grade of 15.31 grams per
	tonne.
</I>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	The Company will be using 2010 to demonstrate several key concepts at Cerro Blanco in preparation
	for a project feasibility study by mid-2011. Mining of the two drifts, from the north and south
	ends of the deposit (1,315 meters in total), and declining into the ore body will demonstrate the
	ability to mine underground in this geothermal area. In parallel, advance dewatering will be
	carried out to determine the long-term viability of the dewatering approach. Samples for
	metallurgical testing will be collected from the underground workings during 2010 to confirm the
	process methodology.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	During 2009, mining of the two declines advanced to a total of 643 meters, with a further 672
	meters remaining until they connect at the centre of the ore body. Additionally, 101 meters of
	lateral development to access mineralized zones and drill stations were completed in 2009. Drilling
	for additional dewatering wells in the third quarter of 2009 along with the installation of pumps
	in two existing wells is expected to increase overall dewatering efficiency. Construction of a
	water treatment plant commenced in the fourth quarter of 2009 and is on schedule for completion and
	operation by mid-2010.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	A geothermal resource with the potential to generate a significant quantity of geothermal power is
	located adjacent to the ore body. Drilling of this resource commenced late in 2008 and the fourth
	well was completed in the third quarter of 2009. Analysis of the test results will be used during
	2010 to determine the feasibility of producing geothermal power from the resource.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 14PT">
<B>
	Escobal Project,
	Guatemala
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	At the Escobal silver discovery, plans are progressing toward development of this world class
	resource. Measured and indicated silver resources at December&nbsp;31, 2009 totalled 130.1&nbsp;million
	ounces and inferred resources totalled 187.5&nbsp;million ounces. In-fill and extensional drilling will
	continue throughout 2010 and baseline environmental work and permitting efforts are underway.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	GOLDCORP&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;35
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	&nbsp;
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	&nbsp;
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage178"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF; MARGIN-LEFT: .25IN; WIDTH: 7.20IN">
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	(in United States dollars, tabular amounts in millions, except where noted)
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<B>
	Pueblo Viejo, Dominican Republic (Goldcorp&#146;s interest &#150; 40%)
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<I>
	Pueblo Viejo is a 23.7&nbsp;million ounce proven and probable gold reserve, where Goldcorp&#146;s interest
	represents 9.5&nbsp;million ounces. The project is a partnership with Barrick Gold Corporation, the
	project operator.
</I>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	The Pueblo Viejo project in the Dominican Republic is advancing on schedule with first gold
	expected in the fourth quarter of 2011. As a result of the plan to accelerate the expansion of the
	processing plant from 18,000 tonnes per day to 24,000 tonnes per day, the previously disclosed
	expansion capital of $0.3&nbsp;billion has been brought forward such that the pre-production capital
	estimate is now expected to be $3.0&nbsp;billion (100% basis). The accelerated expansion of the
	processing plant will increase Goldcorp&#146;s share of estimated annual gold production in its first
	five years of operation from 400,000 &#150; 430,000 ounces to 415,000 &#150; 450,000 ounces at lower total
	cash costs of $250 &#151; $275 per ounce, compared to previous estimates of $275 &#151; $300 per ounce.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	Site demolition is complete, the majority of site preparation earthworks are complete, 44,000 cubic
	meters of concrete have been poured and 1,500 tons of steel has been erected.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	The proposed amendments to the Special Lease Agreement were approved by the President on November
	13, 2009. The community relocation process is progressing on schedule. Pueblo Viejo is consulting
	with the communities in the vicinity of Puerto Viejo, the site of the project&#146;s power generating
	facilities. The ESIA for the power generating facilities was submitted to the Secretaria de Estado
	de Medio Ambiente y Recursos Naturales in October&nbsp;2009.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	Goldcorp has invested $587.1&nbsp;million, $90.3&nbsp;million of which related to the initial acquisition
	cost in 2006, with the balance of $496.8&nbsp;million being funds invested to finance ongoing project
	development activities. The project partners continue to discuss with a group of lenders to put in
	place approximately $1.0&nbsp;billion of project financing (100% share), which covers a portion of the
	total capital cost of the project. Pending final review of the proposed financing as required by
	the lenders&#146; governing laws and policies, the financing is expected to close in 2010.
</DIV>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	Included in corporate administration is stock based compensation expense of $45.1&nbsp;million in 2009
	(2008 &#151; $42.6&nbsp;million; 2007 &#151; $41.2&nbsp;million) which has increased due to the issuance of additional
	stock options and restricted share units and the vesting of previously issued stock options and
	restricted share units. Excluding stock based compensation expenses, corporate administration
	expense decreased by $1.6&nbsp;million in 2009, compared to 2008, and increased by $2.4&nbsp;million in 2008,
	compared to 2007. The decrease in corporate administration expense in 2009 was primarily due to
	restructuring costs incurred in 2008 and corporate efficiencies in 2009 as the Company continues to
	optimize its corporate functions. In 2008, increased corporate activity resulted in higher costs
	incurred for travel, World Gold Council fees, professional development and training, and consulting
	related to information systems, partially offset by a refund of capital taxes received in 2008.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	Exploration costs in 2009 decreased by $34.0&nbsp;million, as compared to 2008, and increased by $23.8
	million in 2008, as compared to 2007. Exploration costs for 2009 were lower due to reduced
	exploration spending in line with the Company&#146;s 2009 plan. Exploration costs for 2008 was higher in
	comparison to 2007 due to the expansion of the drilling program at Red Lake and the full ownership
	of Porcupine and Musselwhite for the entire fiscal year in 2008.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	As a result of the sale of the Company&#146;s 21.2% interest in the El Lim&#243;n gold project to Gleichen
	which closed on February&nbsp;24, 2010, the Company recognized a $24.0&nbsp;million before tax ($17.3&nbsp;million
	after tax) write-down of its investment in El Lim&#243;n during the fourth quarter of 2009. During the
	fourth quarter of 2008, the Company recognized a $47.1&nbsp;million before tax ($30.9&nbsp;million after tax)
	write-down of its mining interests at the Pamour open pit in Porcupine as a result of a reduction
	in its proven and probable reserves by 1.5&nbsp;million ounces of gold as at December&nbsp;31, 2008.
</DIV>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	The decrease in interest and other income (expenses)&nbsp;during 2009 is primarily due to accrued
	withholding taxes in 2009 and the higher interest earned on the significant cash balances held
	throughout 2008, which arose from the sale of the Pe&#241;asquito silver stream in the third quarter of
	2007 and the disposition of the Silver Wheaton shares in the first quarter of 2008, offset by
	interest earned during 2009 on cash balances resulting from the proceeds on the $862.5&nbsp;million
	convertible senior notes issued by the Company on June&nbsp;5, 2009. The Company incurred $2.9&nbsp;million
	of severance and shut-down costs during the third quarter of 2009 relating to the mill shut-down at
	Los Filos underground, offset by $2.2&nbsp;million received during the fourth quarter of 2009 from a
	business interruption claim relating to a crusher/conveyor system failure at Musselwhite.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	GOLDCORP&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;37

<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage180"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF; MARGIN-LEFT: .25IN; WIDTH: 7.20IN">
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	(in United States dollars, tabular amounts in millions, except where noted)
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	Interest expense and finance fees incurred during 2009 of $59.0&nbsp;million relates primarily to the
	convertible senior notes issued on June&nbsp;5, 2009 and $10.3&nbsp;million of accrued interest relating to
	withholding taxes. The decrease in interest expense and finance fees in 2008 compared to 2007 is
	due to the repayment of the balance outstanding on its revolving credit facility in the first
	quarter of 2008 and the exclusion of Silver Wheaton&#146;s non-revolving and revolving term loans as a
	result of the Company&#146;s sale of its interest in Silver Wheaton on February&nbsp;14, 2008. In 2007, the
	Company incurred $44.7&nbsp;million of interest expense and finance fees as a result of borrowings on
	credit facilities in 2006 to fund the acquisition of certain Placer Dome assets. The Company did
	not capitalize any of its interest incurred during 2009 (2008 and 2007 &#151; $1.4&nbsp;million and $10.9
	million, respectively, was capitalized to the Pe&#241;asquito project).
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	The share of earnings of equity investee earned during 2008 and 2007 related to the Company&#146;s
	investment in Peak Gold which was accounted for using the equity method, prior to Goldcorp losing
	significant influence over Peak Gold during the second quarter of 2008.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	As discussed under &#147;Financial Instruments and Related Risks&#148; below, the Company entered into
	foreign currency, heating oil and copper contracts during 2009. These contracts meet the definition
	of derivatives and do not qualify for hedge accounting. As a result, they are marked-to-market at
	each period end with changes in their fair values recorded in earnings for the period. A net gain
	of $3.6&nbsp;million was recorded during 2009, comprised of realized gains of $6.9&nbsp;million on matured
	contracts and mark-to-market losses of $3.3&nbsp;million (2008 &#151; net loss of $2.6&nbsp;million, comprised of
	realized losses of $10.2&nbsp;million on matured contracts and a reversal of unrealized mark-to-market
	losses recognized in previous years of $7.6&nbsp;million; 2007 &#150; net loss of $23.5&nbsp;million, comprised of
	realized losses of $19.9&nbsp;million on matured contracts and mark-to-market losses of $3.6&nbsp;million).
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	During 2009, the Company recorded a $50.2&nbsp;million gain on securities resulting from a $42.8&nbsp;million
	gain on the disposition of its investment in New Gold and a $7.4&nbsp;million net gain on its
	investments in warrants. During 2008, the Company recorded a $105.9&nbsp;million loss on securities,
	primarily related to the other than temporary write-down of its investments in New Gold and one
	other equity security classified as available-for-sale. The Company recorded an impairment loss on
	its investment in New Gold during the fourth quarter of 2008 due to the adverse changes in the
	economic environment in which New Gold operates and the continued decline of the market price of
	New Gold&#146;s shares during 2008. The net gain on securities in 2007 was $5.5&nbsp;million.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	During the fourth quarter of 2009, the Company sold certain mining interests for total proceeds
	amounting to $20.1&nbsp;million and recognized a gain of $20.1&nbsp;million before tax ($15.1&nbsp;million after
	tax). During the fourth quarter of 2008, the Company recorded a gain of $2.6&nbsp;million before tax
	($0.5&nbsp;million after tax) from the sale of certain mining assets. During the second quarter of 2007,
	the Company sold its Amapari and Peak mines to Peak Gold Ltd. for $200.0&nbsp;million in cash and $100.0
	million in share consideration. The sale resulted in a gain of $40.2&nbsp;million before tax ($6.5
	million after tax). In addition, the Company realized a $10.8&nbsp;million gain before tax ($9.1&nbsp;million
	after tax) from the sale of certain mining assets during the fourth quarter of 2007.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	During the first quarter of 2008, the Company completed the sale of its 108&nbsp;million common shares
	of Silver Wheaton (48% remaining interest) to a syndicate of underwriters at a price of C$14.50 per
	common share, for gross proceeds of $1.571&nbsp;billion less total transaction costs of $55.7&nbsp;million
	and less Silver Wheaton&#146;s cash balance of $10.2&nbsp;million. The transaction resulted in a gain of
	$292.5&nbsp;million before tax ($136.5&nbsp;million after tax) recognized in earnings in the first quarter of
	2008.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	Prior to the disposition of the Silver Wheaton shares on February&nbsp;14, 2008, stock options, warrants
	and restricted share units held by non-controlling interests were exercised resulting in 0.1%
	dilution of the Company&#146;s interest in Silver Wheaton and a dilution gain of $1.8&nbsp;million. The
	Company&#146;s interest in Silver Wheaton declined from 49% to 48% during 2007 from the additional
	issuances of common shares by Silver Wheaton. This dilution of interest resulted in a dilution gain
	of $1.1&nbsp;million in 2007.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	During the fourth quarter of 2009, stock options and share purchase warrants held by
	non-controlling interests of Terrane were exercised which resulted in a 1% dilution of the
	Company&#146;s interest from 66% to 65% and the recognition of $0.4&nbsp;million in dilution gain. During the
	first quarter of 2009, Terrane renounced the income tax benefits relating to the C$5.5&nbsp;million flow
	through shares
	issued in the third quarter of 2008 which resulted in a reversal of previously recorded dilution
	gain of $0.7&nbsp;million. The Company&#146;s interest in Terrane decreased from 68% to 66% in 2008 (2007 -
	from 77% to 68%) from additional issuances of common shares by Terrane. This dilution of interest,
	in addition to the reversal of dilution gain previously recorded upon renouncement in 2008 of the
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	GOLDCORP&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;38
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	&nbsp;
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">

<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage181"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF; MARGIN-LEFT: .25IN; WIDTH: 7.20IN">
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	(in United States dollars, tabular amounts in millions, except where noted)
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	income tax benefits relating to flow through shares issued by Terrane in 2007, gave rise to a
	dilution gain of $0.4&nbsp;million in 2008 (2007 &#150;$8.9&nbsp;million).
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	The Company recorded a net foreign exchange loss of $366.6&nbsp;million, resulting from the impact of
	the strengthened Canadian dollar and Mexican peso on the Company&#146;s future income tax liabilities,
	which are denominated in local currencies, and an increase in the Company&#146;s net monetary
	liabilities denominated in local currencies which are subject to foreign exchange translation. At
	December&nbsp;31, 2009, the Company has future income tax liabilities of $3.7&nbsp;billion (2008 and 2007 -
	$3.4&nbsp;billion) arising primarily from acquisitions of mining interests, which are monetary items
	translated each period end at current exchange rates to the US dollar, the Company&#146;s functional
	currency. The Company recorded a net foreign exchange gain of $1,058.9&nbsp;million in 2008, resulting
	primarily from the impact of the weakened Canadian dollar and Mexican peso on the Company&#146;s future
	income tax liabilities, which are denominated in local currencies. The reduction in future income
	tax liabilities was offset by the negative impact of the weakened Canadian dollar on the Company&#146;s
	significant cash balance denominated in Canadian dollars from the proceeds of the Silver Wheaton
	sale in the first quarter of 2008. In 2007, the Company recorded a net foreign exchange loss of
	$49.4&nbsp;million, resulting primarily from the impact of the strengthened Canadian dollar on its
	future income tax liabilities.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<B>
	INCOME AND MINING TAXES
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	Income and mining taxes for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009 amounted to $206.7&nbsp;million,
	approximately 25% of earnings before taxes, foreign exchange loss from translation of future
	income tax assets and liabilities, and stock option expense, which are either not subject to
	taxation, deductible, or likely to be utilizable. In 2008, income and mining taxes were $295.4
	million, or 34% of earnings before taxes,&nbsp; foreign exchange gain from translation of future income
	tax assets and liabilities, write-downs of investments in equity securities, and stock option
	expense (2007 &#150; $160.3&nbsp;million, or 24%).
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	The lower effective tax rate in 2009, as compared to 2008, is primarily due to the $42.8&nbsp;million
	gain on the disposition of the Company&#146;s investment in New Gold in 2009 not being subject to tax
	due to availability of capital loss carryforwards, the impact of additional tax benefits
	recognized from the harmonization of the Ontario corporate income tax with the Federal tax system
	in 2009 and the higher future income taxes payable in 2008 on the disposition of the Silver
	Wheaton shares of $155.9&nbsp;million, offset by the use of Mexican flat tax credits on taxable
	earnings in Mexico ($37.8&nbsp;million) in 2008.&nbsp; The effective tax rate in 2009 also includes the
	impact of a reduction of future income tax liabilities of $40.1&nbsp;million resulting from Canadian
	provincial income tax rate reductions enacted in the fourth quarter of 2009.&nbsp;This has been offset
	by increases in future income tax liabilities in Mexico of $26.2&nbsp;million as a result of the
	changes in Mexican income tax laws and an additional income tax liability of $12.8&nbsp;million arising
	from changes to the Mexican consolidated tax return rules enacted in the fourth quarter of 2009.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	The gain from the disposition of the Silver Wheaton shares became taxable in 2009 and the taxes
	will be payable in the first quarter of 2010, and as a result, the tax liability was reclassified
	from future to current income taxes in the first quarter of 2009.&nbsp; The impact of this
	reclassification was a future income recovery and current income tax expense on the statement of
	earnings, with no impact to net earnings.&nbsp; Cash flows for 2009 were not impacted due to the
	non-cash nature of this reclassification.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	The Mexican government approved its 2010 fiscal budget on December&nbsp;15, 2009 which included several
	significant changes to the Mexican income tax laws. The corporate income tax rate is being
	increased from 28% to 30% for the period from January&nbsp;1, 2010 through December&nbsp;31, 2012 and
	reduced to 29% in 2013 and back to 28% in 2014 and thereafter. As a result, the Company&#146;s future
	income tax liabilities increased by $26.2&nbsp;million in the fourth quarter of 2009. In addition the
	Mexican government modified its consolidated tax return rules such that the company could only
	benefit from a maximum 5&nbsp;year (formerly a maximum 10&nbsp;year) tax deferral of taxable income
	resulting from losses of companies within the consolidated group reducing taxable income of other
	companies within the consolidated group.&nbsp; Included with the changes to the consolidated tax return
	rules are provisions that tax the Company&#146;s past consolidation benefits retroactively by
	estimating the tax benefits of consolidation at December&nbsp;31, 2009 and requiring the company to
	repay the benefits in future years. This element of the changes to the consolidated tax return
	rules has resulted in what
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	GOLDCORP&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;39
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	&nbsp;
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	&nbsp;
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage182"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF; MARGIN-LEFT: .25IN; WIDTH: 7.20IN">
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	(in United States dollars, tabular amounts in millions, except where noted)
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	the company considers a double taxation of income earned by the
	consolidated group. The Company has estimated that the income tax impact of this new legislation
	at December&nbsp;31, 2009 could potentially be $79.1&nbsp;million, of which $7.9&nbsp;million, $23.6&nbsp;million, and
	$47.6&nbsp;million would be payable evenly during the period 2013 to 2017, 2014 to 2018 and 2015 to
	2019, respectively, without additional tax restructuring. The Company has the ability and intends
	to execute a plan that is fully within its control and solely at its discretion to merge two
	entities within the consolidated group in 2013 which will reduce the estimated income tax impact
	to $12.8&nbsp;million, of which $8.4&nbsp;million and $4.4&nbsp;million is payable evenly during the period 2015
	to 2019 and 2018 to 2022, respectively. Accordingly, the Company has recorded an income and mining
	taxes payable, classified as long-term, and a current income tax expense of $12.8&nbsp;million as at
	and for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009. There is an expectation that Mexico may publish
	technical corrections to certain aspects of the Tax Reform Bill in 2010 that could significantly
	reduce the amounts due from the Company as described above. However, there is no assurance that
	Mexico will in fact publish such corrections, nor is it clear what impact any corrections
	published will have on the Company&#146;s actual liability under the new law. Although any ultimate
	outcome is uncertain, the Company intends to contest the validity and effective date of the new
	legislation.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	On October&nbsp;1, 2007, the Government of Mexico enacted legislation which introduced a new flat rate
	business tax effective January&nbsp;1, 2008 (16.5% in 2008, 17% in 2009 and 17.5% thereafter) and a new
	2% tax on cash deposits effective July&nbsp;1, 2008. The Company was not subject to the flat tax in
	2009 and 2008.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<B>
	NON-CONTROLLING INTERESTS
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	The non-controlling interests relate to Goldcorp&#146;s non-wholly owned subsidiaries, Terrane (65%),
	and Silver Wheaton (48%), until February&nbsp;14, 2008, at which time, Goldcorp disposed of its 48%
	interest.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<B>
<I>
	Silver Wheaton
</I>
</B>
	: As a result of the acquisition of Wheaton River Minerals Ltd. (&#147;Wheaton&#148;) on
	February&nbsp;14, 2005, Goldcorp acquired Wheaton&#146;s 65% ownership of its subsidiary, Silver Wheaton.
	Following various share issuances by Silver Wheaton, Goldcorp&#146;s interest in Silver Wheaton declined
	to 49% at January&nbsp;1, 2007. Additional share issuances by Silver Wheaton from the exercise of stock
	options and warrants outstanding decreased Goldcorp&#146;s interest from 49% to 48% during 2007. In the
	first quarter of 2008, prior to the disposition of Silver Wheaton shares on February&nbsp;14, 2008,
	stock options, warrants and restricted share units held by non-controlling interests were exercised
	and resulted in a 0.1% dilution in Goldcorp&#146;s interest. The Company continued to consolidate Silver
	Wheaton up to the date of disposition of its interests on February&nbsp;14, 2008, as it maintained
	control over Silver Wheaton due to the influence it exerted on the board of directors.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	The non-controlling interests&#146; share of Silver Wheaton&#146;s net earnings for 2008, prior to Goldcorp&#146;s
	disposition of its Silver Wheaton shares, amounted to $7.3&nbsp;million (year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 -
	$47.0&nbsp;million).
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<B>
<I>
	Terrane:
</I>
</B>
	In 2006, the Company sold certain of its Canadian exploration interests, including the Mt.
	Milligan gold/copper project in Canada to Terrane in exchange for 240&nbsp;million convertible Series&nbsp;A
	preferred shares of Terrane at a price of C$0.50 per share. On an as-converted basis, Goldcorp
	would own an 81% equity interest in Terrane, and, as a result, non-controlling interests of $22
	million was recognized on acquisition of Terrane. Following the issuance of common shares and
	common share purchase warrants in a private placement on November&nbsp;3, 2006, Goldcorp&#146;s interest in
	Terrane declined to 77% at January&nbsp;1, 2007.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	On June&nbsp;21, 2007, Terrane closed a C$25&nbsp;million public offering of 30.8&nbsp;million common shares at a
	price of C$0.65 per share and 6.25&nbsp;million flow-through shares at a price of C$0.80 per share. On
	July&nbsp;23, 2007, Terrane closed a private placement of 5.6&nbsp;million common shares at a price of C$0.65
	per share for gross proceeds of C$3.6&nbsp;million. These transactions resulted in a decrease in
	Goldcorp&#146;s interest in Terrane from 77% to 68%, and an increase in non-controlling interests of
	$20.1&nbsp;million.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	During the third quarter of 2008, Terrane closed a private placement of 10.0&nbsp;million flow through
	common shares at a price of C$0.55 per share for gross proceeds of C$5.5&nbsp;million. The private
	placement in addition to issuances of common shares from exercises of stock
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	GOLDCORP&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;40
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	&nbsp;
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	&nbsp;
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage183"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF; MARGIN-LEFT: .25IN; WIDTH: 7.20IN">
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	(in United States dollars, tabular amounts in millions, except where noted)
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	options outstanding
	resulted in a decrease in Goldcorp&#146;s interest in Terrane from 68% to 66% and an increase in
	non-controlling interests of $4.5&nbsp;million.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	During the fourth quarter of 2009, Terrane issued 4.8&nbsp;million common shares resulting from
	exercises of stock options and common share purchase warrants outstanding. This resulted in a
	decrease in Goldcorp&#146;s interest in Terrane from 66% to 65% and an increase in non-controlling
	interests of $1.9&nbsp;million. The non-controlling interests&#146; share of Terrane&#146;s net loss during the
	year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009 was $2.0&nbsp;million (2008 &#150; share of net earnings of $0.4&nbsp;million; 2007 &#150;
	share of net loss of $0.9&nbsp;million).
</DIV>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_56"></A>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<B>
	DISCONTINUED OPERATION &#150; LA COIPA MINE, CHILE
</B>
	(Goldcorp&#146;s interest &#150; 50%)
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	On December&nbsp;21, 2007, Goldcorp acquired Kinross&#146; 49% share of the Porcupine gold mines in
	north-eastern Ontario and its 32% share of the Musselwhite gold mine in northwestern Ontario in
	exchange for Goldcorp&#146;s 50% interest in the La Coipa gold/silver mine in Chile (&#147;La Coipa&#148;) and
	$200.0&nbsp;million in cash. As a result, La Coipa, previously disclosed as a separate operating
	segment, was retroactively reclassified as a discontinued operation. The following table presents
	selected data for Goldcorp&#146;s 50% interest in La Coipa:
</DIV>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage184"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF; MARGIN-LEFT: .25IN; WIDTH: 7.20IN">
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	(in United States dollars, tabular amounts in millions, except where noted)
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<B>
	NON-GAAP MEASURE &#150; TOTAL CASH COSTS (BY-PRODUCT) PER GOLD OUNCE CALCULATION
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	The Company has included non-GAAP performance measures, total cash costs, by-product and
	co-product, per gold ounce, throughout this document. The Company reports total cash costs on a
	sales basis. In the gold mining industry, this is a common performance measure but does not have
	any standardized meaning. The Company follows the recommendations of the Gold Institute Production
	Cost Standard. The Company believes that, in addition to conventional measures, prepared in
	accordance with GAAP, certain investors use this information to evaluate the Company&#146;s performance
	and ability to generate cash flow. Accordingly, it is intended to provide additional information
	and should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for measures of performance prepared
	in accordance with GAAP. The following table provides a reconciliation of total cash costs
	(by-product) per ounce to the consolidated financial statements:
</DIV>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_57"></A>

<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	If silver and copper were treated as co-products, total cash costs of
	continuing operations would be $391 per ounce of gold (2008 &#151; $391 per ounce,
	2007 &#151; $305 per ounce).
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">

	&nbsp;

<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	$69.4&nbsp;million in royalties are included in operating expenses per the
	consolidated financial statements (2008 &#151; $67.2&nbsp;million, 2007 &#151; $135.0&nbsp;million).
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>

<TD>
	&nbsp;

	&nbsp;

	San Martin mine ended its mining process in October&nbsp;2007, and is therefore
	excluded from the figures above commencing 2008.
</DIV>
</TD>

	&nbsp;

<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF; MARGIN-LEFT: .25IN; WIDTH: 7.20IN">
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	(in United States dollars, tabular amounts in millions, except where noted)
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<B>
	NON-GAAP MEASURE &#150; ADJUSTED NET EARNINGS
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	The Company has included non-GAAP performance measures, adjusted net earnings and adjusted net
	earnings per share, throughout this document. The Company believes that, in addition to
	conventional measures prepared in accordance with GAAP, certain investors use this information to
	evaluate the Company&#146;s performance and ability to generate cash flow. Accordingly, it is intended
	to provide additional information and should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for
	measures of performance prepared in accordance with GAAP. The following table provides a
	reconciliation of adjusted net earnings to the consolidated financial statements:
</DIV>

<A NAME="FIS_INCOME_STATEMENT"></A>

<TD>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:15PX; TEXT-INDENT:-15PX">
<B>
	Net earnings per consolidated financial statements
</B>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage186"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF; MARGIN-LEFT: .25IN; WIDTH: 7.20IN">
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	(in United States dollars, tabular amounts in millions, except where noted)
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<B>
	FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS AND RELATED RISKS
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	The Company manages its exposure to financial risks, including credit risk, liquidity risk,
	currency risk, interest rate risk and price risk, in accordance with its Risk Management Policy.
	The Company&#146;s Board of Directors oversees management&#146;s risk management practices by setting trading
	parameters and reporting requirements. The Risk Management Policy provides a framework for the
	Company to manage the risks it is exposed to in various markets and to protect itself against
	adverse market movements. All transactions undertaken are to support the Company&#146;s ongoing
	business. The Company does not acquire or issue derivative financial instruments for trading or
	speculative purposes.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	The following describes the types of risks that the Company is exposed to and its objectives and
	policies for managing those risk exposures:
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<B>
<I>
	Credit risk
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	Credit risk is the risk that the counterparty to a financial instrument will cause a financial loss
	for the Company by failing to discharge its obligations. Credit risk is primarily associated with
	trade receivables; however, it also arises on cash and cash equivalents and derivative assets. To
	mitigate exposure to credit risk on financial assets, the Company has established policies to limit
	the concentration of credit risk, ensure counterparties demonstrate minimum acceptable credit
	worthiness and ensure liquidity of available funds.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	The Company closely monitors its financial assets and does not have any significant concentration
	of credit risk. The Company invests its cash and cash equivalents in highly rated corporations and
	government issuances in accordance with its short-term investment policy and the credit risk
	associated with its money market investments is considered to be low. The Company sells its
	products exclusively to large international financial institutions and other organizations with
	strong credit ratings. The historical level of customer defaults is negligible and, as a result,
	the credit risk associated with trade receivables at December&nbsp;31, 2009 is considered to be
	negligible. The Company&#146;s foreign currency, heating oil and copper contracts are entered into with
	large international financial institutions with strong credit ratings.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	The Company&#146;s maximum exposure to credit risk at December&nbsp;31 is as follows:
</DIV>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<B>
<I>
	Liquidity risk
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	Liquidity risk is the risk that the Company will encounter difficulty in meeting obligations
	associated with its financial liabilities that are settled by delivering cash or another financial
	asset. The Company has in place a rigorous planning, budgeting and forecasting process to help
	determine the funds required to support the Company&#146;s normal operating requirements on an ongoing
	basis and its expansionary plans. The Company ensures that sufficient committed loan facilities
	exist to meet its short-term business requirements, taking into account its anticipated cash flows
	from operations and its holdings of cash and cash equivalents. During the year ended December&nbsp;31,
	2009, the Company generated operating cash flows from continuing activities of $1,270.2&nbsp;million
	(2008 &#151; $866.0&nbsp;million; 2007 &#151; $650.7&nbsp;million).
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2009, Goldcorp held cash and cash equivalents of $874.6&nbsp;million (2008- $262.3
	million) and had working capital of $866.5&nbsp;million (2008 &#151; $274.5&nbsp;million).
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	On May&nbsp;18, 2007, Goldcorp entered into a $1.5&nbsp;billion revolving credit facility. At December&nbsp;31,
	2009, there was no amount outstanding under this credit facility. On July&nbsp;8, 2008, Terrane entered
	into a credit agreement for an 18-month, non-revolving term loan facility of
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	GOLDCORP&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;44
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	&nbsp;
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	&nbsp;
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>

<!-- END TABLE BODY -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2009, the Company had letters of credit outstanding and secured deposits in the
	amount of $270.9&nbsp;million (2008 &#151; $201.3&nbsp;million).
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	In the opinion of management, the working capital at December&nbsp;31, 2009, together with future cash
	flows from operations, is sufficient to support the Company&#146;s commitments. The Company&#146;s total
	planned capital expenditures for 2010 with a focus on commissioning Pe&#241;asquito in 2010 and further
	developing Pueblo Viejo are forecasted to be approximately $1.5&nbsp;billion. These expenditures will be
	funded partly by available cash balances, cash flows from operations, available funding under the
	$1.5&nbsp;billion revolving credit facility and anticipated project financing loan of approximately $1.0
	billion ($400.0&nbsp;million &#150; Goldcorp&#146;s share). The acquisitions completed in February&nbsp;2010 will be
	funded by available cash balances and funding under the $1.5&nbsp;billion revolving credit facility
<I>
	.
</I>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	For the periods beyond 2010, cash flows from operations and available funding under the Company&#146;s
	loan facilities are expected to sufficiently support further expansions and growth. Pe&#241;asquito will
	be the main driver of the Company&#146;s gold production growth expected in the next five years, with
	significant contributions from Red Lake and Pueblo Viejo.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<B>
<I>
	Market Risk
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<B>
<I>
	(i)&nbsp;Currency risk
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	Currency risk is the risk that the fair values or future cash flows of the Company&#146;s financial
	instruments will fluctuate because of changes in foreign currency exchange rates. Exchange rate
	fluctuations may affect the costs that the Company incurs in its operations. Gold, silver, copper,
	zinc and lead are sold in US dollars and the Company&#146;s costs are incurred principally in US
	dollars, Canadian dollars, Mexican pesos, Argentine pesos and Guatemalan quetzals. The appreciation
	of non-US dollar currencies against the US dollar can increase the costs of gold, silver, copper,
	zinc and lead production and capital expenditures in US dollar terms. The Company also holds cash
	and cash equivalents that are denominated in non-US dollar currencies which are subject to currency
	risk. Accounts receivable and other current and long-term assets denominated in non-US dollars
	relate to goods and services taxes, value-added taxes and insurance receivables. At December&nbsp;31,
	2009, the Company had $3.7&nbsp;billion of future income tax liabilities which arose primarily from the
	acquisitions of Placer Dome Inc.&#146;s assets and Glamis in 2006 and Gold Eagle in the third quarter of
	2008 which are payable in
	local currencies. The future income tax liabilities are considered monetary items, which are
	translated each period end at current exchange rates, with the gain or loss recorded in earnings
	for the period.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	GOLDCORP&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;45
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	&nbsp;
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	&nbsp;
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>

<!-- END TABLE BODY -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 14PT">
	During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009, the Company recognized a loss of $366.6&nbsp;million on foreign
	exchange (2008 &#151; gain of $1,058.9&nbsp;million; 2007 &#151; loss of $49.4&nbsp;million). Of this amount, $324.3
	million resulted from the translation of future income taxes denominated in currencies other than
	US dollars (2008 &#151; gain of $1,070.9&nbsp;million; 2007 &#151; loss of $54.6&nbsp;million). Based on the above net
	exposures at December&nbsp;31, 2009, a 10% depreciation or appreciation of the above currencies against
	the US dollar would result in a $282.5&nbsp;million increase or decrease in the Company&#146;s after-tax net
	earnings, respectively.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009, the Company entered into Canadian dollar and Mexican peso
	forward and option contracts to purchase and sell the respective foreign currencies at
	pre-determined US dollar amounts. These contracts were entered into to normalize operating expenses
	incurred by the Company&#146;s foreign operations as expressed in US dollar terms. In accordance with
	its Risk Management Policy, the Company may hedge up to 50% and 30% of its annual Canadian dollar
	and Mexican peso operating expenditures over the next twelve months and subsequent thirteen to
	twenty four months, respectively. The Company entered into nominal foreign currency contracts
	during the fourth quarter of 2008 that matured within the quarter. No foreign currency contracts
	were entered into during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 14PT">
<B>
<I>
	(ii)&nbsp;Interest rate risk
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	Interest rate risk is the risk that the fair values and future cash flows of the Company&#146;s
	financial instruments will fluctuate because of changes in market interest rates. The Company is
	exposed to interest rate risk on its outstanding revolving credit facility and non-revolving term
	loan and cash and cash equivalents. The Company monitors its exposure to interest rates and is
	comfortable with its
	exposures given the relatively low short-term US dollar rates. The weighted average interest rate
	incurred by the Company during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009 on outstanding balances under its
	revolving credit facility and non-revolving term loan was 0.83% (2008 &#150; 4.12%; 2007 &#150; 5.63%). At
	December&nbsp;31, 2009, a 10% increase or decrease in the interest rate would result in a nominal
	decrease or increase in the Company&#146;s after-tax net earnings. The average interest rate earned by
	the Company during the year ended
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	GOLDCORP&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;46
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	&nbsp;
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	&nbsp;
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage189"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF; MARGIN-LEFT: .25IN; WIDTH: 7.20IN">
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	(in United States dollars, tabular amounts in millions, except where noted)
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	December&nbsp;31, 2009 on its cash and cash equivalents was 0.22%
	(2008 &#151; 2.68%; 2007 &#151; 5.16%). A 10% increase or decrease in the interest earned from financial
	institutions on deposits held and money market investments would result in a nominal increase or
	decrease in the Company&#146;s after-tax net earnings, respectively.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<B>
<I>
	(iii)&nbsp;Price risk
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	Price risk is the risk that the fair value or future cash flows of the Company&#146;s financial
	instruments will fluctuate because of changes in market prices. Profitability of the Company
	depends on metal prices for gold, silver, copper, zinc and lead. Metal prices are affected by
	numerous factors such as the sale or purchase of gold and silver by various central banks and
	financial institutions, interest rates, exchange rates, inflation or deflation, fluctuations in the
	value of the US dollar and foreign currencies, global and regional supply and demand, and the
	political and economic conditions of major producing countries throughout the world. A 10% increase
	or decrease in metal prices would result in a $212.0&nbsp;million increase or decrease in the Company&#146;s
	after-tax net earnings, respectively. The Company has a policy not to hedge gold sales. In
	accordance with the Company&#146;s Risk Management Policy, the Company may hedge up to 50% of its base
	metal sales volume over the next fifteen months to manage its exposure to fluctuations in base
	metal prices.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	The costs relating to the Company&#146;s production, development and exploration activities vary
	depending on the market prices of certain mining consumables including diesel and electricity. A
	10% increase or decrease in diesel market prices would result in an $8.0&nbsp;million decrease or
	increase in the Company&#146;s after-tax net earnings, respectively. The Company does not intend to
	hedge against diesel price fluctuations in Mexico as the government regulates the domestic market.
	The Company has entered into contracts to hedge against diesel price fluctuations in Canada and the
	United States through NYMEX heating oil contracts as a proxy for diesel. Electricity is regionally
	priced in Ontario, Canada and Mexico and semi-regulated by the provincial and federal governments,
	respectively. The regulation of electricity prices reduces the risk of price fluctuation and the
	Company therefore does not contemplate entering into contracts to hedge against such risk.
</DIV>

<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 14PT">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2009, there was no externally imposed capital requirement, to which the Company is
	subject, which the Company has not complied with.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009, the Company invested a total of $1,356.4&nbsp;million in mining
	interests, including $521.8&nbsp;million at Pe&#241;asquito, $329.4&nbsp;million at Pueblo Viejo, $109.8&nbsp;million
	at Red Lake, $78.9&nbsp;million at Musselwhite, $72.8&nbsp;million at Los Filos and $66.6&nbsp;million at
	&#201;l&#233;onore. These expenditures were funded primarily from cash flows from operations.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	As at March&nbsp;11, 2010, there were 733.9&nbsp;million common shares of the Company issued and outstanding
	and 13.6&nbsp;million stock options outstanding which are exchangeable into common shares at exercise
	prices ranging between C$8.06 per share to C$39.77 per share. In
	addition, the Company had 9.2&nbsp;million share purchase warrants outstanding, of which 8.4&nbsp;million are
	exchangeable for 8.4&nbsp;million common shares at an exercise price of C$45.75 per share until June&nbsp;9,
	2011. The remaining 0.8&nbsp;million share purchase warrants are exchangeable for 0.8&nbsp;million common
	shares at an exercise price of C$34.76 per share until June&nbsp;26, 2011.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	Cash dividend payments for the period totaled $131.7&nbsp;million (2008 &#151; $128.7&nbsp;million; 2007 &#151; $126.9
	million).
