<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 8%">
	At the date of acquisition, the cumulative mark-to-market gain on Gold Eagle shares, owned
	by the Company prior to the transaction and classified as available-for-sale investments, of
	$29.2&nbsp;million was removed from AOCI and offset against the total purchase price. The assets
	and liabilities acquired have been assigned to and included in the Red Lake reporting unit.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="4%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	(d)
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Disposition of Silver Wheaton shares
</B>
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 8PT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="4%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	On February&nbsp;14, 2008, Goldcorp disposed of its 108&nbsp;million common shares of Silver Wheaton
	(48% interest) to a syndicate of underwriters at a price of C$14.50 per common share, for
	gross proceeds of $1,571.0&nbsp;million. The Company received net proceeds of $1,505.1&nbsp;million
	(gross proceeds of $1,571.0&nbsp;million less transaction costs of $55.7&nbsp;million and cash held by
	Silver Wheaton of $10.2&nbsp;million).
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 8PT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="4%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	After deducting the book value of the Silver Wheaton shares ($546.0&nbsp;million) and transaction
	costs ($55.7&nbsp;million), the Company had excess consideration of $969.3&nbsp;million on the sale of
	its Silver Wheaton shares. The total gain recognized in earnings in the first quarter of
	2008 of $292.5&nbsp;million is comprised of the $279.4&nbsp;million relating to the third party silver
	arrangements between Silver Wheaton and Zinkgruvan, Yauliyacu and Stratoni and the
	realization of $17.7&nbsp;million of AOCI related to Silver Wheaton&#146;s investments, offset by $4.6
	million of other liabilities. The sale of the Silver Wheaton shares resulted in an income
	tax liability for the Company of $155.9&nbsp;million, which is payable in the first quarter of
	2010 and was reclassified from future income taxes to current income taxes in the first
	quarter of 2009.
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 8PT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="4%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	As a result of the Company having arrangements to sell silver to Silver Wheaton from its San
	Dimas, Los Filos and Pe&#241;asquito mines at approximately $4 per ounce, the remaining $689.9
	million of excess consideration was applied as a reduction to the carrying amounts of mining
	properties and plant and equipment at San Dimas, Los Filos and Pe&#241;asquito ($479.4&nbsp;million,
	$26.5&nbsp;million and $184.0&nbsp;million, respectively). The consideration paid to Goldcorp by
	Silver Wheaton for the San Dimas silver arrangement in 2004 and 2006, and the Pe&#241;asquito
	silver arrangement in 2007, which were previously eliminated upon consolidation, were
	applied as a reduction to mining properties and plant and equipment at San Dimas and
	Pe&#241;asquito, respectively, as a result of the disposition of the Company&#146;s interest in Silver
	Wheaton.
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 8PT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="4%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	The results of Silver Wheaton were consolidated prior to this disposition. As a result of
	Goldcorp&#146;s continuing cash flows with Silver Wheaton arising from the San Dimas, Los Filos
	and Pe&#241;asquito silver arrangements, Silver Wheaton has not been classified as a discontinued
	operation in these consolidated financial statements.
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	GOLDCORP&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;22

<A NAME="eolPage225"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<!-- XBRL -->
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF; MARGIN-LEFT: .25IN; WIDTH: 7.20IN">
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	(in United States dollars and tabular amounts in millions, except where noted)
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="4%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	(e)
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Acquisition of 100% Interest in Porcupine and Musselwhite and Disposition of Interest
	in La Coipa
</B>
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 8PT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="4%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	On December&nbsp;21, 2007, Goldcorp acquired Kinross Gold Corporation&#146;s 49% interest in the
	Porcupine gold mines in northeastern Ontario and 32% interest in the Musselwhite gold mine
	in northwestern Ontario in exchange for Goldcorp&#146;s 50% interest in the La Coipa gold/silver
	mine (&#147;La Coipa&#148;) in Chile and $204.9&nbsp;million in cash, net of cash and cash equivalents
	acquired.
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 8PT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="4%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	The results of La Coipa were retroactively reclassified as a discontinued operation in the
	2007 consolidated financial statements
<I>
	(note 6)
</I>
	. A gain of $46.4&nbsp;million was recognized on
	the disposition in the fourth quarter of 2007
<I>
	.
</I>
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 8PT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="4%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	Goldcorp&#146;s interests in Porcupine and Musselwhite are included in these consolidated
	financial statements at 51% and 68%, respectively, from May&nbsp;12, 2006 to December&nbsp;21, 2007
	and at 100% thereafter.
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 8PT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="4%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	The acquisition of the remaining interests in Porcupine and Musselwhite was accounted for as
	a step purchase transaction, with the purchase price allocated as follows:
</DIV>
</TD>

	Prior to closing of the above transaction, the Porcupine joint venture disposed of a
	property consisting of a decommissioned mine and mill in Timmins, Ontario. Goldcorp
	recognized a gain of $10.8&nbsp;million from the sale of this property. For the purpose of these
	consolidated financial statements, the purchase price was allocated to the fair values of
	assets acquired and liabilities assumed based on management&#146;s best estimates and taking into
	account all available information at the time of acquisition.

<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 8%">
	Goldcorp&#146;s interest in Peak Gold was reduced to 18% in the first quarter of 2008 upon the
	exercise of special warrants issued by Peak Gold in November&nbsp;2007. Goldcorp lost significant
	influence over Peak Gold during the second quarter of 2008, at which time its investment was
	classified as available-for-sale and measured at fair value. On June&nbsp;30, 2008, Peak Gold
	completed a business combination with Metallica Resources Inc. and New Gold, with the
	combined company carrying on as New Gold. Former Peak Gold shareholders received 0.1 common
	share of New Gold and $0.0001 in cash for each common share of Peak Gold, which resulted in
	Goldcorp owning 7% of New Gold. The investment in New Gold was classified as
	available-for-sale and measured at fair value prior to its disposition on October&nbsp;13, 2009
<I>
	(note
</I>
<I>
	15(a)
</I>
<I>
	)
</I>
	.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">

<B>
	(g)

<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	On February&nbsp;1, 2007, a wholly owned subsidiary of Goldcorp disposed of other mining
	interests for cash of $24.0&nbsp;million and $2.0&nbsp;million in common shares of the acquirer. The
	proceeds received approximated the net book value of the mining interests sold. The common
	shares received by the Company were classified as available-for-sale on initial
	recognition.
</DIV>

<!-- XBRL,BODY -->
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
<B>
	Glamis Gold Ltd.
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	The allocation of the purchase price relating to the acquisition of Glamis Gold Ltd. (&#147;Glamis&#148;)
	which closed on November&nbsp;4, 2006 was finalized in the fourth quarter of 2007. As a result,
	adjustments were made in the fourth quarter of 2007 to increase the amount initially recorded
	for mining interests by $837.9&nbsp;million, decrease goodwill by $524.6&nbsp;million, increase future
	income and mining taxes by $354.7&nbsp;million and increase other assets and liabilities by $41.4
	million, net.
</DIV>

<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	As a result of the sale of Goldcorp&#146;s interest in La Coipa in the fourth quarter of 2007
<I>
	(note
</I>
<I>
	4(e)
</I>
<I>
	)
</I>
	, La Coipa, previously disclosed as a separate operating segment, was retroactively
	reclassified as a discontinued operation in the 2007 consolidated financial statements.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	Selected financial information of the discontinued operation included in the Consolidated
	Statements of Earnings and the Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows for the year ended December
	31, 2007 is as follows:
</DIV>
<EFX_INCOME_STATEMENT>
<A NAME="FIS_INCOME_STATEMENT_3"></A>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT">
<TABLE STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT" CELLSPACING="0" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="96%">
<!-- BEGIN TABLE HEAD -->

	&nbsp;

<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="CENTER" COLSPAN="2" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM: 0PX SOLID #000000">
	2007
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 1PX">

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	The amount of inventories recognized as an expense during the year is included in operating
	expenses in the Consolidated Statements of Earnings.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	The San Martin mine ended its mining process in October&nbsp;2007 and commenced reclamation
	activities at that time. For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008, the Company recorded an $8.0
	million write-down of heap leach ore inventory relating to the San Martin mine which is included
	in operating expenses.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
<B>
<I>
	Stockpiled ore
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	The majority of the low-grade stockpiled ore is located at Alumbrera and is forecasted to be
	drawn down throughout the remainder of the mine life, until 2017. The portion that is to be
	processed over a period exceeding twelve months is classified as long-term.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	GOLDCORP&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;25
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	&nbsp;
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	&nbsp;
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>

<TD WIDTH="1%">

<TD WIDTH="96">

<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(a)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	On September&nbsp;25, 2008, the Company acquired the net assets of Gold Eagle pursuant to a
	plan of arrangement. The mining interests of Gold Eagle are included in Red Lake
<I>
	(note
	4(c))
</I>
	.
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(b)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	The Company recognized a $47.1&nbsp;million before tax ($30.9&nbsp;million after tax) write-down
	of its mining interests at the Pamour open pit in Porcupine in the fourth quarter of 2008
	as a result of a reduction in its proven and probable reserves by 1.4&nbsp;million ounces of
	gold as at December&nbsp;31, 2008.
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(c)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	Included in the carrying amount is capitalized interest during the year ended December
	31, 2009 of $nil (2008 &#151; $1.4&nbsp;million; 2007 &#151; $10.9&nbsp;million). Also included in the carrying
	amount is the capitalized amount of $3.0&nbsp;million relating to stock options vested during
	the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009 (2008 and 2007 &#151; $nil)
<I>
	(note 18(b))
</I>
	.
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(d)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	Included in the net book value is San Martin which commenced reclamation activities in
	October&nbsp;2007.
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(e)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	The equity investments in these exploration/development stage properties have no
	current operations. The carrying amounts represent the fair values of the properties at the
	time they were acquired, plus subsequent expenditures which have been invested in property
	development.
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(f)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	As a result of the transaction completed with Gleichen on February&nbsp;24, 2010
<I>
	(note
	24(c))
</I>
	, the Company recognized a $24.0&nbsp;million before tax ($17.3&nbsp;million after tax)
	write-down of its investment in the El Lim&#243;n gold project during the fourth quarter of
	2009. Of the $24.0&nbsp;million, $33.3&nbsp;million was applied against mining interests and the
	offsetting $9.3&nbsp;million was applied against the related future income tax liability.
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(g)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2009, assets under construction and therefore not yet being
	depreciated, included in the net book value of plant and equipment, amounted to $1,116.5
	million (2008 &#151; $569.6&nbsp;million).
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT">
<TABLE WIDTH="96%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 6PT">
<TD WIDTH="3%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="96">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(a)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	On July&nbsp;8, 2008 Terrane entered into a credit agreement for an 18-month, non-revolving
	term loan facility of up to C$40&nbsp;million to further advance Terrane&#146;s long lead-time
	capital equipment procurement program in support of the construction of an open pit mine
	and 60,000 tonnes per day processing plant at Terrane&#146;s Mt. Milligan project. Under the
	terms of the credit agreement, Goldcorp guaranteed the credit facility in exchange for a
	one-time option to convert its equity interest in Terrane into a participating joint
	venture interest in the Mt. Milligan project. The option expired unexercised on January&nbsp;7,
	2010. On January&nbsp;7, 2010, the credit agreement was extended to May&nbsp;7, 2010. During the
	period from July&nbsp;8, 2008 to December&nbsp;31, 2009, Terrane drew down on the facility via 90&nbsp;day
	bankers&#146; acceptances and prime rate loans with weighted average annual effective interest
	rates ranging from 1.1% to 4.1%. Interest incurred for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009
	amounted to $0.2&nbsp;million (2008 &#151; $0.2&nbsp;million). Terrane has a contractual right to continue
	to roll over the short-term obligations for the term of the credit agreement and
	accordingly the balance outstanding at December&nbsp;31, 2008 was classified as a long-term
	liability. The balance outstanding at December&nbsp;31, 2009 with a weighted average annual
	effective interest rate of 1.9% is classified as a current liability.
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(b)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	On June&nbsp;5, 2009, the Company issued convertible senior notes (&#147;the notes&#148; or &#147;the
	Company&#146;s notes&#148;) with an aggregate principal amount of $862.5&nbsp;million. The notes are
	unsecured and bear interest at an annual rate of 2.0% payable semi-annually in arrears on
	February 1 and August 1 of each year, beginning on February&nbsp;1, 2010, and mature on August
	1, 2014.
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	Holders of the notes may convert the notes at their option at any time during the period from
	May&nbsp;1, 2014 to the maturity date and at any time during the period from June&nbsp;5, 2009 to May
	1, 2014, subject to certain market and other conditions. The notes are convertible into the
	Company&#146;s common shares at a conversion rate of 20.8407 common shares for every $1,000
	principal amount of notes, subject to adjustment in certain events. Subject to satisfaction
	of certain conditions, the Company may, upon conversion by the holder, elect to settle in
	cash or a combination of cash and common shares. The notes are non-redeemable, except upon
	occurrence of certain changes in Canadian withholding tax laws or a fundamental change.
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	The notes are accounted for as compound financial instruments comprised of a liability and an
	equity component. Of the total proceeds of $862.5&nbsp;million, $703.4&nbsp;million was allocated on
	initial recognition to the liability component, representing the present value of the
	Company&#146;s contractual obligation to make principal and interest payments using an annual
	effective interest rate of 6.33%, being management&#146;s estimate of the interest rate available
	on similar borrowings without the conversion feature at the time the notes were issued. The
	remaining amount of $159.1&nbsp;million was allocated on initial recognition to the equity
	component, representing the value of the call options granting the holders the right to
	convert into common shares of the Company. Total transaction costs of $22.7&nbsp;million were
	allocated in proportion to the allocation of proceeds. The amount allocated to the liability
	component of $18.5&nbsp;million was expensed on initial recognition and included in finance fees.
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	The carrying amount of the liability is accreted to the face value of the notes over the term
	of the notes. Accretion is included in interest expense during each period based on the
	annual effective interest rate of 6.33% per annum. Interest expense for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2009 amounted to $25.5&nbsp;million, which includes $15.6&nbsp;million of accretion.
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	GOLDCORP&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;28
</DIV>

<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<!-- XBRL -->
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF; MARGIN-LEFT: .25IN; WIDTH: 7.20IN">
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	(in United States dollars and tabular amounts in millions, except where noted)
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT">
<TABLE WIDTH="96%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 6PT">
<TD WIDTH="3%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="96">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(c)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	On May&nbsp;18, 2007, the Company entered into a $1.5&nbsp;billion revolving credit facility. The
	revolving credit facility is unsecured and amounts drawn are required to be refinanced or
	repaid on or by May&nbsp;18, 2012. Effective June&nbsp;1, 2009, amounts drawn incur interest at LIBOR
	plus 0.25% to 0.70% per annum dependent upon the Company&#146;s debt ratings, increasing by an
	additional 0.05% per annum if the total amount drawn under this facility exceeds $750
	million. Undrawn amounts are subject to a 0.07% to 0.175% per annum commitment fee
	dependent on the Company&#146;s debt ratings. There was no amount outstanding under this
	facility at December&nbsp;31, 2009 and 2008. A portion of the proceeds from issuance of the
	notes on June&nbsp;5, 2009
<I>
	(note 11(b))
</I>
	was used to repay the outstanding balance of $355.0
	million under this facility from draws made during the period from January&nbsp;1, 2009 to June
	5, 2009. There were no draws made under this facility subsequent to June&nbsp;5, 2009.
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>

<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage232"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<!-- XBRL -->
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF; MARGIN-LEFT: .25IN; WIDTH: 7.20IN">
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	(in United States dollars and tabular amounts in millions, except where noted)
</DIV>
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 6PT">
<TD WIDTH="3%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="96">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(a)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	The Mexican government approved its 2010 fiscal budget on December&nbsp;15, 2009 which
	included several significant changes to the Mexican income tax laws. The corporate income
	tax rate is being increased from 28% to 30% for the period from January&nbsp;1, 2010 through
	December&nbsp;31, 2012 and reduced to 29% in 2013 and back to 28% in 2014 and thereafter. As a
	result, the Company&#146;s future income tax liabilities increased by $26.2&nbsp;million in the
	fourth quarter of 2009. In addition the Mexican government modified its consolidated tax
	return rules such that the Company could only benefit from a maximum 5&nbsp;year (formerly a
	maximum 10&nbsp;year) tax deferral of taxable income resulting from losses of companies within
	the consolidated group reducing taxable income of other companies within the consolidated
	group. Included with the changes to the consolidated tax return rules are provisions that
	tax the Company&#146;s past consolidation benefits retroactively by estimating the tax benefits
	of consolidation at December&nbsp;31, 2009 and requiring the company to repay the benefits in
	future years. This element of the changes to the consolidated tax return rules has
	resulted in what the Company considers a double taxation of income earned by the
	consolidated group. The Company has estimated that the income tax impact of this new
	legislation at December&nbsp;31, 2009 could potentially be $79.1&nbsp;million, of which $7.9
	million, $23.6&nbsp;million, and $47.6&nbsp;million would be payable evenly during the period 2013
	to 2017, 2014 to 2018 and 2015 to 2019, respectively, without additional tax
	restructuring. The Company has the ability and intends to execute a plan that is fully
	within its control and solely at its discretion to merge two entities within the
	consolidated group in 2013 which will reduce the estimated income tax impact to $12.8
	million, of which $8.4&nbsp;million and $4.4&nbsp;million is payable evenly during the period 2015
	to 2019 and 2018 to 2022, respectively. Accordingly, the Company has recorded an income
	and mining taxes payable, classified as long-term, and a current income tax expense of
	$12.8&nbsp;million as at and for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009. There is an expectation that
	Mexico may publish technical corrections to certain aspects of the Tax Reform Bill in 2010
	that could significantly reduce the amounts due from the Company as described above.
	However, there is no assurance that Mexico will in fact publish such corrections, nor is
	it clear what impact any corrections published will have on the Company&#146;s actual liability
	under the new law. Although any ultimate outcome is uncertain, the Company intends to
	contest the validity and effective date of the new legislation.
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	The effective tax rate in 2009 also includes the impact of a reduction of future income tax
	liabilities of $40.1&nbsp;million resulting from Canadian provincial and federal income tax rate
	reductions enacted in the fourth quarter of 2009.
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 3PT">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
	(b)
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
	Mexico introduced a flat tax (&#147;IETU tax&#148;) effective January&nbsp;1, 2008 to replace the
	previous asset tax as the minimum tax. The IETU tax is calculated on a cash flow basis,
	with the tax base determined by reducing taxable revenue with specific deductions. In
	general if deductions exceed revenues, a credit is granted which may be credited against
	the IETU tax in the following years. Taxpayers first compute their income tax liability and
	their IETU tax liability for a fiscal year. As the income tax liability may be credited
	against the IETU tax liability, the IETU tax is payable only to the extent it exceeds the
	income tax payable by a Mexican entity. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008, IETU tax
	credits earned by a subsidiary reduced Mexican income taxes payable by the Company by $37.8
	million. The ability to use IETU tax credits in the future to reduce income taxes was
	eliminated with the Mexican tax law changes passed in 2009, effective 2010. No IETU tax
	credits were used to reduce Mexican income taxes payable in 2009. In certain circumstances
	IETU tax credits can be used to reduce income taxes in the year they are generated.
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	GOLDCORP&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;30
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	&nbsp;
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	&nbsp;
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>

<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
<B>
<I>
	Tax Loss Carryforwards, Investment Tax Credits, and AMT Credits
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2009, the Company had the following unused tax losses and other income tax
	deductions for which it has recognized a future income tax asset:
</DIV>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_82"></A>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT">
<TABLE STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT" CELLSPACING="0" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="96%">
<!-- BEGIN TABLE HEAD -->
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD WIDTH="44%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="9%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="9%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage234"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<!-- XBRL -->
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF; MARGIN-LEFT: .25IN; WIDTH: 7.20IN">
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	(in United States dollars and tabular amounts in millions, except where noted)
</DIV>
<!-- XBRL,N -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	13.
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<B>
	RECLAMATION AND CLOSURE COST OBLIGATIONS
</B>
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<!-- XBRL,BODY -->
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	The present value of the Company&#146;s reclamation and closure cost obligations at December&nbsp;31,
	2009 is $306.5&nbsp;million (2008 &#151; $284.5&nbsp;million), calculated using a discount rate of 5%. The
	amount relating to operating and inactive mines and development projects is $232.9&nbsp;million,
	$49.4&nbsp;million and $24.2&nbsp;million, respectively, (2008 &#151; $222.7&nbsp;million, $48.2&nbsp;million and $13.6
	million, respectively) reflecting payments for approximately the next 100&nbsp;years. Reclamation and
	closure activities include land rehabilitation, demolition of buildings and mine facilities,
	ongoing care and maintenance and other costs.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	The undiscounted value of the obligation at December&nbsp;31, 2009 is $523.5&nbsp;million (2008 &#151; $482.9
	million), calculated using an inflation rate assumption of 2%. Accretion expense for the year
	ended December&nbsp;31, 2009 was $14.7&nbsp;million (2008 &#151; $13.8&nbsp;million; 2007 &#151; $10.8&nbsp;million). Changes
	to the Company&#146;s reclamation and closure cost obligations during the years ended December&nbsp;31 are
	as follows:
</DIV>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_83"></A>

<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage235"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<!-- XBRL -->
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF; MARGIN-LEFT: .25IN; WIDTH: 7.20IN">
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	(in United States dollars and tabular amounts in millions, except where noted)
</DIV>
<!-- XBRL,N -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	14.
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<B>
	EMPLOYEE PENSION PLANS
</B>
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<!-- XBRL,BODY -->
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	Total cash payments for employee pension plans for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009,
	consisting of cash contributed by the Company to its funded defined benefit pension plans, cash
	payments directly to beneficiaries of its unfunded defined benefit pension plans and cash
	contributed to its defined contribution plans was $17.1&nbsp;million (2008 &#151; $14.5&nbsp;million; 2007 -
	$10.0&nbsp;million).
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
<B>
	Defined contribution pension plans
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	The Company has several defined contribution pension plans covering substantially all employees
	in North America. Under these plans, the Company contributes either a fixed percentage of the
	employees&#146; salaries or matches a percentage of the employees&#146; contributions. The employees are
	able to direct the contributions into a variety of investment funds offered by the plans. The
	Company&#146;s expense related to these plans was $13.9&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009
	(2008 &#151; $11.8&nbsp;million; 2007 &#151; $7.8&nbsp;million), included in operating expenses and corporate
	administration in the Consolidated Statements of Earnings.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
<B>
	Defined benefit pension plans
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	The Company has several defined benefit pension plans covering certain of its Canadian
	employees, which were assumed upon the acquisition of certain of Placer Dome Inc.&#146;s assets in
	2006, and a defined benefit plan for certain of its employees in Mexico.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	The following table summarizes the changes in the Company&#146;s accrued benefit obligation and fair
	value of plan assets during the years ended December&nbsp;31 and the reconciliation of the Company&#146;s
	accrued benefit obligation to the accrued benefit liability at December&nbsp;31:
</DIV>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_84"></A>

</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	The Company measures its accrued benefit obligation and the fair value of plan assets for
	accounting purposes as at December&nbsp;31 of each year. The most recent actuarial valuation of the
	pension plans for funding purposes was as at December&nbsp;31, 2007, and the next required valuation
	will be as at December&nbsp;31, 2010.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	GOLDCORP&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;33
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	&nbsp;
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	&nbsp;
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>

<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
<B>
	Plan assets
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	The Company&#146;s Employee Benefits Committee maintains and establishes investment policies relating
	to the Company&#146;s defined benefit and defined contribution pension plans. The Company&#146;s Board of
	Directors approves these policies and any material changes to these policies.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	The composition of plan assets relating to the Company&#146;s defined benefit pension plans at
	December&nbsp;31 is as follows:
</DIV>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_87"></A>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT">
<TABLE STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT" CELLSPACING="0" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="96%">
<!-- BEGIN TABLE HEAD -->
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD WIDTH="72%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="9%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage237"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<!-- XBRL -->
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF; MARGIN-LEFT: .25IN; WIDTH: 7.20IN">
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	(in United States dollars and tabular amounts in millions, except where noted)
</DIV>
<!-- XBRL,N -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	15.
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<B>
	FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS
</B>
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<!-- XBRL,BODY -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="4%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	(a)
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Financial assets and liabilities
</B>
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	The Company&#146;s financial instruments at December&nbsp;31, 2009 and 2008 consist of cash, short-term
	money market investments, marketable securities, accounts receivable, investments in equity
	securities and warrants, accounts payable and accrued liabilities, current and long-term debt
	including convertible debt, and foreign currency, heating oil and copper contracts.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
<B>
<I>
	Classification of financial assets and liabilities
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	Cash and short-term money market investments are classified as held-for-trading. Accounts
	receivable arising from sales of metal concentrates are designated and classified as
	held-for-trading. Investments in warrants held by the Company are for long-term investment
	purposes, however, due to their nature meet the definition of derivatives and are classified as
	held-for-trading. The Company enters into foreign currency contracts to manage its exposure to
	fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates. The Company also enters into heating oil and
	copper contracts to manage its exposure to fuel and copper prices, respectively. These contracts
	meet the definition of derivatives and do not meet the criteria for hedge accounting. As a
	result, these contracts are classified as held-for-trading. Held-for-trading financial assets
	are measured at fair value with mark-to-market gains and losses recorded in earnings in the
	period they occur. The carrying amounts of cash and short-term money market investments
	approximate their fair values. The change in fair values of accounts receivable arising from
	sales of metal concentrates result from changes in metal market prices to which the related
	revenues are subject. These changes are recorded in revenue in the period they occur. Fair
	values of investments in warrants that are publicly traded are quoted market prices. Fair values
	of investments in warrants held that are not publicly traded are estimated using the
	Black-Scholes option pricing model with inputs based on observable market data. Fair values of
	foreign currency contracts are determined based on various observable market data, including
	foreign exchange forward curves, exchange rate volatility and the risk-free interest rate. Fair
	values of heating oil and copper contracts are determined by reference to published heating oil
	and copper prices in an active market.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	Marketable securities and investments in equity securities are classified as available-for-sale
	because the Company does not hold these securities for the purpose of trading.
	Available-for-sale financial assets are measured at fair value with mark-to-market gains and
	losses recognized directly in OCI. Fair values of marketable securities and investments in
	equity securities are quoted market prices.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	Accounts receivable not arising from sales of metal concentrates are classified as loans and
	receivables. Accounts payable and accrued liabilities and long-term debt including the debt
	component of the Company&#146;s notes
<I>
	(note
</I>
<I>
	11(b)
</I>
<I>
	)
</I>
	are classified as other financial liabilities.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
<B>
<I>
	Fair value measurements of financial assets and liabilities recognized in the balance sheet
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	The amendments to Section&nbsp;3862
<I>
	(note 3)
</I>
	introduce a fair value hierarchy that reflects the
	significance of inputs used in making fair value measurements as follows:
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	Level 1 &#151; quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities;
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	Level 2 &#151; inputs other than quoted prices included in Level 1 that are observable for the asset
	or liability, either directly (i.e.: as prices) or indirectly (i.e.: derived from prices); and
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	Level 3 &#151; inputs for the asset or liability that are not based on observable market data.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	GOLDCORP&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;35
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	&nbsp;
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	&nbsp;
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage238"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<!-- XBRL -->
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF; MARGIN-LEFT: .25IN; WIDTH: 7.20IN">
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>

<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	(in United States dollars and tabular amounts in millions, except where noted)
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2009, the levels in the fair value hierarchy into which the Company&#146;s financial
	assets and liabilities measured and recognized in the balance sheet at fair value are
	categorized are as follows:
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT">

<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2009, there were no financial assets or liabilities measured and recognized in
	the balance sheet at fair value that would be categorized as level 3 in the fair value hierarchy
	above.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
<B>
<I>
	Fair values of financial assets and liabilities not already measured and recognized at fair
	value in the balance sheet
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2009 the carrying amounts of accounts receivable not arising from sales of metal
	concentrates and accounts payable and accrued liabilities are considered to be reasonable
	approximations of their fair values due to the short-term nature of these instruments. The
	carrying amount of the Company&#146;s non-revolving term loan
<I>
	(note
</I>
<I>
	11(a)
</I>
<I>
	)
</I>
	approximates the fair
	value due to its floating interest rates being in line with market interest rates.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	On initial recognition, the carrying amount of the liability component of the Company&#146;s notes
	(
<I>
	note 11(b)
</I>
	) equaled the fair value of the notes on that date. The fair value of the notes was
	calculated as the Company&#146;s contractual obligation to make principal and interest payments
	discounted to net present value using the market interest rate on similar borrowings but without
	the conversion feature on the initial recognition date of June&nbsp;5, 2009, being 6.33% per annum.
	The initial carrying amount of the liability component of the notes has been accreted from June
	5, 2009 to December&nbsp;31, 2009 based on the annual effective interest rate of 6.33%. The estimated
	market interest rate on similar borrowings without the conversion feature has decreased to
	approximately 4% per annum as at December&nbsp;31, 2009. Accordingly, the fair value of the liability
	component of the notes has increased to $796.9&nbsp;million, compared to a carrying amount of $728.9
	million, which includes $9.9&nbsp;million of accrued interest payable included in accounts payable
	and accrued liabilities at December&nbsp;31, 2009.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
<B>
<I>
	Marketable securities and investments
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	The Company&#146;s investments in warrants, classified as held-for-trading, and marketable securities
	and investments in equity securities, classified as available-for-sale, are recorded at fair
	value. The balances outstanding for these instruments at December&nbsp;31 and the related gains and
	losses for the years ended December&nbsp;31 are as follows:
</DIV>

</TABLE>
</DIV>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	During the period from June&nbsp;30, 2008, the date of the Peak Gold/New Gold business combination
<I>
	(note
</I>
<I>
	4(f)
</I>
<I>
	)
</I>
	, to December&nbsp;31, 2008, the fair value of the Company&#146;s investment in New Gold
	continued to decline. New Gold recorded a write-down of $156.9&nbsp;million on its Amapari mine in
	its 2008 third quarter results. While significant resources remained at Amapari, the additional
	capital resources required to maintain economic production levels and the limited remaining
	oxide reserves justified the decision to place the mine on temporary care and maintenance and
	mining was suspended as of January&nbsp;2, 2009. In addition, New Gold revised its development plan
	for the New Afton project with full production expected for the second half of 2012 instead of
	the previous expectation of operations commencing in late 2009 with full production in the
	second quarter of 2011. The adverse changes that took place in the economic environment in which
	New Gold operates and the continued decline in the market price of its shares below the
	Company&#146;s original cost (market price of shares at June&nbsp;30, 2008 was C$7.83 per share which
	dropped continuously to C$1.77 per share at December&nbsp;31, 2008 with original cost at C$6.70 per
	share) provided objective evidence that the decline in fair value of the Company&#146;s investment
	was other than temporary. Accordingly, the Company removed the cumulative mark-to-market loss
	that had been previously recognized in AOCI as at December&nbsp;31, 2008 and recognized an impairment
	loss on available-for-sale securities of $81.5&nbsp;million in earnings during the fourth quarter of
	2008.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	During the third quarter of 2008, the Company determined that the decline in the fair value of
	one other investment in equity securities was other than temporary. The adverse changes that
	took place in the economic and political environment in which the equity investee operates and
	the continued decline in the market price of the equity investee&#146;s shares below the Company&#146;s
	original cost provided evidence that the decline in fair value of the Company&#146;s investment was
	other than temporary and that the Company&#146;s investment was impaired. Accordingly, the Company
	removed the cumulative mark-to-market loss that had been previously recognized in AOCI as at
	December&nbsp;31, 2008 relating to the investment and recognized an impairment loss on
	available-for-sale securities of $29.7&nbsp;million in earnings for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008.
	During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009, the fair value of this investment increased. At
	December&nbsp;31, 2009, the amount of mark-to-market gain recorded in AOCI relating to this
	investment was $2.4&nbsp;million.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	GOLDCORP&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;37
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	&nbsp;
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	&nbsp;
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>

<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;

<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF; MARGIN-LEFT: .25IN; WIDTH: 7.20IN">
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_91"></A>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	(in United States dollars and tabular amounts in millions, except where noted)
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	The Company disposed of its investment in New Gold on October&nbsp;13, 2009 for net proceeds of $65.2
	million. During the period from January&nbsp;1, 2009 to October&nbsp;13, 2009, the fair value of the
	Company&#146;s investment in New Gold increased. The cumulative mark-to-market gains recognized in
	AOCI at October&nbsp;13, 2009 amounted to $43.0&nbsp;million. This amount was removed from AOCI and
	reclassified to earnings upon derecognition of the investment resulting in a recognized gain of
	$42.8&nbsp;million, net of selling costs of $0.2&nbsp;million.

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
<B>
<I>
	(ii)&nbsp;Embedded derivatives
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	Financial instruments and non-financial contracts may contain embedded derivatives, which are
	required to be accounted for separately at fair value as derivatives when the risks and
	characteristics of the embedded derivatives are not closely related to those of their host
	contract and the host contract is not measured at fair value. The Company regularly assesses its
	financial instruments and non-financial contracts to ensure that any embedded derivatives are
	accounted for in accordance with its policy. There were no material embedded derivatives
	requiring separate accounting at December&nbsp;31, 2009 or 2008. Embedded derivatives relating to
	sales of metal concentrates that are subject to provisional pricing are not required to be
	accounted for separately as outstanding amounts are measured at fair value at the end of each
	period.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	GOLDCORP&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;39
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	&nbsp;
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	&nbsp;
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage242"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<!-- XBRL -->
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF; MARGIN-LEFT: .25IN; WIDTH: 7.20IN">
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	(in United States dollars and tabular amounts in millions, except where noted)
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; COLOR: #000000; BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
<TD WIDTH="4%" STYLE="BACKGROUND: TRANSPARENT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	(b)
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Financial instrument risk exposure
</B>
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	The Company manages its exposure to financial risks, including credit risk, liquidity risk,
	currency risk, interest rate risk and price risk, in accordance with its Risk Management Policy.
	The Company&#146;s Board of Directors oversees management&#146;s risk management practices by setting
	trading parameters and reporting requirements. The Risk Management Policy provides a framework
	for the Company to manage the risks it is exposed to in various markets and to protect itself
	against adverse market movements. All transactions undertaken are to support the Company&#146;s
	ongoing business. The Company does not acquire or issue derivative financial instruments for
	trading or speculative purposes.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	The following describes the types of risks that the Company is exposed to and its objectives and
	policies for managing those risk exposures:
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
<B>
<I>
	Credit risk
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	Credit risk is the risk that the counterparty to a financial instrument will cause a financial
	loss for the Company by failing to discharge its obligations. Credit risk is primarily
	associated with trade receivables; however, it also arises on cash and cash equivalents and
	derivative assets. To mitigate exposure to credit risk on financial assets, the Company has
	established policies to limit the concentration of credit risk, ensure counterparties
	demonstrate minimum acceptable credit worthiness and ensure liquidity of available funds.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	The Company closely monitors its financial assets and does not have any significant
	concentration of credit risk. The Company invests its cash and cash equivalents in highly rated
	corporations and government issuances in accordance with its short-term investment policy and
	the credit risk associated with its money market investments is considered to be low. The
	Company sells its products exclusively to large international financial institutions and other
	organizations with strong credit ratings. The historical level of customer defaults is
	negligible and, as a result, the credit risk associated with trade receivables at December&nbsp;31,
	2009 is considered to be negligible. The Company&#146;s foreign currency, heating oil and copper
	contracts are entered into with large international financial institutions with strong credit
	ratings.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	The Company&#146;s maximum exposure to credit risk at December&nbsp;31 is as follows:
</DIV>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_93"></A>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT">
<TABLE STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT" CELLSPACING="0" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="96%">

</DIV>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 14PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
<B>
<I>
	Liquidity risk
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	Liquidity risk is the risk that the Company will encounter difficulty in meeting obligations
	associated with its financial liabilities that are settled by delivering cash or another
	financial asset. The Company has in place a rigorous planning, budgeting and forecasting process
	to help determine the funds required to support the Company&#146;s normal operating requirements on
	an ongoing basis and its expansionary plans. The Company ensures that sufficient committed loan
	facilities exist to meet its short-term business requirements, taking into account its
	anticipated cash flows from operations and its holdings of cash and cash equivalents. During the
	year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009, the Company generated operating cash flows from continuing
	activities of $1,270.2&nbsp;million (2008 &#151; $866.0&nbsp;million; 2007 &#151; $650.7&nbsp;million).
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2009, Goldcorp held cash and cash equivalents of $874.6&nbsp;million (2008- $262.3
	million) and had working capital of $866.5&nbsp;million (2008 &#151; $274.5&nbsp;million).
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	GOLDCORP&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;40
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	&nbsp;
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	&nbsp;
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

<A NAME="eolPage243"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<!-- XBRL -->
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF; MARGIN-LEFT: .25IN; WIDTH: 7.20IN">
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	(in United States dollars and tabular amounts in millions, except where noted)
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	On May&nbsp;18, 2007, Goldcorp entered into a $1.5&nbsp;billion revolving credit facility. At December&nbsp;31,
	2009, there was no amount outstanding under this credit facility
<I>
	(note
</I>
<I>
	11(c)
</I>
<I>
	)
</I>
	. On July&nbsp;8, 2008,
	Terrane entered into a credit agreement for an 18-month, non-revolving term loan facility of up
	to C$40&nbsp;million. On January&nbsp;7, 2010, this credit facility was extended to May&nbsp;7, 2010. At
	December&nbsp;31, 2009, the amount outstanding was C$17.5&nbsp;million ($16.7&nbsp;million)
<I>
	(note
</I>
<I>
	11(a)
</I>
<I>
	)
</I>
	.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	In the normal course of business, the Company enters into contracts and performs business
	activities that give rise to commitments for future minimum payments. The following table
	summarizes the contractual maturities of the Company&#146;s financial liabilities and operating and
	capital commitments at December&nbsp;31:
</DIV>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>

</TABLE>
</DIV>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2009, the Company had letters of credit outstanding and secured deposits in the
	amount of $270.9&nbsp;million (2008 &#151; $201.3&nbsp;million).
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	In the opinion of management, the working capital at December&nbsp;31, 2009, together with future
	cash flows from operations, is sufficient to support the Company&#146;s commitments. The Company&#146;s
	total planned capital expenditures for 2010 with a focus on commissioning Pe&#241;asquito in 2010 and
	further developing Pueblo Viejo are forecasted to be approximately $1.5&nbsp;billion. These
	expenditures will be funded partly by available cash balances, cash flows from operations,
	available funding under the $1.5&nbsp;billion revolving credit facility and anticipated project
	financing loan of approximately $1.0&nbsp;billion ($400.0&nbsp;million &#151; Goldcorp&#146;s share). The
	acquisitions completed in February&nbsp;2010
<I>
	(notes
</I>
<I>
	24(a)
</I>
<I>
	and (b))
</I>
	will be funded by available cash
	balances and funding under the $1.5&nbsp;billion revolving credit facility
<I>
	(note
</I>
<I>
	11(c)
</I>
<I>
	).
</I>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	For the periods beyond 2010, cash flows from operations and available funding under the
	Company&#146;s loan facilities are expected to sufficiently support further expansions and growth.
	Pe&#241;asquito will be the main driver of the Company&#146;s gold production growth expected in the next
	five years, with significant contributions from Red Lake and Pueblo Viejo.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
<B>
<I>
	Market Risk
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
<B>
<I>
	(i)&nbsp;Currency risk
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	Currency risk is the risk that the fair values or future cash flows of the Company&#146;s financial
	instruments will fluctuate because of changes in foreign currency exchange rates. Exchange rate
	fluctuations may affect the costs that the Company incurs in its operations. Gold, silver,
	copper, zinc and lead are sold in US dollars and the Company&#146;s costs are incurred principally in
	US dollars, Canadian dollars, Mexican pesos, Argentinean pesos and Guatemalan quetzals. The
	appreciation of non-US dollar currencies against the US dollar can increase the costs of gold,
	silver, copper, zinc and lead production and capital expenditures in US dollar terms. The
	Company also holds cash and cash equivalents that are denominated in non-US dollar currencies
	which are subject to currency risk. Accounts receivable and other current and long-term assets
	denominated in non-US dollars relate to goods and services taxes, value-added taxes and
	insurance receivables. At December&nbsp;31, 2009, the Company had $3.7&nbsp;billion of future income
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	GOLDCORP&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;41
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	&nbsp;
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	&nbsp;
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>

<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<!-- XBRL -->
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF; MARGIN-LEFT: .25IN; WIDTH: 7.20IN">
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	(in United States dollars and tabular amounts in millions, except where noted)
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	tax liabilities which arose primarily from the acquisitions of Placer Dome Inc.&#146;s assets and
	Glamis in 2006 and Gold Eagle in the third quarter of 2008 which are payable in local
	currencies. The future income tax liabilities are considered monetary items, which are
	translated each period end at current exchange rates, with the gain or loss recorded in earnings
	for the period.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	The Company is exposed to currency risk through the following financial assets and liabilities
	and future income tax liabilities denominated in currencies other than US dollars at December
	31:
</DIV>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_95"></A>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009, the Company recognized a loss of $366.6&nbsp;million on
	foreign exchange (2008 &#151; gain of $1,058.9&nbsp;million; 2007 &#151; loss of $49.4&nbsp;million). Of this
	amount, $324.3&nbsp;million resulted from the translation of future income taxes denominated in
	currencies other than US dollars (2008 &#151; gain of $1,070.9&nbsp;million; 2007 &#151; loss of $54.6
	million). Based on the above net exposures at December&nbsp;31, 2009, a 10% depreciation or
	appreciation of the above currencies against the US dollar would result in a $282.5&nbsp;million
	increase or decrease in the Company&#146;s after-tax net earnings, respectively.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009, the Company entered into Canadian dollar and Mexican
	peso forward and option contracts to purchase and sell the respective foreign currencies at
	pre-determined US dollar amounts
<I>
	(note
</I>
<I>
	15(a)
</I>
<I>
	)
</I>
	. These contracts were entered into to normalize
	operating expenses incurred by the Company&#146;s foreign operations as expressed in US dollar terms.
	In accordance with its Risk Management Policy, the Company may hedge up to 50% and 30% of its
	annual Canadian dollar and Mexican peso operating expenditures over the next twelve months and
	subsequent thirteen to twenty four months, respectively. The Company entered into nominal
	foreign currency contracts during the fourth quarter of 2008 that matured within the quarter. No
	foreign currency contracts were entered into during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
<B>
<I>
	(ii)&nbsp;Interest rate risk
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	Interest rate risk is the risk that the fair values and future cash flows of the Company&#146;s
	financial instruments will fluctuate because of changes in market interest rates. The Company is
	exposed to interest rate risk on its outstanding revolving credit facility and non-revolving
	term loan and cash and cash equivalents. The Company monitors its exposure to interest rates and
	is comfortable with its exposures given the relatively low short-term US dollar rates. The
	weighted average interest rate incurred by the Company
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	GOLDCORP&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;42
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	&nbsp;
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<!-- FOLIO -->
	&nbsp;
<!-- /FOLIO -->
</DIV>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P>
<A NAME="eolPage245"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<!-- XBRL -->
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF; MARGIN-LEFT: .25IN; WIDTH: 7.20IN">
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	(in United States dollars and tabular amounts in millions, except where noted)
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009 on outstanding balances under its revolving credit
	facility and non-revolving term loan was 0.83% (2008 &#151; 4.12%; 2007 &#151; 5.63%). At December&nbsp;31,
	2009, a 10% increase or decrease in the interest rate would result in a nominal decrease or
	increase in the Company&#146;s after-tax net earnings. The average interest rate earned by the
	Company during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009 on its cash and cash equivalents was 0.22% (2008
	&#151; 2.68%; 2007 &#151; 5.16%). A 10% increase or decrease in the interest earned from financial
	institutions on deposits held and money market investments would result in a nominal increase or
	decrease in the Company&#146;s after-tax net earnings, respectively.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
<B>
<I>
	(iii)&nbsp;Price risk
</I>
</B>
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	Price risk is the risk that the fair value or future cash flows of the Company&#146;s financial
	instruments will fluctuate because of changes in market prices. Profitability of the Company
	depends on metal prices for gold, silver, copper, zinc and lead. Metal prices are affected by
	numerous factors such as the sale or purchase of gold and silver by various central banks and
	financial institutions, interest rates, exchange rates, inflation or deflation, fluctuations in
	the value of the US dollar and foreign currencies, global and regional supply and demand, and
	the political and economic conditions of major producing countries throughout the world. A 10%
	increase or decrease in metal prices would result in a $212.0&nbsp;million increase or decrease in
	the Company&#146;s after-tax net earnings, respectively. The Company has a policy not to hedge gold
	sales. In accordance with the Company&#146;s Risk Management Policy, the Company may hedge up to 50%
	of its base metal sales volume over the next fifteen months to manage its exposure to
	fluctuations in base metal prices
<I>
	(note
</I>
<I>
	15(a)
</I>
<I>
	)
</I>
	.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	The costs relating to the Company&#146;s production, development and exploration activities vary
	depending on the market prices of certain mining consumables including diesel and electricity. A
	10% increase or decrease in diesel market prices would result in an $8.0&nbsp;million decrease or
	increase in the Company&#146;s after-tax net earnings, respectively. The Company does not intend to
	hedge against diesel price fluctuations in Mexico as the government regulates the domestic
	market. The Company has entered into contracts to hedge against diesel price fluctuations in
	Canada and the United States through NYMEX heating oil contracts as a proxy for diesel.
	Electricity is regionally priced in Ontario, Canada and Mexico and semi-regulated by the
	provincial and federal governments, respectively. The regulation of electricity prices reduces
	the risk of price fluctuation and the Company therefore does not contemplate entering into
	contracts to hedge against such risk.
</DIV>
<!-- XBRL,N -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">

<TD WIDTH="3%" NOWRAP ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	16.
</B>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;

<B>
	MANAGEMENT OF CAPITAL
</B>
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<!-- XBRL,BODY -->
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	The Company&#146;s objectives of capital management are to safeguard the entity&#146;s ability to
	support the Company&#146;s normal operating requirements on an ongoing basis, continue the
	development and exploration of its mineral properties and support any expansionary plans.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">

	debt, net of cash and cash equivalents as follows:

<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	The Company manages its capital structure and makes adjustments in light of changes in its
	economic environment and the risk characteristics of the Company&#146;s assets. To effectively manage
	the entity&#146;s capital requirements, the Company has in place a rigorous planning, budgeting and
	forecasting process to help determine the funds required to ensure the Company has the
	appropriate liquidity to meet its operating and growth objectives. The Company ensures that
	there are sufficient committed loan
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	GOLDCORP&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;43
</DIV>

<P>
<A NAME="eolPage246"></A>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
	&nbsp;
</H5>
<P>
<!-- XBRL -->
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY: 'TIMES NEW ROMAN',TIMES,SERIF; MARGIN-LEFT: .25IN; WIDTH: 7.20IN">
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="RIGHT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT">
	(in United States dollars and tabular amounts in millions, except where noted)
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	facilities to meet its short-term business requirements, taking into account its anticipated
	cash flows from operations and its holdings of cash and cash equivalents.
</DIV>
<DIV ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 10PT; MARGIN-LEFT: 4%">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2009, the Company expects its capital resources which includes anticipated
	project financing for Pueblo Viejo
<I>
	(note
</I>
<I>
	15(b)
</I>
<I>
	)
</I>
	and projected free cash flows from continuing
	operations to support its normal operating requirements and planned development and exploration
	of its mineral properties. At December&nbsp;31, 2009, there was no externally imposed capital
	requirement, to which the Company is subject, which the Company has not complied with.
</DIV>
